
   
MONKSHAVEN
  
<EOS>
On
the
north
-
eastern
shores
of
England
there
is
a
town
called
Monkshaven
,
containing
at
the
present
day
about
fifteen
thousand
inhabitants
.
<EOS>
There
were
,
however
,
but
half
the
number
at
the
end
of
the
last
century
,
and
it
was
at
that
period
that
the
events
narrated
in
the
following
pages
occurred
.
  
<EOS>
Monkshaven
was
a
name
not
unknown
in
the
history
of
England
,
and
traditions
of
its
having
been
the
landing
-
place
of
a
throneless
queen
were
current
in
the
town
.
<EOS>
At
that
time
there
had
been
a
fortified
castle
on
the
heights
above
it
,
the
site
of
which
was
now
occupied
by
a
deserted
manor
-
house
;
and
at
an
even
earlier
date
than
the
arrival
of
the
queen
and
coeval
with
the
most
ancient
remains
of
the
castle
,
a
great
monastery
had
stood
on
those
cliffs
,
overlooking
the
vast
ocean
that
blended
with
the
distant
sky
.
<EOS>
Monkshaven
itself
was
built
by
the
side
of
the
Dee
,
just
where
the
river
falls
into
the
German
Ocean
.
<EOS>
The
principal
street
of
the
town
ran
parallel
to
the
stream
,
and
smaller
lanes
branched
out
of
this
,
and
straggled
up
the
sides
of
the
steep
hill
,
between
which
and
the
river
<EOS>
the
houses
were
pent
in
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
bridge
across
the
Dee
,
and
consequently
a
Bridge
Street
running
at
right
angles
to
the
High
Street
;
and
on
the
south
side
of
the
stream
there
were
a
few
houses
of
more
pretension
,
around
which
lay
gardens
and
fields
.
<EOS>
It
was
on
this
side
of
the
town
that
the
local
aristocracy
lived
.
<EOS>
And
who
were
the
great
people
of
this
small
town
?
<EOS>
Not
the
younger
branches
of
the
county
families
that
held
hereditary
state
in
their
manor
-
houses
on
the
wild
bleak
moors
,
that
shut
in
Monkshaven
almost
as
effectually
on
the
land
side
as
ever
<EOS>
the
waters
did
on
the
sea
-
board
.
<EOS>
No
;
these
old
families
kept
aloof
from
the
unsavoury
yet
adventurous
trade
which
brought
wealth
to
generation
after
generation
of
certain
families
in
Monkshaven
.
  
<EOS>
The
magnates
of
Monkshaven
were
those
who
had
the
largest
number
of
ships
engaged
in
the
whaling
-
trade
.
<EOS>
Something
like
the
following
was
the
course
of
life
with
a
Monkshaven
lad
of
this
class
:
 
<EOS>
He
was
apprenticed
as
a
sailor
to
one
of
the
great
ship
-
owners
 
to
his
own
father
,
possibly
 
along
with
twenty
other
boys
,
or
,
it
might
be
,
even
more
.
<EOS>
During
the
summer
months
he
and
his
fellow
apprentices
made
voyages
to
the
Greenland
seas
,
returning
with
their
cargoes
in
the
early
autumn
;
and
employing
the
winter
months
in
watching
the
preparation
of
the
oil
from
the
blubber
in
the
melting
-
sheds
,
and
learning
navigation
from
some
quaint
but
experienced
teacher
,
half
schoolmaster
,
half
sailor
,
who
seasoned
his
instructions
by
stirring
narrations
of
the
wild
adventures
of
his
youth
.
<EOS>
The
house
of
the
ship
-
owner
to
whom
he
was
apprenticed
was
his
home
and
that
of
his
companions
during
the
idle
season
between
October
and
March
.
<EOS>
The
domestic
position
of
these
boys
varied
according
to
the
premium
paid
;
some
took
rank
with
the
sons
of
the
family
,
others
were
considered
as
little
better
than
servants
.
<EOS>
Yet
once
on
board
an
equality
prevailed
,
in
which
,
if
any
claimed
superiority
,
it
was
the
bravest
and
brightest
.
<EOS>
After
a
certain
number
of
voyages
the
Monkshaven
lad
would
rise
by
degrees
to
be
captain
,
and
as
such
would
have
a
share
in
the
venture
;
all
these
profits
,
as
well
as
all
his
savings
,
would
go
towards
building
a
whaling
vessel
of
his
own
,
if
he
was
not
so
fortunate
as
to
be
the
child
of
a
ship
-
owner
.
<EOS>
At
the
time
of
which
I
write
,
there
was
but
little
division
of
labour
in
the
Monkshaven
whale
fishery
.
<EOS>
The
same
man
might
be
the
owner
of
six
or
seven
ships
,
any
one
of
which
he
himself
was
fitted
by
education
and
experience
to
command
;
the
master
of
a
score
of
apprentices
,
each
of
whom
paid
a
pretty
sufficient
premium
;
and
the
proprietor
of
the
melting
-
sheds
into
which
his
cargoes
of
blubber
and
whalebone
were
conveyed
to
be
fitted
for
sale
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
wonder
that
large
fortunes
were
acquired
by
these
ship
-
owners
,
nor
that
their
houses
on
the
south
side
of
the
river
Dee
were
stately
mansions
,
full
of
handsome
and
substantial
furniture
.
<EOS>
It
was
also
not
surprising
that
the
whole
town
had
an
amphibious
appearance
,
to
a
degree
unusual
even
in
a
seaport
.
<EOS>
Every
one
depended
on
the
whale
fishery
,
and
almost
every
male
inhabitant
had
been
,
or
hoped
to
be
,
a
sailor
.
<EOS>
Down
by
the
river
the
smell
was
almost
intolerable
to
any
but
Monkshaven
people
during
certain
seasons
of
the
year
;
but
on
these
unsavoury
"
staithes
"
the
old
men
and
children
lounged
for
hours
,
almost
as
if
they
revelled
in
the
odours
of
train
-
oil
.
  
<EOS>
This
is
,
perhaps
,
enough
of
a
description
of
the
town
itself
.
<EOS>
I
have
said
that
the
country
for
miles
all
around
was
moorland
;
high
above
the
level
of
the
sea
<EOS>
towered
the
purple
crags
,
whose
summits
were
crowned
with
greensward
that
stole
down
the
sides
of
the
scaur
a
little
way
in
grassy
veins
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
a
brook
forced
its
way
from
the
heights
down
to
the
sea
,
making
its
channel
into
a
valley
more
or
less
broad
in
long
process
of
time
.
<EOS>
And
in
the
moorland
hollows
,
as
in
these
valleys
,
trees
and
underwood
grew
and
flourished
;
so
that
,
while
on
the
bare
swells
of
the
high
land
you
shivered
at
the
waste
desolation
of
the
scenery
,
when
you
dropped
into
these
wooded
"
bottoms
"
you
were
charmed
with
the
nestling
shelter
which
they
gave
.
<EOS>
But
above
and
around
these
rare
and
fertile
vales
there
were
moors
for
many
a
mile
,
here
<EOS>
and
there
bleak
enough
,
with
the
red
freestone
cropping
out
above
the
scanty
herbage
;
then
,
perhaps
,
there
was
a
brown
tract
of
peat
and
bog
,
uncertain
footing
for
the
pedestrian
who
tried
to
make
a
short
cut
to
his
destination
;
then
on
the
higher
sandy
soil
there
was
the
purple
ling
,
or
commonest
species
of
heather
growing
in
beautiful
wild
luxuriance
.
<EOS>
Tufts
of
fine
elastic
grass
were
occasionally
to
be
found
,
on
which
the
little
black
-
faced
sheep
browsed
;
but
either
the
scanty
food
,
or
their
goat
-
like
agility
,
kept
them
in
a
lean
condition
that
did
not
promise
much
for
the
butcher
,
nor
yet
was
their
wool
of
a
quality
fine
enough
to
make
them
profitable
in
that
way
to
their
owners
.
<EOS>
In
such
districts
there
is
little
population
at
the
present
day
;
there
was
much
less
in
the
last
century
,
before
agriculture
was
sufficiently
scientific
to
have
a
chance
of
contending
with
such
natural
disqualifications
as
the
moors
presented
,
and
when
there
were
no
facilities
of
railroads
to
bring
sportsmen
from
a
distance
to
enjoy
the
shooting
season
,
and
make
an
annual
demand
for
accommodation
.
  
<EOS>
There
were
old
stone
halls
in
the
valleys
;
there
were
bare
farmhouses
to
be
seen
on
the
moors
at
long
distances
apart
,
with
small
stacks
of
coarse
poor
hay
,
and
almost
larger
stacks
of
turf
for
winter
fuel
in
their
farmyards
.
<EOS>
The
cattle
in
the
pasture
fields
belonging
to
these
farms
looked
half
starved
;
but
somehow
there
was
an
odd
,
intelligent
expression
in
their
faces
,
as
well
as
in
those
of
the
black
-
visaged
sheep
,
which
is
seldom
seen
in
the
placidly
stupid
countenances
of
well
-
fed
animals
.
<EOS>
All
the
fences
were
turf
banks
,
with
loose
stones
piled
into
walls
on
the
top
of
these
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
comparative
fertility
and
luxuriance
down
below
in
the
rare
green
dales
.
<EOS>
The
narrow
meadows
stretching
along
the
brookside
seemed
as
though
the
cows
could
really
satisfy
their
hunger
in
the
deep
rich
grass
;
whereas
on
the
higher
lands
the
scanty
herbage
was
hardly
worth
the
fatigue
of
moving
about
in
search
of
it
.
<EOS>
Even
in
these
"
bottoms
"
the
piping
sea
-
winds
,
following
the
current
of
the
stream
,
stunted
and
cut
low
any
trees
;
but
still
there
was
rich
thick
underwood
,
tangled
and
tied
together
with
brambles
,
and
brier
-
rose
,
[
sic
]
and
honeysuckle
;
and
if
the
farmer
in
these
comparatively
happy
valleys
had
had
wife
or
daughter
who
cared
for
gardening
,
many
a
flower
would
have
grown
on
the
western
or
southern
side
of
the
rough
stone
house
.
<EOS>
But
at
that
time
gardening
was
not
a
popular
art
in
any
part
of
England
;
in
the
north
it
is
not
yet
.
<EOS>
Noblemen
and
gentlemen
may
have
beautiful
gardens
;
but
farmers
and
day
-
labourers
care
little
for
them
north
of
the
Trent
,
which
is
all
I
can
answer
for
.
<EOS>
A
few
"
berry
"
bushes
,
a
black
currant
tree
or
two
(
the
leaves
to
be
used
in
heightening
the
flavour
of
tea
,
the
fruit
as
medicinal
for
colds
and
sore
throats
)
,
a
potato
ground
(
and
this
was
not
so
common
at
the
close
of
the
last
century
as
it
is
now
)
,
a
cabbage
bed
,
a
bush
of
sage
,
and
balm
,
and
thyme
,
and
marjoram
,
with
possibly
a
rose
tree
,
and
"
old
man
"
growing
in
the
midst
;
a
little
plot
of
small
strong
coarse
onions
,
and
perhaps
some
marigolds
,
the
petals
of
which
flavoured
the
salt
-
beef
broth
;
such
plants
made
up
a
well
-
furnished
garden
to
a
farmhouse
at
the
time
and
place
to
which
my
story
belongs
.
<EOS>
But
for
twenty
miles
inland
there
was
no
forgetting
the
sea
,
nor
the
sea
-
trade
;
refuse
shell
-
fish
,
seaweed
,
the
offal
of
the
melting
-
houses
,
were
the
staple
manure
of
the
district
;
great
ghastly
whale
-
jaws
,
bleached
bare
and
white
,
were
the
arches
over
the
gate
-
posts
to
many
a
field
or
moorland
stretch
.
<EOS>
Out
of
every
family
of
several
sons
,
however
agricultural
their
position
might
be
,
one
had
gone
to
sea
,
and
the
mother
looked
wistfully
seaward
at
the
changes
of
the
keen
piping
moorland
winds
.
<EOS>
The
holiday
rambles
were
to
the
coast
;
no
one
cared
to
go
inland
to
see
aught
,
unless
indeed
it
might
be
to
the
great
annual
horse
-
fairs
held
where
the
dreary
land
broke
into
habitation
and
cultivation
.
  
<EOS>
Somehow
in
this
country
sea
thoughts
followed
the
thinker
far
inland
;
whereas
in
most
other
parts
of
the
island
,
at
five
miles
from
the
ocean
,
he
has
all
but
forgotten
the
existence
of
such
an
element
as
salt
water
.
<EOS>
The
great
Greenland
trade
of
the
coasting
towns
was
the
main
and
primary
cause
of
this
,
no
doubt
.
<EOS>
But
there
was
also
a
dread
and
an
irritation
in
every
one
's
mind
,
at
the
time
of
which
I
write
,
in
connection
with
the
neighbouring
sea
.
  
<EOS>
Since
the
termination
of
the
American
war
,
there
had
been
nothing
to
call
for
any
unusual
energy
in
manning
the
navy
;
and
the
grants
required
by
Government
for
this
purpose
diminished
with
every
year
of
peace
.
<EOS>
In
1792
this
grant
touched
its
minimum
for
many
years
.
<EOS>
In
1793
the
proceedings
of
the
French
had
set
Europe
on
fire
,
and
the
English
were
raging
with
anti
-
Gallican
excitement
,
fomented
into
action
by
every
expedient
of
the
Crown
and
its
Ministers
.
<EOS>
We
had
our
ships
;
but
where
were
our
men
?
<EOS>
The
Admiralty
had
,
however
,
a
ready
remedy
at
hand
,
with
ample
precedent
for
its
use
,
and
with
common
(
if
not
statute
)
law
to
sanction
its
application
.
<EOS>
They
issued
"
press
warrants
,
"
calling
upon
the
civil
power
throughout
the
country
to
support
their
officers
in
the
discharge
of
their
duty
.
<EOS>
The
sea
-
coast
was
divided
into
districts
,
under
the
charge
of
a
captain
in
the
navy
,
who
again
delegated
sub
-
districts
to
lieutenants
;
and
in
this
manner
all
homeward
-
bound
vessels
were
watched
and
waited
for
,
all
ports
were
under
supervision
;
and
in
a
day
,
if
need
were
,
a
large
number
of
men
could
be
added
to
the
forces
of
his
Majesty
's
navy
.
<EOS>
But
if
the
Admiralty
became
urgent
in
their
demands
,
they
were
also
willing
to
be
unscrupulous
.
<EOS>
Landsmen
,
if
able
-
bodied
,
might
soon
be
trained
into
good
sailors
;
and
once
in
the
hold
of
the
tender
,
which
always
awaited
the
success
of
the
operations
of
the
press
-
gang
,
it
was
difficult
for
such
prisoners
to
bring
evidence
of
the
nature
of
their
former
occupations
,
especially
when
none
had
leisure
to
listen
to
such
evidence
,
or
were
willing
to
believe
it
if
they
did
listen
,
or
would
act
upon
it
for
the
release
of
the
captive
<EOS>
if
they
had
by
possibility
both
listened
and
believed
.
<EOS>
Men
were
kidnapped
,
literally
disappeared
,
and
nothing
was
ever
heard
of
them
again
.
<EOS>
The
street
of
a
busy
town
was
not
safe
from
such
press
-
gang
captures
,
as
Lord
Thurlow
could
have
told
,
after
a
certain
walk
he
took
about
this
time
on
Tower
Hill
,
when
he
,
the
attorney
-
general
of
England
,
was
impressed
,
when
the
Admiralty
had
its
own
peculiar
ways
of
getting
rid
of
tiresome
besiegers
and
petitioners
.
<EOS>
Nor
yet
were
lonely
inland
dwellers
more
secure
;
many
a
rustic
went
to
a
statute
fair
or
"
mop
,
"
and
never
came
home
to
tell
of
his
hiring
;
many
a
stout
young
farmer
vanished
from
his
place
by
the
hearth
of
his
father
,
and
was
no
more
heard
of
by
mother
or
lover
;
so
great
was
the
press
for
men
to
serve
in
the
navy
during
the
early
years
of
the
war
with
France
,
and
after
every
great
naval

of
that

.
  
<EOS>
The
servants
of
the
Admiralty
lay
in

for
all
merchantmen
and
traders
;
there
were
many
instances
of
vessels
returning
home
after
long
absence
,
and
laden
with
rich
cargo
,
being
boarded
within
a
day
's
distance
of
land
,
and
so
many
men
pressed

carried

,
that
the

,
with
her

,
became

from

,

the
wild

,
and
was
sometimes

;
sometimes

were

.
<EOS>
The
men
thus

were
taken

the
near

of
parents
or
wives
,
and
were
often

of
years
,
which

the

of
the
merchantman

which
they
had
served
,
subject
to
all
the
chances
of
honesty

,

.
<EOS>
Now
all
this

(
for
I
can

)
is

to

;
we
can
not

is

for
so

,
even

any

,
any

of

,
any

of
loyal

to
the

.
<EOS>
When

read

in

the
press
-

,

the

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Whether

was
that
living
in
closer

to
the
metropolis
 
<EOS>
the

inspired

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Numbers

;

.
<EOS>
A

"

.
<EOS>
Their

.
<EOS>
Why
!
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
So

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
Where

<EOS>

<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
There

just
another

some

many

.
<EOS>
The

,

?
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,

,

.
<EOS>
They

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
So

<EOS>
Touching

,

<EOS>
The

,

,

"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Still

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Whatever

.
<EOS>
They

back

,
therefore

.
<EOS>
They
were
serving

.
<EOS>
They
were
using

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
There

;

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

,
and
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Fourteen

_
Aurora
_
,
good
man
-

-
war
;

,

.
<EOS>
One
,

_

_
,

,

<EOS>
At

.
    
<EOS>
HOME
FROM
GREENLAND
  
<EOS>
One
hot
day
,
early
in
October
of
the
year
1796
,
two
girls
set
off
from
their
country
homes
to
Monkshaven
to
sell
their
butter
and
eggs
,
for
they
were
both
farmers
'
daughters
,
though
rather
in
different
circumstances
;
for
Molly
Corney
was
one
of
a
large
family
of
children
,
and
had
to
rough
it
accordingly
;
Sylvia
Robson
was
an
only
child
,
and
was
much
made
of
in
more
people
's
estimation
than
Mary
's
by
her
elderly
parents
.
<EOS>
They
had
each
purchases
to
make
after
their
sales
were
effected
,
as
sales
of
butter
and
eggs
were
effected
in
those
days
by
the
market
-
women
sitting
on
the
steps
of
the
great
old
mutilated
cross
till
a
certain
hour
in
the
afternoon
,
after
which
,
if
all
their
goods
were
not
disposed
of
,
they
took
them
unwillingly
to
the
shops
and
sold
them
at
a
lower
price
.
<EOS>
But
good
housewives
did
not
despise
coming
themselves
to
the
Butter
Cross
,
and
,
smelling
and
depreciating
the
articles
they
wanted
,
kept
up
a
perpetual
struggle
of
words
,
trying
,
often
in
vain
,
to
beat
down
prices
.
<EOS>
A
housekeeper
of
the
last
century
would
have
thought
that
she
did
not
know
her
business
,
if
she
had
not
gone
through
this

;
and
the
farmers
'
wives
and
daughters
treated
it
all
as
a
matter

course
,
replying
with
a
good
deal
of
independent

to
the
customer
,
who
,
once
having
discovered
where
good
butter
and
fresh
eggs
were
to
be
sold
,
came
time
after
time
to
depreciate
the
articles
she
always
ended
in
taking
.
<EOS>
There
was
leisure
for
all
this
kind
of
work
in
those
days
.
  
<EOS>
Molly
had
tied
a
knot
on
her
pink
-
spotted
handkerchief
for
each
of
the
various
purchases
she
had
to
make
;
dull
but
important
articles
needed
for
the
week
's
consumption
at
home
;
if
she
forgot
any
one
of

she
knew
she
was
sure
of
a
good
"
rating
"
from
her
mother
.
<EOS>
The
number
of
them
made
her
pocket
-

look
like
one
of

nine
-
tails
of
a
"
cat
;
"
but
not
a

for

,

,

,

any

her
numerous

.
<EOS>
There
was
neither
much
thought
nor
much
money
to
spend
for
any
but
collective
wants
in
the
Corney

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
different

Sylvia
.
<EOS>
She
was
going

first

,
not

of

's
,
that

,

(
and

<EOS>

)
,

,

,

,

of

's

.
<EOS>
Every
now
<EOS>
and

off

the
one

,
but

,

,

fresh

of
the
respective
merits
of
gray
and

.
<EOS>
These

were

<EOS>
There

round

<EOS>
Molly

<EOS>
"

the

,

noane

o

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sylvia

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
Above
,

,

;

,

<EOS>
The

,
while

.
<EOS>
The

was

and

till
its

over

of

watching

on
the
staithes
,
as

.
<EOS>
The
quay
-

was
unsavourily

-

,
for

of

were

in

open
air
,
and
no

existed
for
sweeping
away

of

of
this
operation
.
  
<EOS>
The
fresh
salt

was
bringing
up

,

from
the
blue

beyond

.
<EOS>
Behind

returning

there

white
-

ship
,
as
if
she
were
all

.
  
<EOS>
How

,

those
on

,
may

,

as

,
dreary
Arctic

from

.
<EOS>
No

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
On

among

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Molly

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
If

,

,

<EOS>

"

"

,

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Just

,

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

,
    
"
<EOS>
Well
!
<EOS>
I
dunno
.
<EOS>
It

ill

<EOS>
o

afore

.
<EOS>
And

Charley
Kinraid

hissen
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Charley
Kinraid
!
<EOS>
who

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yon

cousin
o
'

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

yo
'

yo
'
?
"
<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

'

'
,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

good
a
bargain
as
iver
I
can
on
'em
;
and
thou
can
be
off
to
choose
this
grand
new
cloak
as
is
to
be
,
afore
it
gets
any
darker
.
<EOS>
Where
is
ta
going
to
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
said
I
'd
better
go
to
Foster
's
,
"
answered
Sylvia
,
with
a
shade
of
annoyance
in
her
face
.
"
<EOS>
Feyther
said
just
anywhere
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Foster
's
is
t
'
best
place
;
thou
canst
try
anywhere
afterwards
.
<EOS>
I
'll
be
at
Foster
's
in
five
minutes
,
for
I
reckon
we
mun
hasten
a
bit
now
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
near
five
o'clock
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
hung
her
head
and
looked
very
demure
as
she
walked
off
by
herself
to
Foster
's
shop
in
the
market
-
place
.
    
<EOS>
BUYING
A
NEW
CLOAK
  
<EOS>
Foster
's
shop
was
the
shop
of
Monkshaven
.
<EOS>
It
was
kept
by
two
Quaker
brothers
,
who
were
now
old
men
;
and
their
father
had
kept
it
before
them
;
probably
his
father
before
that
.
<EOS>
People
remembered
it
as
an
old
-
fashioned
dwelling
-
house
,
with
a
sort
of
supplementary
shop
with
unglazed
windows
projecting
from
the
lower
story
.
<EOS>
These
openings
had
long
been
filled
with
panes
of
glass
that
at
the
present
day
would
be
accounted
very
small
,
but
which
seventy
years
ago
were
much
admired
for
their
size
.
<EOS>
I
can
best
make
you
understand
the
appearance
of
the
place
by
bidding
you
think
of
the
long
openings
in
a
butcher
's
shop
,
and
then
to
fill
them
up
in
your
imagination
with
panes
about
eight
inches
by
six
,
in
a
heavy
wooden
frame
.
<EOS>
There
was
one
of
these
windows
on
each
side
the
door
-
place
,
which
was
kept
partially
closed
through
the
day
by
a
low
gate
about
a
yard
high
.
<EOS>
Half
the
shop
was
appropriated
to
grocery
;
the
other
half
to
drapery
,
and
a
little
mercery
.
<EOS>
The
good
old
brothers
gave
all
their
known
customers
a
kindly
welcome
;
shaking
hands
with
many
of
them
,
and
asking
all
after
their
families
and
domestic
circumstances
before
proceeding
to
business
.
<EOS>
They
would
not
for
the
world
have
had
any
sign
of
festivity
at
Christmas
,
and
scrupulously
kept
their
shop
open
at
that
holy
festival
,
ready
themselves
to
serve
sooner
than
tax
the
consciences
of
any
of
their
assistants
,
only
nobody
ever
came
.
<EOS>
But
on
New
Year
's
Day
they
had
a
great
cake
,
and
wine
,
ready
in
the
parlour
behind
the
shop
,
of
which
all
who
came
in
to
buy
anything
were
asked
to
partake
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
though
scrupulous
in
most
things
,
it
did
not
go
against
the
consciences
of
these
good
brothers
to
purchase
smuggled
articles
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
back
way
from
the
river
-
side
,
up
a
covered
entry
,
to
the
yard
-
door
of
the
Fosters
,
and
a
peculiar
kind
of
knock
at
this
door
always
brought
out
either
John
or
Jeremiah
,
or
if
not
them
,
their
shopman
,
Philip
Hepburn
;
and
the
same
cake
and
wine
that
the
excise
officer
's
wife
might
just
have
been
tasting
,
was
brought
out
in
the
back
parlour
to
treat
the
smuggler
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
locking
of
doors
,
and
drawing
of
the
green
silk
curtain
that
was
supposed
to
shut
out
the
shop
,
but
really
all
this
was
done
very
much
for
form
's
sake
.
<EOS>
Everybody
in
Monkshaven
smuggled
who
could
,
and
every
one
wore
smuggled
goods
who
could
,
and
great
reliance
was
placed
on
the
excise
officer
's
neighbourly
feelings
.
  
<EOS>
The
story
went
that
John
and
Jeremiah
Foster
were
so
rich
that
they
could
buy
up
all
the
new
town
across
the
bridge
.
<EOS>
They
had
certainly
begun
to
have
a
kind
of
primitive
bank
in
connection
with
their
shop
,
receiving
and
taking
care
of
such
money
as
people
did
not
wish
to
retain
in
their
houses
for
fear
of
burglars
.
<EOS>
No
one
asked
them
for
interest
on
the
money
thus
deposited
,
nor
did
they
give
any
;
but
,
on
the
other
hand
,
if
any
of
their
customers
,
on
whose
character
they
could
depend
,
wanted
a
little
advance
,
the
Fosters
,
after
due
inquiries
made
,
and
in
some
cases
due
security
given
,
were
not
unwilling
to
lend
a
moderate
sum
without
charging
a
penny
for
the
use
of
their
money
.
<EOS>
All
the
articles
they
sold
were
as
good
as
they
knew
how
to
choose
,
and
for
them
they
expected
and
obtained
ready
money
.
<EOS>
It
was
said
that
they
only
kept
on
the
shop
for
their
amusement
.
<EOS>
Others
averred
that
there
was
some
plan
of
a
marriage
running
in
the
brothers
'
heads
 
a
marriage
between
William
Coulson
,
Mr.
Jeremiah
's
wife
's
nephew
(
Mr.
Jeremiah
was
a
widower
)
,
and
Hester
Rose
,
whose
mother
was
some
kind
of
distant
relation
,
and
who
served
in
the
shop
along
with
William
Coulson
and
Philip
Hepburn
.
<EOS>
Again
,
this
was
denied
by
those
who
averred
that
Coulson
was
no
blood
relation
,
and
that
if
the
Fosters
had
intended
to
do
anything
considerable
for
Hester
,
they
would
never
have
allowed
her
and
her
mother
to
live
in
such
a
sparing
way
,
ekeing
out
their
small
income
by
having
Coulson
and
Hepburn
for
lodgers
.
<EOS>
No
;
John
and
Jeremiah
would
leave
all
their
money
to
some
hospital
or
to
some
charitable
institution
.
<EOS>
But
,
of
course
,
there
was
a
reply
to
this
;
when
are
there
not
many
sides
to
an
argument
about
a
possibility
concerning
which
no
facts
are
known
?
<EOS>
Part
of
the
reply
turned
on
this
:
the
old
gentlemen
had
,
probably
,
some
deep
plan
in
their
heads
in
permitting
their
cousin
to
take
Coulson
and
Hepburn
as
lodgers
,
the
one
a
kind
of
nephew
,
the
other
,
though
so
young
,
the
head
man
in
the
shop
;
if
either
of
them
took
a
fancy
to
Hester
,
how
agreeably
matters
could
be
arranged
!
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
Hester
is
patiently
waiting
to
serve
Sylvia
,
who
is
standing
before
her
<EOS>
a
little
shy
,
a
little
perplexed
and
distracted
,
by
the
sight
of
so
many
pretty
things
.
  
<EOS>
Hester
was
a
tall
young
woman
,
sparely
yet
largely
formed
,
of
a
grave
aspect
,
which
made
her
look
older
than
she
really
was
.
<EOS>
Her
thick
brown
hair
was
smoothly
taken
off
her
broad
forehead
,
and
put
in
a
very
orderly
fashion
,
under
her
linen
cap
;
her
face
was
a
little
square
,
and
her
complexion
sallow
,
though
the
texture
of
her
skin
was
fine
.
<EOS>
Her
gray
eyes
were
very
pleasant
,
because
they
looked
at
you
so
honestly
and
kindly
;
her
mouth
was
slightly
compressed
,
as
most
have
it
who
are
in
the
habit
of
restraining
their
feelings
;
but
when
she
spoke
you
did
not
perceive
this
,
and
her
rare
smile
slowly
breaking
forth
showed
her
white
even
teeth
,
and
when
accompanied
,
as
it
generally
was
,
by
a
sudden
uplifting
of
her
soft
eyes
,
it
made
her
countenance
very
winning
.
<EOS>
She
was
dressed
in
stuff
of
sober
colours
,
both
in
accordance
with
her
own
taste
,
and
in
unasked
compliance
with
the
religious
customs
of
the
Fosters
;
but
Hester
herself
was
not
a
Friend
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
,
standing
opposite
,
not
looking
at
Hester
,
but
gazing
at
the
ribbons
in
the
shop
window
,
as
if
hardly
conscious
that
any
one
awaited
the
expression
of
her
wishes
,
was
a
great
contrast
;
ready
to
smile
or
to

,
or
to
show
her

in
any
way
,
with
a
character
as
undeveloped
as
a
child
's
,
affectionate
,
wilful
,
naughty
,
tiresome
,
charming
,
anything
,
in
fact
,
at
present
that
the
chances
of
an
hour
called
out
.
<EOS>
Hester
thought
her
customer
the
prettiest
creature
ever
seen
,
in
the
moment
she
had
for
admiration
before
Sylvia
turned
round
and
,
recalled

,

,
    
"
Oh
,
I
beg
your

,
miss
;
I
was
thinking
what
may
the
price
of
yon
crimson
ribbon
be
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
said
nothing
,
but
went
to

-
mark
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
I
did

I
wanted

,

.
<EOS>
Thank

,

,
but
I
am
very
sorry
 
<EOS>
some
duffle
,
please
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
silently
replaced
the
ribbon
and
went
in
search
of
the
duffle
.
<EOS>
While
she
was
gone
Sylvia
was
addressed
by
the
very
person
she
most
wished
to
avoid
,
and
whose
absence
she
had
rejoiced
over
on
first
entering
the
shop
,
her
cousin
Philip
Hepburn
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
a
serious
-
looking
young
man
,
tall
,
but
with
a
slight
stoop
in
his
shoulders
,
brought
on
by
his
occupation
.
<EOS>
He
had
thick
hair
standing
off
from
his
forehead
in
a
peculiar
but
not
unpleasing
manner
;
a
long
face
,
with
a
slightly
aquiline
nose
,
dark
eyes
,
and
a
long
upper
lip
,
which
gave
a
disagreeable
aspect
to
a
face
that
might
otherwise
have
been
good
-
looking
.
  
<EOS>
"
Good
day
,
Sylvie
,
"
he
said
;
"
what
are
you
wanting
?
<EOS>
How
are
all
at
home
?
<EOS>
Let
me
help
you
!
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
pursed
up
her
red
lips
,
and
did
not

at

as

,
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
very
well
,
and
so
is
mother
;
feyther
's
got
a
touch
of
rheumatiz
,
and
there
's
a
young
woman
getting
what
I
want
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

when

,
as
if
it
had
comprised
all

.
<EOS>
But
he

,
  
"
You
wo
n't
know
how
to
choose
,
"
and
,
seating

on

,
he
swung

after
the
fashion
of
shop
-
men
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
took
no
notice

him
,
but
pretended
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
you
want
,
Sylvie
?
"
<EOS>
asked
he
,
at
last

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like

be
called
"
Sylvie
;
"
my
name
is
Sylvia
;
and
I
'm
wanting
duffle
for
a

,
if
you
must
know
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
now
returned
,
with
a
shop
-
boy
helping
her
to
drag
along
the
great
rolls
of
scarlet
and
gray
cloth
.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
that
,
"
said
Philip
,
kicking

red
duffle
with

,
and
speaking

lad
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
gray
you
want
,

,
Sylvie
?
"
<EOS>
He
used
the
name
he
had
had

cousin
's
right
to

her
by
since
her

,
without
remembering
her
words
on
the
subject

;
but

,
and
was

.
  
<EOS>
"
Please
,
miss
,
it
is
the
scarlet
duffle
I
want
;
do
n't
let
him
take
it
away
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
looked
up
at
both
their
countenances
,
a
little
wondering
what
was
their
position
with
regard

each
other
;
for
this
,
then
,
was
the
beautiful
little
cousin
about
whom
Philip
had
talked
to
her
mother
,
as
sadly
spoilt
,
and

;
a
lovely
little
dunce
,
and
so
forth
.
<EOS>
Hester
had
pictured
Sylvia
Robson
,
somehow
,
as
very
different
from
what
she
was
:
<EOS>
younger
,
more
stupid
,
not
half
so
bright
and
charming
(
for
,
though
she
was
now
both
pouting
and
cross
,
it
was
evident
that
this
was
not
her
accustomed
mood
)
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
devoted
her
attention
to
the
red
cloth
,
pushing
aside
the
gray
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
Hepburn
was
vexed
at
his
advice
being
slighted
;
and
yet
he
urged
it
afresh
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
is
a
respectable
,
quiet
-
looking
article
that
will
go
well
with
any
colour
;
you
niver
will
be
so
foolish
as
to
take
what
will
mark
with
every
drop
of
rain
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
sorry
you
sell
such
good
-
for
-
nothing
things
,
"
replied
Sylvia
,
conscious
of
her
advantage
,
and
relaxing
a
little
(
as
little
as
she
possibly
could
)
of
her
gravity
.
  
<EOS>
Hester
came
in
now
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
means
to
say
that
this
cloth
will
lose
its
first
brightness
in
wet
or

;
but
it
will
always
be
a
good
article
,
and
the
colour
will
stand
a
deal
of

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Foster
would
not
have
had
it
in
his
shop
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
Philip
did
not

that
even
a
reasonable
peace
-
making
interpreter
should
come
between
him
and
Sylvia
,
so
he
held
his

in

.
  
<EOS>
Hester
went
on
:
  
"
To
be
sure
,
this
gray
is
the
closer
make
,
and
would
wear
the
longest
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
care
,
"
said
Sylvia
,
still
rejecting
the
dull
gray
.
<EOS>
"
I
like
this
best
.
<EOS>
Eight
yards
,
if
you
please
,
miss
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
cloak
takes
nine
yards
,
at
least
,
"
said
Philip
,
decisively
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
told
me
eight
,
"
said
Sylvia
,
secretly
conscious
that
her
mother
would
have
preferred
the
more
sober
colour
;
and
feeling
that
as
she
had
had
her
own
way
in
that
respect
,
she
was
bound
to
keep
to
the
directions
she
had
received
as
to
the
quantity
.
<EOS>

for
it
would
grieve
me
if
they
were
misled
into
violence
.
"
  
<EOS>
Philip
hesitated
.
  
<EOS>
"
Speak
out
,
man
!
<EOS>
Always
ease
an
uneasy

,
and
never
let

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
had

,
for
the
town
<EOS>
is

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
The

"
The

!
<EOS>
the
old
Adam
!
"
<EOS>

?
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

Philip

"

.

<EOS>

John

,

.
<EOS>
With

he
told

two

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia

,

less

she
ought

the

of

.
<EOS>
Molly
took

,
leaving

good

of
both
,
according

the
code
of
manners
in

;
and

because

was
continually

.
<EOS>
For

's

,

.
<EOS>
But

's

.
<EOS>
Sylvia

,

<EOS>
What
business
had

pretty

-

,

.
<EOS>
And
,

!
<EOS>

rough

?
<EOS>
What
did

?
    
<EOS>
PHILIP
HEPBURN
  
<EOS>
The
coast
on
that
part
of
the
island
to
which
this
story
refers
is
bordered
by
rocks
and
cliffs
.
<EOS>
The
inland
country
immediately
adjacent
to
the
coast
is
level
,
flat
,
and
bleak
;
it
is
only
where
the
long
stretch
of
dyke
-
enclosed
fields
terminates
abruptly
in
a
sheer
descent
,
and
the
stranger
sees
the
ocean
creeping
up
the
sands
far
below
him
,
that
he
is
aware
on
how
great
an
elevation
he
has
been
.
<EOS>
Here
and
there
,
as
I
have
said
,
a
cleft
in
the
level
land
(
thus
running
out
into
the
sea
in
steep
promontories
)
occurs
 
what
they
would
call
a
"
chine
"
in
the
Isle
of
Wight
;
but
instead
of
the
soft
south
wind
stealing
up
the
woody
ravine
,
as
it
does
there
,
the
eastern
breeze
comes
piping
shrill
and
clear
along
these
northern
chasms
,
keeping
the
trees
that
venture
to
grow
on
the
sides
down
to
the
mere
height
of
scrubby
brushwood
.
<EOS>
The
descent
to
the
shore
through
these
"
bottoms
"
is
in
most
cases
very
abrupt
,
too
much
so
for
a
cartway
,
or
even
a
bridle
-
path
;
but
people
can
pass
up
and
down
without
difficulty
,
by
the
help
of
a
few
rude
steps
hewn
here
and
there
out
of
the
rock
.
  
<EOS>
Sixty
or
seventy
years
ago
(
not
to
speak
of
much
later
times
)
<EOS>
the
farmers
who
owned
or
hired
the
land
which
lay
directly
on
the
summit
of
these
cliffs
were
smugglers
to
the
extent
of
their
power
,
only
partially
checked
by
the
coast
-
guard
distributed
,
at
pretty
nearly
equal
interspaces
of
eight
miles
,
all
along
the
north
-
eastern
seaboard
.
<EOS>
Still
sea
-
wrack
was
a
good
manure
,
and
there
was
no
law
against
carrying
it
up
in
great
osier
baskets
for
the
purpose
of
tillage
,
and
many
a
secret
thing
was
lodged
in
hidden
crevices
in
the
rocks
till
the
farmer
sent
trusty
people
down
to
the
shore
for
a
good
supply
of
sand
and
seaweed
for
his
land
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
the
farms
on
the
cliff
had
lately
been
taken
by
Sylvia
's
father
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
man
who
had
roamed
about
a
good
deal
 
<EOS>
been
sailor
,
smuggler
,
horse
-
dealer
,
and
farmer
in
turns
;
a
sort
of
fellow
possessed
by
a
spirit
of
adventure
and
love
of
change
,
which
did
him
and
his
own
family
more
harm
than
anybody
else
.
<EOS>
He
was
just
the
kind
of
man
that
all
his
neighbours
found
fault
with
,
and
all
his
neighbours
liked
.
<EOS>
Late
in
life
(
for
such
an
imprudent
man
as
he
,
was
one
of
a
class
who
generally
we
d
,
trusting
to
chance
and
luck
for
the
provision
for
a
family
)
,
farmer
Robson
married
a
woman
whose
only
want
of
practical
wisdom
consisted
in
taking
him
for
a

.
<EOS>
She
was
Philip
Hepburn
's
aunt
,
and
had
had
the
charge
of
him
until
she
married
from
her
widowed
brother
's
house
.
<EOS>
He
<EOS>
it
was
who
had
let
her
know
when
Haytersbank
Farm
had
been
to
let
;
esteeming
it
a
likely
piece
of
land
for
his
uncle
to
settle
down
upon
,
after
a
somewhat
unprosperous
career
of
horse
-
dealing
.
<EOS>
The
farmhouse
lay
in
the
shelter
of
a
very
slight
green
hollow
scarcely
scooped
out
of
the
pasture
field
by
which
it
was
surrounded
;
the
short
crisp
turf
came
creeping
up
to
the
very
door
and
windows
,
without
any
attempt
at
a
yard
or
garden
,
or
any
nearer
enclosure
of
the
buildings
than
the
stone
dyke
that
formed
the
boundary
of
the
field
itself
.
<EOS>
The
buildings
were
long
and
low
,
in
order
to
avoid
the
rough
violence
of
the
winds
that
swept
over
that
wild
,
bleak
spot
,
both
in
winter
and
summer
.
<EOS>
It
was
well
for
the
inhabitants
of
that
house
that
coal
was
extremely
cheap
;
otherwise
a
southerner
might
have
imagined
that
they
could
never
have
survived
the
cutting
of
the
bitter
gales
that
piped
all
round
,
and
seemed
to
seek
out
every
crevice
for
admission
into
the
house
.
  
<EOS>
But
the
interior
was
warm
enough
when
once
you
had
mounted
the
long
bleak
lane
,
full
of
round
rough
stones
,
enough
to
lame
any
horse
unaccustomed
to
such
roads
,
and
had
crossed
the
field
by
the
little
dry
,
hard
footpath
,
which
tacked
about
so
as
to
keep
from
directly
facing
the
prevailing
wind
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Robson
was
a
Cumberland
woman
,
and
as
such
,
was
a
cleaner
housewife
than
the
farmers
'
wives
of
that
north
-
eastern
coast
,
and
was
often
shocked
at
their
ways
,
showing
it
more
by
her
looks
than
by
her
words
,
for
she
was
not
a
great
talker
.
<EOS>
This
fastidiousness
in
such
matters
made
her
own
house
extremely
comfortable
,
but
did
not
tend
to
render
her
popular
among
her
neighbours
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
Bell
Robson
piqued
herself
on
her
housekeeping
generally
,
and
once
in
-
doors
in
the
gray
,
bare
stone
house
,
there
were
plenty
of
comforts
to
be
had
besides
cleanliness
and

.
<EOS>
The
great
rack
of
clap
-
bread
hung
overhead
,
and
Bell
Robson
's
preference
of
this
kind

-

over
the
leavened

kind
used
in
Yorkshire
was

.
<EOS>
Flitches
of
bacon
and
"
hands
"
(
_
<EOS>
i.e.
_
,
shoulders
of
cured

,
the
legs

being
sold
,
as
fetching

)

;

any

was

for
"
turf

"

"

,
"
with

honoured

,

he

their
high

,

.
  
<EOS>
This

Robson
was
fidgeting
in
and

,

.

Another

.
  
<EOS>
People
speak
of
the
way

sets

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
STORY
OF
THE
PRESS
-
GANG
  
<EOS>
For
a
few
days
after
the
evening
mentioned
in
the
last
chapter
the
weather
was
dull
.
<EOS>
Not
in
quick
,
sudden
showers
did
the
rain
come
down
,
but
in
constant
drizzle
,
blotting
out
all
colour
from
the
surrounding
landscape
,
and
filling
the
air
with
fine
gray
mist
,
until
people
breathed
more
water
than
air
.
<EOS>
At
such
times
the
consciousness
of
the
nearness
of
the
vast
unseen
sea
acted
as
a
dreary
depression
to
the
spirits
;
but
besides
acting
on
the
nerves
of
the
excitable
,
such
weather
affected
the
sensitive
or
ailing
in
material
ways
.
<EOS>
Daniel
Robson
's
fit
of
rheumatism
incapacitated
him
from
stirring
abroad
;
and
to
a
man
of
his
active
habits
,
and
somewhat
inactive
mind
,
this
was
a
great
hardship
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
ill
-
tempered
naturally
,
but
this
state
of
confinement
made
him
more
ill
-
tempered
than
he
had
ever
been
before
in
his
life
.
<EOS>
He
sat
in
the
chimney
-
corner
,
abusing
the
weather
and
doubting
the
wisdom
or
desirableness
of
all
his
wife
saw
fit
to
do
in
the
usual
daily
household
matters
.
<EOS>
The
"
chimney
-
corner
"
was
really
a
corner
at
Haytersbank
.
<EOS>
There
were
two
projecting
walls
on
each
side
of
the
fire
-
place
,
running
about
six
feet
into
the
room
,
and
a
stout
wooden
settle
was
placed
against
one
of
these
,
while
opposite
was
the
circular
-
backed
"
master
's
chair
,
"
the
seat
of
which
was
composed
of
a
square
piece
of
wood
judiciously
hollowed
out
,
and
placed
with
one
corner
to
the
front
.
<EOS>
Here
,
in
full
view
of
all
the
operations
going
on
over
the
fire
,
sat
Daniel
Robson
for
four
live
-
long
days
,
advising
and
directing
his
wife
in
all
such
minor

as
the
boiling
of
potatoes
,
the
making
of
porridge
,
all
the
work
on
which
she
specially
piqued
herself
,
and
on
which
she
would
have
taken
advice
 
<EOS>
no
!
<EOS>
not
from
the
most
skilled
housewife
in
all
the
three
Ridings
.
<EOS>
But
,
somehow
,
she
managed
to
keep
her

quiet
from
telling

,
as
she
would

done
any

,
and

,
to

,
or

.
<EOS>
She
even
checked

when

,
as

,
that

,
and

consequences

.
  
<EOS>
"
Na
,
na
!
<EOS>
"

,
"
th

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Bell
sighed
,
for

four

she
had
experienced
somewhat
of
Madame

's

(
and

fewer

)
of

man
who
was
not

.
<EOS>
For
Bell
,
good

,

not

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
's
plan
,
undutiful

was
in
her
mother
's

,

Daniel

,

,

,

,

to
her

,
did
not

him
when

.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
scouted
the
notion
of
cousin
Philip
coming
into
their

in
the
character
of
an
amusing

entertaining
person
,
till
she
nearly

her
mother
angry
at
her

of
the
good
steady
young
fellow
,
to
whom
Bell
looked
up
as
the
pattern
of
all
that
early
manhood
should
be
.
<EOS>
But
the
moment
Sylvia
saw
she
had
been
giving
her
mother
pain
,
she
left
off
her
wilful
little
jokes
,
and
kissed
her
,
and
told
her
she
would
manage
all
famously
,
and
ran
out
of
the
back
-
kitchen
,
in
which
mother
and
daughter
had
been
scrubbing
the
churn
and
all
the
wooden
implements
of
butter
-
making
.
<EOS>
Bell
looked
at
the
pretty
figure
of
her
little

"

.

,

,

;

by
every
one
down
to
the
little
child
in
its
mother
's
arms
,
that
innocently
clutched
the
piece
of
rosemary
to
be
thrown
into
the
grave
"
for
remembrance
.
<EOS>
"
Darley
,
the
seaman
shot
by
the
press
-
gang
,
nine
leagues
off
St.
Abb
's
Head
,
was
to
be
buried
to
-
day
,
at
the
accustomed
time
for
the
funerals
of
the
poorer
classes
,
directly
after
evening
service
,
and
there
were
only
the
sick
and
their
nurse
-
tenders
who
did
not
come
forth
to
show
their
feeling
for
the
man
whom
they
looked
upon
as
murdered
.
<EOS>
The
crowd
of
vessels
in
harbour
bore
their
flags
<EOS>
half
-
mast
high
;
and
the
crews
were
making
their
way
through
the
High
Street
.
<EOS>
The
gentlefolk
of
Monkshaven
,
full
of
indignation
at
this
interference
with
their
ships
,
full
of
sympathy
with
the
family
who
had
lost
their
son
and
brother
almost
within
sight
of
his
home
,
came
in
unusual
numbers
 
<EOS>
no
lack
of
patterns
for
Sylvia
;
but
her
thoughts
were
far
otherwise
and
more
suitably
occupied
.
<EOS>
The
unwonted
sternness
and
solemnity
visible
on
the
countenances
of
all
whom
she
met
awed
and
affected
her
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
speak
in
reply
to
Molly
's
remarks
on
the
dress
or
appearance
of
those
who
struck
her
.
<EOS>
She
felt
as
if
these
speeches
jarred
on
her
,
and
annoyed
her
almost
to
irritation
;
yet
Molly
had
come
all
the
way
to
Monkshaven
Church
in
her
service
,
and
deserved
forbearance
accordingly
.
<EOS>
The
two
mounted
the
steps
alongside
of
many
people
;
few
words
were
exchanged
,
even
at
the
breathing
places
,
so
often
the
little
centres
of
gossip
.
<EOS>
Looking
over
the
sea
there
was
not
a
sail
to
be
seen
;
it
seemed
bared
of
life
,
as
if
to
be
in
serious
harmony
with
what
was
going
on
inland
.
  
<EOS>
The
church
was
of
old
Norman
architecture
;
low
and
massive
outside
:
inside
,
of
vast
space
,
only
a
quarter
of
which
was
filled
on
ordinary
Sundays
.
<EOS>
The
walls
were
disfigured
by
numerous
tablets
of
black
and
white
marble
intermixed
,
and
the
usual
ornamentation
of
that
style
of
memorial
as
erected
in
the
last
century
,
of
weeping
willows
,
urns
,
and
drooping
figures
,
with
here
and
there
a
ship
in
full
sail
,
or
an
anchor
,
where
the
seafaring
idea
prevalent
through
the
place
had
launched
out
into
a
little
originality
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
wood
-
work
,
the
church
had
been
stripped
of
that
,
most
probably
when
the
neighbouring
monastery
had
been
destroyed
.
<EOS>
There
were
large
square
pews
,
lined
with
green
baize
,
with
the
names
of
the
families
of
the
most
flourishing
ship
-
owners
painted
white
on
the
doors
;
there
were
pews
,
not
so
large
,
and
not
lined
at
all
,
for
the
farmers
and
shopkeepers
of
the
parish
;
and
numerous
heavy
oaken
benches
which
,
by
the
united

of
several
men
,
might
be
brought
within
earshot
of
the
pulpit
.
<EOS>
These
were
being
removed
into
the
most
convenient
situations
when
Molly
and
Sylvia
entered
the
church
,
and
after
two
or
three
whispered
sentences
they
took
their
seats
on
one
of
these
.
  
<EOS>
The
vicar
of
Monkshaven
was
a
kindly
,
peaceable
old
man
,
hating
strife
and
troubled
waters
above
everything
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
vehement
Tory
in
theory
,
as
became
his
cloth
in
those
days
.
<EOS>
He
had
two
bugbears
to
fear
 
the
French
and
the
Dissenters
.
<EOS>
It
was
difficult
to
say
of
which
he
had
the
worst
opinion
and
the
most
intense
dread
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
hated
the
Dissenters
most
,
because
they
came
nearer
in
contact
with
him
than
the
French
;
besides
,
the
French
had
the
excuse
of
being
Papists
,
while
the
Dissenters
might
have
belonged
to
the
Church
of
England
if
they
had
not
been
utterly
depraved
.
<EOS>
Yet
in
practice
Dr
Wilson
did
not
object
to
dine
with
Mr.
Fishburn
,
who
was
a
personal
friend
and
follower
of
Wesley
,
but
then
,
as
the
doctor
would
say
,
"
Wesley
was
an
Oxford
man
,
and
that
makes
him
a

;
and
he
was
an
ordained
minister
of
the
Church
of
England
,
so
that
grace
can
never

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
do
not
know
what

he
would
have
alleged
for

broth
and

to
old
Ralph
Thompson
,
a

,
who
had
been
given
to
abusing

and
the
vicar
,
from
a

,
as

.
<EOS>
However
,
that
inconsistency
between
Dr
Wilson
's
theories
and
practice
was
not
generally
known
in
Monkshaven
,
so
we
have
nothing
to
do

.
  
<EOS>
Dr
Wilson
had
had
a
very
difficult
part
to
play
,
and
a
still
more
difficult
sermon
to
write
,
during
this
last

.
<EOS>
The
Darley
who
had
been
killed
was
the
son
of
the
vicar
's
gardener
,
and
Dr
Wilson
's
sympathies
as
a
man
had
been
all
on
the
bereaved
father
's
side
.
<EOS>
But
then
he
had
received
,
as
the
oldest

in
the

,
a
letter
from
the
captain
of
the
_
Aurora
_
,

.
<EOS>
Darley
had
been
resisting
the
orders
of
an
officer
in
his
Majesty
's
service
.
<EOS>
What
would
become
of
due

and

,
and
the

of
the
service
,
and
the
chances
of
beating
those
confounded
French
,
if
such

as
Darley
's
was

?
<EOS>
(
Poor
Darley
!
<EOS>
he
was
past
all
evil
effects
of
human
encouragement
now
!
)
  
<EOS>
So
the
vicar
mumbled
hastily
over
a
sermon
on
the
text
,
"
<EOS>
In
the
midst
of
life
we
are
in
death
"
;
which
might
have
done
as
well
for
a
baby
cut
off
in

convulsion
-
fit
as
for
the
strong
man
shot
down
with
all
his
eager
blood
hot
within
him
,
by
men
as
hot
-
blooded
as
himself
.
<EOS>
But
once
when
the
old
doctor
's

caught
the
up
-

,
straining

of
the
father
Darley
,
seeking

to

of

in
the

,
his

.
<EOS>
Had

nothing
to
say
that
should
calm
anger
and
revenge
with
spiritual

?
<EOS>
no
breath
of
the
comforter
to
soothe
repining
into

?
<EOS>
But
again
the
discord
between
the
laws
of
man
and
the
laws
of
Christ
stood
before
him
;
and
he
gave
up
the
attempt
to
do
more
than
he
was
doing
,
as
beyond
his
power
.
<EOS>
Though
the
hearers
went
away
as
full
of
anger
as
they
had
entered
the
church
,
and
some
with
a
dull

of

as
to
what
they
had
got

,
yet
no

felt
anything
but

towards

.
<EOS>
His
simple
,
happy
life
led
amongst
them
for
forty
years
,
and
open
to
all
men
in
its
daily

;
his
sweet
-

,
cordial
ways
;
his
practical

,
made
him
beloved
by
all
;
and
neither
he
nor
<EOS>
they
thought
much
or
cared
much
for
admiration
of
his
talents
.
<EOS>
Respect
for
his
office
was
all
the
respect
he
thought
of
;
and
that
was
conceded
to
him
from
old
traditional
and
hereditary
association
.
<EOS>
In
looking
back
to
the
last
century
,
it
appears
curious
to
see
how
little
our
ancestors
had
the
power
of
putting
two
things
together
,
and
perceiving
either
the
discord
or
harmony
thus
produced
.
<EOS>
Is
it
because
we
are
farther
off
from
those
times
,
and
have
,
consequently
,
a
greater
range
of
vision
?
<EOS>
Will
our
descendants
have
a
wonder
about
us
,
such
as
we
have
about
the
inconsistency
of
our
forefathers
,
or
a
surprise
at
our
blindness
that
we
do
not
perceive
that
,
holding
such
and
such

,
our
course
of
action
must
be
so
and
so
,
or
that
the
logical
consequence
of
particular
opinions
must
be
convictions
which
at
present
we
hold
in

?
<EOS>
It
seems
puzzling
to
look
back
on
men
such
as
our
vicar
,
who
almost
held
the
doctrine
that
the
King
could
do
no
wrong
,
yet
were
ever
ready
to
talk
of
the
glorious

,
and
to
abuse
the
Stuarts
for
having
entertained
the
same
doctrine
,
and
tried
to
put
it
in
practice
.
<EOS>
But
such
discrepancies
ran
through
good
men
's
lives
in
those
days
.
<EOS>
It
is
well
for
us
that
we
live
at
the
present
time
,
when
everybody
is
logical
and
consistent
.
<EOS>
This
little
discussion
must
be
taken
in
place
of
Dr
Wilson
's
sermon
,
of
which
no
one
could
remember
more
than

text

.
<EOS>
Even
the
doctor
himself
had
the
recollection
of
the
words
he
had
uttered
swept
out
of
his
mind
,
<EOS>
as
,
having
doffed
his
gown
and

,
he
came
out
of
the
dusk
of
his
vestry
and
went
to
the
church
-
door
,
looking
into
the
broad
light
which
came
upon
the
plain
of
the
church
-
yard
on
the
cliffs
;
for
the
sun
had
not
yet
set
,
and
the
pale

was
slowly
rising
through
the
silvery
mist
that
obscured
the
distant

.
<EOS>
There
was
a
thick
,
dense

,
all
still
and

,
looking
away
from
the
church
and
the
vicar
,
who
awaited
the
bringing
of
the
dead
.
<EOS>
They
were
watching
the
slow
black
line
winding
up
the
long
steps
,
resting
their
heavy
burden
here
<EOS>
and
there
,
standing
in
silent
groups
at
each

-
place
;
now
lost

as
a
piece
of
broken
,

ground
intervened
,
now
emerging
suddenly
nearer
;
and
overhead
the
great
church
bell
,
with
its

,
familiar

vicar
,
if
to

else

,
<EOS>
I
to
the
grave
do
summon
all
,
kept
on
its
heavy

,
with
which
no
other
sound
from
land
or
sea
,
near
or
distant
,
intermingled
,
except

far
-

on
the
moors
,
as

were
coming
home
to
roost
;
and
that
one
noise
from
so
great

distance
seemed
only
to
deepen

.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
a
little
movement
in
the
crowd
;
a
little

from
side
to
side
,
to
make
a
path
for
the
corpse
and
its
bearers
 
an
aggregate
of
the
fragments
of
room
.
  
<EOS>
With
bent
heads
and
spent
strength
,
those
who
carried
the
coffin

on
;
behind
came
the
poor
old

,
a
brown
-
black

thrown
over
his
homely

,
and
supporting
his
wife
with
steps
scarcely
less

than
her

.
<EOS>
He
had
come
to
church
that

,
with
a

to

that
he
would
return
to
lead

to
the

firstborn
;
for

,

,
full
of

and

,
as

must
go
and
hear
something
which
should
exorcize
the
unwonted
longing
for
revenge
that
disturbed
his
grief
,
and
made
him
conscious
of
that
great
blank
of
consolation
which
faithfulness
produces
.
<EOS>
And
for
the
time
he
was
faithless
.
<EOS>
How
came
God
to
permit
such
cruel
injustice
of
man
?
<EOS>
Permitting
it
,
He
could
not
be
good
.
<EOS>
Then
what
was
life
,
and
what
was
death
,
but
woe
and
despair
?
<EOS>
The
beautiful
solemn
words
of
the
ritual
had
done
him
good
,
and
restored
much
of
his
faith
.
<EOS>
Though
he
could
not
understand
why
such
sorrow
had
befallen
him
any
more
than
before
,
he
had
come
back
to
something
of
his
childlike
trust
;
he
kept

to

in

,
as

weary

,
"
It
is
the
Lord
's
doing
"
;
and
the
repetition
soothed
him
unspeakably
.
<EOS>
Behind
this
old
couple
followed
their
children
,
grown
men
and
women
,
come
from
distant
place
or
farmhouse
service
;
the
servants
at
the
vicarage
,
and
many
a

,
anxious
to
show

,
and
most

from

of
the

in

,
joined
in
procession
,
and
followed
the
dead
body
into
the
church
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
too
great
a
crowd
immediately
within
the
door
for
Sylvia
and
Molly
to
go
in
again
,
and
they
accordingly
betook
themselves
to
the
place
where
the
deep
grave
was
waiting
,
wide
and
hungry
,
to
receive
its
dead
.
<EOS>
There
,
leaning
against
the
headstones
all
around
,
were
many
standing
 
looking
over
the
broad
and
placid
sea
,
and
turned
to
the
soft

air
which
blew
on
their
hot

and
rigid

;
for
no

spoke
of

that
number
.
<EOS>
They
were
thinking
of
the
violent
death
of
him
over
whom
the
solemn
words
were
now
being
said
in
the
gray
old
church
,
scarcely
out
of
their
hearing
,
had
not

sound
been
broken
by
the
measured

of
the

far

.
  
<EOS>
Suddenly
every
one
looked
round
towards
the
path
from
the
churchyard
steps
.
<EOS>
Two
sailors
were
supporting
a
ghastly
figure
that
,
with
feeble

,
was
drawing
near
the
open

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
t
'
specksioneer
as
tried
to
save
him
!
<EOS>
It
's
him
as
was
left
for
dead
!
"
<EOS>
the
people
murmured
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
Charley
Kinraid
,
as
I
'm
a
sinner
!
"
<EOS>
said
Molly
,
starting
forward
to
greet
her
cousin
.
  
<EOS>
But
as
he
came
on
,
she
saw
that
all
his
strength
was
needed
for
the
mere
action
of
walking
.
<EOS>
The
sailors
,
in
their
strong
sympathy
,
had
yielded
to
his
earnest
entreaty
,
and
carried
him
up
the
steps
,
in
order
that
he
might
see
the
last
of
his
messmate
.
<EOS>
They
placed
him
near
the
grave
,
resting
against
a
stone
;
and
he
was
hardly
there
before
the
vicar
came
forth
,
and
the
great
crowd
poured
out
of
the
church
,
following
the
body
to
the
grave
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
was
so
much
wrapt
up
in
the
solemnity
of
the
occasion
,
that
she
had
no
thought
to
spare
at
the
first

for
the
pale

haggard
figure
opposite
;
much
less
was
she
aware
of
her
cousin
Philip
,
who
now
singling

out
for
the
first
time
from
among
the

,
pressed
to
her
side
,
with
an
intention
of

and
protection
.
  
<EOS>
As

went
on
,
ill

rose

two

,
who
were

the

in
the
crowd
,
and
by
-
and
-
by
the

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
's

rained
down
her
face
,
and
her

so

it
attracted

attention
of
many

that
inner

.
<EOS>
Among

noticed

,

the

innocent

,

a
sweetheart
of

.
  
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
and
<EOS>
oh

.
  
<EOS>
In
the
agricultural
counties
,
and
among
the
class
to
which
these
four
persons
belonged
,
there
is
little
analysis
of

comparison
of

and

,
even

this
present
day
of

.
<EOS>
Sixty

ago
there
was

less
.
<EOS>
I
do

,

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

,

,

,

that

.
  
<EOS>
To

we

of

.

!
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
In

,
and

lost

,

.
  
<EOS>
Hester

,

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>

,

"
How

!

"
<EOS>
Yes

;

good

.

<EOS>

.

"

,
"

.
    
<EOS>
ATTRACTION
AND
REPULSION
  
<EOS>
A
fortnight
had
passed
over
and
winter
was
advancing
with
rapid
strides
.
<EOS>
In
bleak
northern
farmsteads
there
was
much
to
be
done
before
November
weather
should
make
the
roads
too
heavy
for
half
-
fed
horses
to
pull
carts
through
.
<EOS>
There
was
the
turf
,
pared
up
on
the
distant
moors
,
and
left
out
to
dry
,
to
be
carried
home
and
stacked
;
the
brown
fern
was
to
be
stored
up
for
winter
bedding
for
the
cattle
;
for
straw
was
scarce
and
dear
in
those
parts
;
even
for
thatching
,
heather
(
or
rather
ling
)
was
used
.
<EOS>
Then
there
was
meat
to

<EOS>

of
reading
and
understanding
what
he
read
was
almost
too
much
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
could
read
,
or
he
could
understand
what
was
read
aloud
to
him
;
reading
was
no
pleasure
,
but
listening
was
.
  
<EOS>
Besides
,
he
had
a
true
John
Bullish
interest
in
the
war
,
without
very
well

what
the
English
were
fighting
for
.
<EOS>
But
in
those
days
,
so

fought
the
French
for
any

,
or

no

,
every

was
satisfied
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
and
her
mother
did
not
care
for
any
such
far
-
extended
interest
;
a
little
bit
of
York
news
,
the

of
a

a

that
they

,
was

far
more

of
Nelson
and

North
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
read
in
a
high
-
pitched
and
unnatural
tone
of
voice
,
which
deprived
the
words
of
their
reality
;
for
even
familiar

can
become
unfamiliar
and
convey
no
ideas
,
if
the
utterance
is
forced
or
affected
.
<EOS>
Philip
was
somewhat
of
a
pedant
;
yet
there

a

in
his

not
always
to

in

,
and

now

prized

,

,
until

Sylvia
,

,

,
her

;

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

.

.

"
  
<EOS>
Philip

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
    
<EOS>
THE
SPECKSIONEER
  
<EOS>
A
few
days
after
,
Farmer
Robson
left
Haytersbank
betimes
on
a
longish
day
's
journey
,
to
purchase
a
horse
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
and
her
mother
were
busied
with
a
hundred
household
things
,
and
the
early
winter
's
evening
closed
in
upon
them
almost
before
they
were
aware
.
<EOS>
The
consequences
of
darkness
in
the
country
even
now
are
to
gather
the
members
of
a
family
together
into
one
room
,
and
to
make
them
settle
to
some
sedentary
employment
;
and
it
was
much
more
the
case
at
the
period
of
my
story
,
when
candles
were
far
dearer
than
they
are
at
present
,
and
when
one
was
often
made
to
suffice
for
a
large
family
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
and
daughter
hardly
spoke
at
all
when
they
sat
down
at
last
.
<EOS>
The
cheerful
click
of
the
knitting
-
needles
made
a
pleasant
home
-
sound
;
and
in
the
occasional
snatches
of
slumber
that
overcame
her
mother
,
Sylvia
could
hear
the
long
-
rushing
boom
of
the
waves
,
down
below
the
rocks
,
for
the
Haytersbank
gulley
allowed
the
sullen
roar
to
come
up
so
far
inland
.
<EOS>
It
might
have
been
about
eight
o'clock
 
though
from
the
monotonous
course
of
the
evening
<EOS>
it
seemed
much
later
 
when
Sylvia
heard
her
father
's
heavy
step
cranching
down
the
pebbly
path
.
<EOS>
More
unusual
,
she
heard
his
voice
talking
to
some
companion
.
  
<EOS>
Curious
to
see
who
it
could
be
,
with
a
lively
instinctive
advance
towards
any
event
which
might
break
the
monotony
she
had
begun
to
find
somewhat
dull
,
she
sprang
up
to
open
the
door
.
<EOS>
Half
a
glance
into
the
gray
darkness
outside
made
her
suddenly
timid
,
and
she
drew
back
behind
the
door
as
she
opened
it
wide
to
admit
her
father
and
Kinraid
.
  
<EOS>
Daniel
Robson
came
in
bright
and
boisterous
.
<EOS>
He
was
pleased
with
his
purchase
,
and
had
had
some
drink
to
celebrate
his
bargain
.
<EOS>
He
had
ridden
the
new
mare
into
Monkshaven
,
and
left
her
at
the
smithy
there
until
morning
,
to
have
her
feet
looked
at
,
and
to
be
new
shod
.
<EOS>
On
his
way
from
the
town
he
had
met
Kinraid
wandering
about
in
search
of
Haytersbank
Farm
itself
,
so
he
had
just
brought
him
along
with
him
;
and
here
they
were
,
ready
for
bread
and
cheese
,
and
aught
else
<EOS>
the
mistress
would
set
before
them
.
  
<EOS>
To
Sylvia
the
sudden
change
into
brightness
and
bustle
occasioned
by
the
entrance
of
her
father
and
<EOS>
the
specksioneer
was
like
that
which
you
may
effect
any
winter
's
night
,
when
you
come
into
a
room
where
a
great
lump
of
coal
lies
hot
and
slumbering
on
the
fire
;
just
break
it
up
with
a
judicious
blow
from
the
poker
,
and
the
room
,
late
so
dark
,
and
dusk
,
and
lone
,
is
full
of
life
,
and
light
,
and
warmth
.
  
<EOS>
She
moved
about
with
pretty
household
briskness
,
attending
to
all
her
father
's
wants
.
<EOS>
Kinraid
's
eye
watched
her
as
she
went
backwards
and
forwards
,
to
and
fro
,
into
the
pantry
,
the
back
-
kitchen
,
out
of
light
into
shade
,
out
of
the
shadow
into
the
broad
firelight
where
he
could
see
and
note
her
appearance
.
<EOS>
She
wore
the
high
-
crowned
linen
cap
of
that
day
,
surmounting
her
lovely
masses
of
golden
brown
hair
,
rather
than
concealing
them
,
and
tied
firm
to
her
head
by
a
broad
blue
ribbon
.
<EOS>
A
long
curl
hung
down
on
each
side
of
her
neck
 
<EOS>
her
throat
<EOS>
rather
,
for
her
neck
was
concealed
by
a
little
spotted
handkerchief
carefully
pinned
across
at
the
waist
of
her
brown
stuff
gown
.
  
<EOS>
How
well
it
was
,
thought
the
young
girl
,
that
she
had
doffed
her
bed
-
gown
and
linsey
-
woolsey
petticoat
,
her
working
-

,
and
made
herself
smart
in
her
stuff
gown
,
when
she
sate

to
work

mother
.
  
<EOS>
By
the

she
could
sit

again
,
her
father
and
Kinraid
had
their

filled
,
and

talking
of
the
relative
merits
of
various
kinds
of
spirits
;
that
led
on
to
tales
of
smuggling
,
and
the
different
contrivances
by
which
they
or
their
friends
had
eluded
the
preventive
service
;
the
nightly
relays
of
men
to
carry

goods
inland
;
the
kegs
of
brandy
found
by
certain
farmers
whose

had
gone
so
far
in
the
night
,
that
they
could
do
no
work
the
next
day
;
the
clever
way
in
which
certain
women
managed
to
bring
in
prohibited
goods
;
in
fact
,
that
when
a
woman
did
give

to
smuggling
,
she
was
more
full
of
resources
,
and
tricks
,
and
impudence
,
and
energy
than
any
man
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
question
of
the
morality
of
the
affair
;
one
of
the
greatest
signs
of
the
real
progress
we
have
made
since
those
times
seems
to
be
that
our
daily
concerns
of
buying
and
selling
,
eating
and
drinking
,
whatsoever
we
do
,
are
more
tested
by
the
real
practical
standard
of
our
religion
than

the
days

our

.
<EOS>
Neither
Sylvia
nor
her
mother
was
in
advance
of
their
age
.
<EOS>
Both
listened
with
admiration
to
the
ingenious
devices
,
and
acted
as
well
as
spoken
lies
,
that
were
talked
about
as
fine
and
spirited
things
.
<EOS>
Yet
if
Sylvia
had
attempted
one
tithe
of
this
deceit
in
her
every
-
day
life
,
it
would
have
half
broken
her
mother
's
heart
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
duty
on
salt
was
strictly
and
cruelly

,
making
it
penal
to
pick

rough
dirty

ashes

-

;
when
the

of
this
necessary
was

the
tax
upon
it
as

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
It

;

I

.
  
<EOS>
From

<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>
But
,

.
<EOS>
With

came

and
little
homely
every

.
<EOS>
Did

,

?
<EOS>
Was

Molly

,

?
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>

that

<EOS>

<EOS>
A
REFRACTORY
PUPIL
  
Sylvia

full

"
Abednegos
,
"

and
sea
around
that
one

.
<EOS>

such

)
 
<EOS>
understanding

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
and
a
sort
of
consciousness
of
unusual
good
looks
gave
her
a
slight
tinge
of
coquettish
shyness
with
the
few
strangers
whom
she
ever
saw
.
<EOS>
Philip
hailed
her
interest
in
geography
as
another
sign
of
improvement
.
<EOS>
He
had
brought
back
his
book
of
maps
to
the
farm
;
and
there
he
sat
on
many
an
evening
teaching
his
cousin
,
who
had
strange
fancies
respecting
the
places
about
which
she
wished
to
learn
,
and
was
coolly
indifferent
to
the
very
existence
of
other
towns
,
and
countries
,
and
seas
far
more
famous
in
story
.
<EOS>
She
was
occasionally
wilful
,
and
at
times
very
contemptuous
as
to
the
superior
knowledge
of
her
instructor
;
but
,
in
spite
of
it
all
,
Philip
went
regularly
on
the
appointed
evenings
to
Haytersbank
 
through
keen
black
east
wind
,
or
driving
snow
,
or
slushing
thaw
;
for
he
liked
dearly
to
sit
a
little
behind
her
,
with
his
arm
on
the
back
of
her
chair
,
she
stooping
over
the
outspread
map
,
with
her
eyes
<EOS>
,
 
could
he
have
seen
them
,
 
a
good
deal
fixed
on
one
spot
in
the
map
,
not
Northumberland
,
where
Kinraid
was
spending
the
winter
,
but
those
wild
northern
seas
about
which
he
had
told
them
such
wonders
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
towards
spring
,
she
saw
Molly
Corney
coming
towards
the
farm
.
<EOS>
The
companions
had
not
met
for
many
weeks
,
for
Molly
had
been
from
home
visiting
her
relations
in
the
north
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
opened
the
door
,
and
stood
smiling
and
shivering
on
the
threshold
,
glad
to
see
her
friend
again
.
<EOS>
Molly
called
out
,
when
a

,
    
"
Why
,
Sylvia
,
is
that
thee
!
<EOS>
Why
,

thou'rt
growed
,
to

sure
!
<EOS>
What

bonny

thou
is
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Dunnot
talk
nonsense

my

,
"
said
Bell
Robson
,
hospitably

and

;
but

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ay
;

,
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

fra

<EOS>

Charley

,
"

"

"

Mrs.

;
but

.
<EOS>
She

;
it

a

.
<EOS>
Molly

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.

,

!

.
<EOS>

,

ha

's

what

.
"
  
<EOS>
Molly
's

was

.
<EOS>
Sylvia

's

,

,

,

;
but

.

She

,
    
"

's
none

;

's

.
<EOS>
Let

,

's

i
'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Molly

<EOS>
;
but

at

kept

;
and

,

.

"
That

.

.

It

,

"

.

,
"

.

;

"

.
    
<EOS>
VISIONS
OF
THE
FUTURE
  
<EOS>
Before
May
was
out
,
Molly
Corney
was
married
and
had
left
the
neighbourhood
for
Newcastle
.
<EOS>
Although
Charley
Kinraid
was
not
the
bridegroom
,
Sylvia
's
promise
to
be
bridesmaid
was
claimed
.
<EOS>
But
the
friendship
brought
on
by
the
circumstances
of
neighbourhood
and
parity
of
age
had
become
very
much
weakened
in
the
time
that
elapsed
between
Molly
's
engagement
and
wedding
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
place
,
she
herself
was
so
absorbed
in
her
preparations
,
so
elated
by
her
good
fortune
in
getting
married
,
and
married
,
too
,
before
her
elder
sister
,
that
all
her
faults
blossomed
out
full
and
strong
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
felt
her
to
be
selfish
;
Mrs.
Robson
thought
her
not
maidenly
.
<EOS>
A
year
before
she
would
have
been
far
more
missed
and
regretted
by
Sylvia
;
now
it
was
almost
a
relief
to
the
latter
to
be
freed
from
the
perpetual
calls
upon
her
sympathy
,
from
the
constant
demands
upon
her
congratulations
,
made
by
one
who
had
no
thought
or
feeling
to
bestow
on
others
;
at
least
,
not
in
these
weeks
of
"
cock
-
a
-
doodle
-
dooing
,
"
as
Mrs.
Robson
persisted
in
calling
it
.
<EOS>
It
was
seldom
that
Bell
was
taken
with
a
humorous
idea
;
but
this
once
having
hatched
a
solitary
joke
,
she
was
always
clucking
it
into
notice
 
to
go
on
with
her
own
poultry
simile
.
  
<EOS>
Every
time
during
that
summer
that
Philip
saw
his
cousin
,
he
thought
her
prettier
than
she
had
ever
been
before
;
some
new
touch
of
colour
,
some
fresh
sweet
charm
,
seemed
to
have
been
added
,
just
as
every
summer
day
calls
out
new
beauty
in
the
flowers
.
<EOS>
And
this
was
not
the
addition
of
Philip
's
fancy
.
<EOS>
Hester
Rose
,
who
met
Sylvia
on
rare
occasions
,
came
back
each
time
with
a
candid
,
sad
acknowledgement
in
her
heart
that
it
was
no
wonder
that
Sylvia
was
so
much
admired
and
loved
.
  
<EOS>
One
day
Hester
had
seen
her
sitting
near
her
mother
in
the
market
-
place
;
there
was
a
basket
by
her
,
and
over
the
clean
cloth
that
covered
the
yellow
pounds
of
butter
,
she
had
laid
the
hedge
-
roses
and
honeysuckles
she
had
gathered
on
the
way
into
Monkshaven
;
her
straw
hat
was
on
her
knee
,
and
she
was
busy
placing
some
of
the
flowers
in
the
ribbon
that
went
round
it
.
<EOS>
Then
she
held
it
on
her
hand
,
and
turned
it
round
about
,
putting
her
head
on
one
side
,
the
better
to
view
the
effect
;
and
all
this
time
,
Hester
,
peeping
at
her
through
the
folds
of
the
stuffs
displayed
in
Foster
's
windows
,
saw
her
with
admiring
,
wistful
eyes
;
wondering
,
too
,
if
Philip
,
at
the
other
counter
,
were
aware
of
his
cousin
's
being
there
,
so
near
to
him
.
<EOS>
Then
Sylvia
put
on
her
hat
,
and
,
looking
up
at
Foster
's
windows
,
caught
Hester
's
face
of
interest
,
and
smiled
and
blushed
at
the
consciousness
of
having
been
watched
over
her
little
vanities
,
and
Hester
smiled
back
,
but
rather
sadly
.
<EOS>
Then
a
customer
came
in
,
and
she
had
to
attend
to
her
business
,
which
,
on
this
as
on
all
market
days
,
was
great
.
<EOS>
In
the
midst
she
was
aware
of
Philip
rushing
bare
-
headed
out
of
the
shop
,
eager
and
delighted
at
something
he
saw
outside
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
little
looking
-
glass
hung
against
the
wall
on
Hester
's
side
,
placed
in
that
retired
corner
,
in
order
that
the
good
women
who
came
to
purchase
head
-
gear
of
any
kind
might
see
the
effect
thereof
before
they
concluded
their
bargain
.
<EOS>
In
a
pause
of
custom
,
Hester
,
half
-
ashamed
,
stole
into
this
corner
,
and
looked
at
herself
in
the
glass
.
<EOS>
What
did
she
see
?
<EOS>
a
colourless
face
,
dark
soft
hair
with
no
light
gleams
in
it
,
eyes
that
were
melancholy
instead
of
smiling
,
a
mouth
compressed
with
a
sense
of
dissatisfaction
.
<EOS>
This
was
what
she
had
to
compare
with
the
bright
bonny
face
in
the
sunlight
outside
.
<EOS>
She
gave
a
gulp
to
check
the
sigh
that
was
rising
,
and
came
back
,
even
more
patient
than
she
had
been
before
this
disheartening
peep
,
to
serve
all
the
whims
and
fancies
of
purchasers
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
herself
had
been
rather
put
out
by
Philip
's
way
of
coming
to
her
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It
made
her
look
so
silly
,
"
she
thought
;
and
"
what
for
must
he
make
a
sight
of
himself
,
coming
among
the
market
folk
in
that
-
a
-
way
"
;
and
when
he
took
to
admiring
her
hat
,
she
pulled
out
the
flowers
in
a
pet
,
and
threw
them
down
,
and
trampled
them
under
foot
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
for
art
thou
doing
that
,
Sylvie
?
"
said
her
mother
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
flowers
is
well
enough
,
though
may
-
be
thy
hat
might
ha
'
been
stained
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
like
Philip
to
speak
to
me
so
,
"
said
Sylvia
,
pouting
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
?
"
asked
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
But
Sylvia
could
not
repeat
his
words
.
<EOS>
She
hung
her
head
,
and
looked
red
and
pre
-
occupied
,
anything
but
pleased
.
<EOS>
Philip
had
addressed
his
first
expression
of
personal
admiration
at
an
unfortunate
tune
.
  
<EOS>
It
just
shows
what
different
views
different
men
and
women
take

Philip

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
These

were

<EOS>
She
was
afraid

;

,

were

,

.
<EOS>

would
not

to

grave

of
character
,

;
she
would

against

,

.
<EOS>
When
she
wanted

,
she
sought
his
advice
on
such

as
came
up

;
and

not

when
he
used
more
words
 
and
more

words
 
than
were

to

.
<EOS>
But
her
ideal
husband
was
different
from
Philip
in
every
point
,
the
two

never

.
<EOS>
To

she
was

;

was

one

on

he
dared

,
for
fear

both

and

should
decide

,

be

against

will

,
that

his
,
and
that

was

to

his

,
to
the

all

which
,

,

.
<EOS>
For
he
had
been
brought
up
among
the
Quakers
,
and
shared
in

of
a
self

spirit
;
yet
what
else

was

,
"
<EOS>
Give

,

else
,

?
"
<EOS>
No
other
vision
had
ever
crossed
his

for

;
his
was
a
rare
and
constant
love
that
deserved
a
better
fate
than
it
met
with
.
<EOS>
At
this

his
hopes
were
high
,
as
I
have

,
not
merely
as
to
the

Sylvia
's

,

to
the

of

such

,
as
his
wife
,
as
she
had
never

before
.
  
<EOS>
For

brothers
Foster
were
thinking
of
retiring
from

,
and
relinquishing

shop
to
their

,
Philip
Hepburn
and
William
Coulson
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
it
was
only
by
looking
back
for
a
few
months
,
and
noticing
chance
expressions
and
small
indications
,
that
this
intention
of
theirs
could
be
discovered
.
<EOS>
But
every
step
they
took
tended
this
way
,
and
Philip
knew
their
usual
practice
of
deliberation
too
well
to
feel
in
the
least
impatient
for
the
quicker
progress
of
the
end
which
he
saw
steadily
approaching
.
<EOS>
The
whole
atmosphere
of
life
among
the
Friends
at
this
date
partook
of
this
character
of
self
-
repression
,
and
both
Coulson
and
Hepburn
shared
in
it
.
<EOS>
Coulson
was
just
as
much
aware
of
the
prospect
opening
before
him
as
Hepburn
;
but
they
never
spoke
together
on
the
subject
,
although
their
mutual
knowledge
might
be
occasionally
implied
in
their
conversation
on
their
future
lives
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
the
Fosters
were
imparting
more
of
the
background
of
their
business
to
their
successors
.
<EOS>
For
the
present
,
at
least
,
the
brothers
meant
to
retain
an
interest
in
the
shop
,
even
after
they
had
given
up
the
active
management
;
and
they
sometimes
thought
of
setting
up
a
separate
establishment
as
bankers
.
<EOS>
The
separation
of
the
business
,
 
the
introduction
of
their
shopmen
to
the
distant
manufacturers
who
furnished
their
goods
(
in
those
days
the
system
of
"
travellers
"
was
not
so
widely
organized
as
it
is
at
present
)
,
 
all
these
steps
were
in
gradual
progress
;
and
already
Philip
saw
himself
in
imagination
in
the
dignified
position
of
joint
master
of
the
principal
shop
in
Monkshaven
,
with
Sylvia
installed
as
his
wife
,
with
certainly
a
silk
gown
,
and
possibly
a
gig
at
her
disposal
.
<EOS>
In
all
Philip
's
visions
of
future
prosperity
,
it
was
Sylvia
who
was
to
be
aggrandized
by
them
;
his
own
life
was
to
be
spent
as
it
was
now
,
pretty
much
between
the
four
shop
walls
.
    
<EOS>
NEW
YEAR
'S
FETE
  
<EOS>
All
this
enlargement
of
interest
in
the
shop
occupied
Philip
fully
for
some
months
after
the
period
referred
to
in
the
preceding
chapter
.
<EOS>
Remembering
his
last
conversation
with
his
aunt
,
he
might
have
been
uneasy
at
his
inability
to
perform
his
promise
and
look
after
his
pretty
cousin
,
but
that
about
the
middle
of
November
Bell
Robson
had
fallen
ill
of
a
rheumatic
fever
,
and
that
her
daughter
had
been
entirely
absorbed
in
nursing
her
.
<EOS>
No
thought
of
company
or
gaiety
was
in
Sylvia
's
mind
as
long
as
her
mother
's
illness
lasted
;
vehement
in
all
her
feelings
,
she
discovered
in
the
dread
of
losing
her
mother
how
passionately
she
was
attached
to
her
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
<EOS>
she
had
supposed
,
as
children
so
often
do
,
that
her
parents
would
live
for
ever
;
and
now
when
it
was
a
question
of
days
,
whether
by
that
time
the
following
week
her
mother
might
not
be
buried
out
of
her
sight
for
ever
,
she
clung
to
every
semblance
of
service
to
be
rendered
,
or
affection
shown
,
as
if
she
hoped
to
condense
the
love
and
care
of
years
into
the
few
days
only
that
might
remain
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Robson
lingered
on
,
began
slowly
to
recover
,
and
before
Christmas
was
again
sitting
by
the
fireside
in
the
house
-
place
,
wan
and
pulled
down
,
muffled
up
with
shawls
and
blankets
,
but
still
there
once
more
,
where
not
long
before
Sylvia
had
scarcely
expected
to
see
her
again
.
<EOS>
Philip
came
up
that
evening
and
found
Sylvia
in
wild
spirits
.
<EOS>
She
thought
that
everything
was
done
,
now
that
her
mother
had
once
come
downstairs
again
;
she
laughed
with
glee
;
she
kissed
her
mother
;
she
shook
hands
with
Philip
,
she
almost
submitted
to
a
speech
of
more
than
usual
tenderness
from
him
;
but
,
in
the
midst
of
his
words
,
her
mother
's
pillows
wanted
arranging
<EOS>
and
she
went
to
her
chair
,
paying
no
more
heed
to
his
words
than
if

had
been
addressed
to
the
cat
,
that
lying
on
the
invalid
's
knee
was
purring
out
her
welcome
to
the
weak
hand
feebly

back
.
<EOS>
Robson
himself
soon
came
in
,
looking
older
and
more
subdued
since
Philip
had
seen
him
last
.
<EOS>
He
was
very
urgent
that
his
wife
should
have
some
spirits
and
water
;
but
on
her
refusal
,
almost
as
if
she
loathed
the
thought
of
the
smell
,
he
contented
himself
with
sharing
her
tea
,
though
he
kept
abusing
the
beverage
as
"
washing
the
heart
out
of
a
man
,
"
and

all
the
degeneracy
of
the
world
,
growing
up
about
him
in
his

,
to
the

of
such

.
<EOS>
At

,

little
self

,

Isabella

.
<EOS>
He

(

)

.
<EOS>
So

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
At
this

,
all
the
actors
in
this
story
having

,

in

to

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

,

,

,
after

common
to

.
<EOS>
They
might
have
smiled
could

have
read
in
his

the

of
the
coming

,
when
he

in

,

under

,
among

to

,
not
so

as
their
every

,
but

.
<EOS>
Philip
had
so

to
anything

kind
,
that
,

Sylvia
not
been
going
,
he

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

Sylvia

not

going
,

Philip
's

question
whether

did
not
savour
too
much
of
the

.
  
<EOS>
As

,
however
,
the

.
<EOS>
He
was
going
and
she
was
going
.
<EOS>
The
day
before
,
he
had

with

for
Sylvia
.
<EOS>

first

ever

to

her
 
the
first

of
the
kind
<EOS>
would
,

,

;
for
when

any

.
<EOS>

man

white
knee
-
breeches
,
and
a
three
-
cornered
hat
;
with
one
arm
he
supported
the
pipe
in
his
broad
,
smiling
mouth
,
and
the
other
was
placed
akimbo
and
formed
the
handle
.
<EOS>
There
was
also
a
great
china
punch
-
bowl
filled
with
grog
made
after
an
old
ship
-
receipt
current
in
these
parts
,
but
not
too
strong
,
because
if
their

had
too
much
to

at
that
early

of
the
evening
"
it
would
spoil
t
'
fun
,
"
as
Nelly

had
observed
.
<EOS>
Her

,

,

prevalent

that

,
had
stipulated
that
each

should

"
enough
"
before

house
;
enough
meaning
in
Monkshaven
parlance
the
liberty
of
getting

,
if
they
thought
fit
to
do

.
  
<EOS>
Before

for
Toby

the

and

<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Kinraid

;
Philip

what

,

because

,

.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
was
by

the

.
<EOS>
When

played
at
blind
-
man's
-
buff

,

?
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Satisfied

,

,

<EOS>
The

almost

;

<EOS>

came

;
