.
<EOS>
The
field
-
paths
would
have
been
a
matter
of
perplexity
,
had
it
not
been
for
the
well
-
known
gaps
in
the
dyke
-
side
,
which
showed
the
whitened
land
beyond
,
between
the
two
dark
stone
walls
.
<EOS>
Yet
he
went
clear
and
straight
along
his
way
,
having
unconsciously
left
all
guidance
to
the
animal
instinct
which
co
-
exists
with
the
human
soul
,
and
sometimes
takes
strange
charge
of
the
human
body
,
when
all
the
nobler
powers
of
the
individual
are
absorbed
in
acute
suffering
.
<EOS>
At
length
he
was
in
the
lane
,
toiling
up
the
hill
,
from
which
,
by
day
,
Monkshaven
might
be
seen
.
<EOS>
Now
all
features
of
the
landscape
before
him
were
lost
in
the
darkness
of
night
,
against
which
the
white
flakes
came
closer
and
nearer
,
thicker
and
faster
.
<EOS>
On
a
sudden
,
the
bells
of
Monkshaven
church
rang
out
a
welcome
to
the
new
year
,
1796
.
<EOS>
From
the
direction
of
the
wind
,
it
seemed
as
if
the
sound
was
flung
with
strength
and
power
right
into
Philip
's
face
.
<EOS>
He
walked
down
the
hill
to
its
merry
sound
 
its
merry
sound
,
his
heavy
heart
.
<EOS>
As
he
entered
the
long
High
Street
of
Monkshaven
he
could
see
the
watching
lights
put
out
in
parlour
,
chamber
,
or
kitchen
.
<EOS>
The
new
year
had
come
,
and
expectation
was
ended
.
<EOS>
Reality
had
begun
.
  
<EOS>
He
turned
to
the
right
,
into
the
court
where
he
lodged
with
Alice
Rose
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
light
still
burning
there
,
and
cheerful
voices
were
heard
.
<EOS>
He
opened
the
door
;
Alice
,
her
daughter
,
and
Coulson
stood
as
if
awaiting
him
.
<EOS>
Hester
's
wet
cloak
hung
on
a
chair
before
the
fire
;
she
had
her
hood
on
,
<EOS>
for
she
and
Coulson
had
been
to
the
watch
-
night
.
  
<EOS>
The
solemn
excitement
of
the
services
had
left
its
traces
upon
her
countenance
and
in
her
mind
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
spiritual
light
in
her
usually
shadowed
eyes
,
and
a
slight
flush
on
her
pale
cheek
.
<EOS>
Merely
personal
and
self
-
conscious
feelings
were
merged
in
a
loving
good
-
will
to
all
her
fellow
-
creatures
.
<EOS>
Under
the
influence
of
this
large
charity
,
she
forgot
her
habitual
reserve
,
and
came
forward
as
Philip
entered
to
meet
him
with
her
new
year
's
wishes
 
<EOS>
wishes
that
she
had
previously
interchanged
with
the
other
two
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
happy
new
year
to
you
,
Philip
,
and
may
God
have
you
in
his
keeping
all
the
days
thereof
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
took
her
hand
,
and
shook
it
warmly
in
reply
.
<EOS>
The
flush
on
her
cheek
deepened
as
she
withdrew
it
.
<EOS>
Alice
Rose
said
something
curtly
about
the
lateness
of
the
hour
and
her
being
much
tired
;
and
then
she
and
her
daughter
went
upstairs
to
the
front
chamber
,
and
Philip
and
Coulson
to
that
which
they
shared
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
    
<EOS>
PERPLEXITIES
  
<EOS>
Coulson
and
Philip
were
friendly
,
but
not
intimate
.
<EOS>
They
never
had
had
a
dispute
,
they
never
were
confidential
with
each
other
;
in
truth
,
they
were
both
reserved
and
silent
men
,
and
,
probably
,
respected
each
other
the
more
for
being
so
self
-
contained
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
private
feeling
in
Coulson
's
heart
which
would
have
made
a
less
amiable
fellow
dislike
Philip
.
<EOS>
But
of
this
the
latter
was
unconscious
:
they
were
not
apt
to
exchange
many
words
in
the
room
which
they
occupied
jointly
.
  
<EOS>
Coulson
asked
Philip
if
he
had
enjoyed
himself
at
the
Corneys
'
,
and
Philip
replied
,
    
"
Not
much
;
such
parties
are
noane
to
my
liking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
yet
thou
broke
off
from
t
'
watch
-
night
to
go
there
.
"
  
<EOS>
No
answer
;
so
Coulson
went
on
,
with
a
sense
of
the
duty
laid
upon
him
,
to
improve
the
occasion
 
the
first
that
had
presented
itself
since
the
good
old
Methodist
minister
had
given
his
congregation
the
solemn
warning
to
watch
over
the
opportunities
of
various
kinds
which
the
coming
year
would
present
.
  
<EOS>
"
Jonas
Barclay
told
us
as
the
pleasures
o
'
<EOS>
this
world
were
like
apples
o
'
Sodom
,
pleasant
to
look
at
,
but
ashes
to
taste
.
"
  
<EOS>
Coulson
wisely
left
Philip
to
make
the
application
for
himself
.
<EOS>
If
he
did
he
made
no
sign
,
but
threw
himself
on
his
bed
with
a
heavy
sigh
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
yo
'
not
going
to
undress
?
"
said
Coulson
,
as
he
covered
him
up
in
bed
.
  
<EOS>
There
had
been
a
long
pause
of
silence
.
<EOS>
Philip
did
not
answer
him
,
and
he
thought
he
had
fallen
asleep
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
roused
from
his
first
slumber
by
Hepburn
's
soft
movements
about
the
room
.
<EOS>
Philip
had
thought
better
of
it
,
and
,
with
some
penitence
in
his
heart
for
his
gruffness
to
the
unoffending
Coulson
,
was
trying
not
to
make
any
noise
while
he
undressed
.
  
<EOS>
But
he
could
not
sleep
.
<EOS>
He
kept
seeing
the
Corneys
'
kitchen
and
the
scenes
that
had
taken
place
in
it
,
passing
like
a
pageant
before
his
closed
eyes
.
<EOS>
Then
he
opened
them
in
angry
weariness
at
the
recurring
vision
,
and
tried
to
make
out
the
outlines
of
the
room
and
the
furniture
in
the
darkness
.
<EOS>
The
white
ceiling
sloped
into
the
whitewashed
walls
,
and
against
them
he
could
see
the
four
rush
-
bottomed
chairs
,
the
looking
-
glass
hung
on
one
side
,
the
old
carved
oak
-
chest
(
his
own
property
,
with
the
initials
of
forgotten
ancestors
cut
upon
it
)
,
which
held
his
clothes
;
the
boxes
that
belonged
to
Coulson
,
sleeping
soundly
in
the
bed
in
the
opposite
corner
of
the
room
;
the
casement
window
in
the
roof
,
through
which
the
snowy
ground
on
the
steep
hill
-
side
could
be
plainly
seen
;
and
when
he
got
so
far
as
this
in
the
catalogue
of
the
room
,
he
fell
into
a
troubled
feverish
sleep
,
which
lasted
two
or
three
hours
;
and
then
he
awoke
with
a
start
,
and
a
consciousness
of
uneasiness
,
though
what
about
he
could
not
remember
at
first
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
recollected
all
that
had
happened
the
night
before
,
it
impressed
him
much
more
favourably
than
it
had
done
at
the
time
.
<EOS>
If
not
joy
,
hope
had
come
in
the
morning
;
and
,
at
any
rate
,
he
could
be
up
and
be
doing
,
for
the
late
wintry
light
was
stealing
down
the
hill
-
side
,
and
he
knew
that
,
although
Coulson
lay
motionless
in
his
sleep
,
it
was
past
their
usual
time
of
rising
.
<EOS>
Still
,
as
it
was
new
year
's
Day
,
a
time
of
some
licence
,
Philip
had
mercy
on
his
fellow
-
shopman
,
and
did
not
waken
him
till
just
as
he
was
leaving
the
room
.
  
<EOS>
Carrying
his
shoes
in
his
hand
,
he
went
softly
downstairs
for
he
could
see
from
the
top
of
the
flight
that
neither
Alice
nor
her
daughter
was
down
yet
,
as
the
kitchen
shutters
were
not
unclosed
.
<EOS>
It
was
Mrs.
Rose
's
habit
to
rise
early
,
and
have
all
bright
and
clean
against
her
lodgers
came
down
;
but
then
,
in
general
,
she
went
to
rest
before
nine
o'clock
,
whereas
the
last
night
she
had
not
gone
till
past
twelve
.
<EOS>
Philip
went
about
undoing
the
shutters
,
and
trying
to
break
up
the
raking
coal
,
with
as
little
noise
as
might
be
,
for
he
had
compassion
on
the
tired
sleepers
.
<EOS>
The
kettle
had
not
been
filled
,
probably
because
Mrs.
Rose
had
been
unable
to
face
the
storm
of
the
night
before
,
in
taking
it
to
the
pump
just
at
the
entrance
of
the
court
.
<EOS>
When
Philip
came
back
from
filling
it
,
he
found
Alice
and
Hester
both
in
the
kitchen
,
and
trying
to
make
up
for
lost
time
by
hastening
over
their
work
.
<EOS>
Hester
looked
busy
and
notable
with
her
gown
pinned
up
behind
her
,
and
her
hair
all
tucked
away
under
a
clean
linen
cap
;
but
Alice
was
angry
with
herself
for
her
late
sleeping
,
and
that
and
other
causes
made
her
speak
crossly
to
Philip
,
as
he
came
in
with
his
snowy
feet
and
well
-
filled
kettle
.
  
<EOS>
"
Look
the
'
there
!
<EOS>
droppin
'
and
drippin
'
along
t
'
flags
as
was
cleaned
last
night
,
and
meddlin
'
<EOS>
wi
'
woman
's
work
as
a
man
has
no
business
wi
'
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Philip
was
surprised
and
annoyed
.
<EOS>
He
had
found
relief
from
his
own
thoughts
in
doing
what
he
believed
would
help
others
.
<EOS>
He
gave
up
the
kettle
to
her
snatching
hands
,
and
sate
down
behind
the
door
in
momentary
ill
-
temper
.
<EOS>
But
the
kettle
was
better
filled
,
and
consequently
heavier
than
the
old
woman
expected
,
and
she
could
not
manage
to
lift
it
to
the
crook
from
which
it
generally
hung
suspended
.
<EOS>
She
looked
round
for
Hester
,
but
she
was
gone
into
the
back
-
kitchen
.
<EOS>
In
a
minute
Philip
was
at
her
side
,
and
had
heaved
it
to
its
place
for
her
.
<EOS>
She
looked
in
his
face
for
a
moment
wistfully
,
but
hardly
condescended
to
thank
him
;
at
least
the
sound
of
the
words
did
not
pass
the
lips
that
formed
them
.
<EOS>
Rebuffed
by
her
manner
,
he
went
back
to
his
old
seat
,
and
mechanically
watched
the
preparations
for
breakfast
;
but
his
thoughts
went
back
to
the
night
before
,
and
the
comparative
ease
of
his
heart
was
gone
.
<EOS>
The
first
stir
of
a
new
day
had
made
him
feel
as
if
he
had
had
no
sufficient
cause
for
his
annoyance
and
despondency
the
previous
evening
;
but
now
,
condemned
to
sit
quiet
,
he
reviewed
looks
and
words
,
and
saw
just
reason
for
his
anxiety
.
<EOS>
After
some
consideration
he
resolved
to
go
that
very
night
to
Haytersbank
,
and
have
some
talk
with
either
Sylvia
or
her
mother
;
what
the
exact
nature
of
this
purposed
conversation
should
be
,
he
did
not
determine
;
much
would
depend
on
Sylvia
's
manner
and
mood
,
and
on
her
mother
's
state
of
health
;
but
at
any
rate
something
would
be
learnt
.
  
<EOS>
During
breakfast
something
was
learnt
nearer
home
;
though
not
all
that
a
man
less
unconscious
and
more
vain
than
Philip
might
have
discovered
.
<EOS>
He
only
found
out
that
Mrs.
Rose
was
displeased
with
him
for
not
having
gone
to
the
watch
-
night
with
Hester
,
according
to
the
plan
made
some
weeks
before
.
<EOS>
But
he
soothed
his
conscience
by
remembering
that
he
had
made
no
promise
;
he
had
merely
spoken
of
his
wish
to
be
present
at
the
service
,
about
which
Hester
was
speaking
;
and
although
at
the
time
and
for
a
good
while
afterwards
,
he
had
fully
intended
going
,
yet
as
there
had
been
William
Coulson
to
accompany
her
,
his
absence
could
not
have
been
seriously
noticed
.
<EOS>
Still
he
was
made
uncomfortable
by
Mrs.
Rose
's
change
of
manner
;
once
or
twice
he
said
to
himself
that
she
little
knew
how
miserable
he
had
been
during
his
"
gay
evening
,
"
as
she
would
persist
in
calling
it
,
or
she
would
not
talk
at
him
with
such
persevering
bitterness
this
morning
.
<EOS>
Before
he
left
for
the
shop
,
he
spoke
of
his
intention
of
going
to
see
how
his
aunt
was
,
and
of
paying
her
a
new
year
's
day
visit
.
  
<EOS>
Hepburn
and
Coulson
took
it
in
turns
week
and
week
about
to
go
first
home
to
dinner
;
the
one
who
went
first
sate
down
with
Mrs.
Rose
and
her
daughter
,
instead
of
having
his
portion
put
in
the
oven
to
keep
warm
for
him
.
<EOS>
To
-
day
it
was
Hepburn
's
turn
to
be
last
.
<EOS>
All
morning
the
shop
was
full
with
customers
,
come
rather
to
offer
good
wishes
than
to
buy
,
and
with
an
unspoken
remembrance
of
the
cake
and
wine
which
the
two
hospitable
brothers
Foster
made
a
point
of
offering
to
all
comers
on
new
year
's
day
.
<EOS>
It
was
busy
work
for
all
 
for
Hester
on
her
side
,
where
caps
,
ribbons
,
and
women
's
gear
were
exclusively
sold
 
for
the
shopmen
and
boys
in
the
grocery
and
drapery
department
.
<EOS>
Philip
was
trying
to
do
his
business
with
his
mind
far
away
;
and
the
consequence
was
that
his
manner
was
not
such
as
to
recommend
him
to
the
customers
,
some
of
whom
recollected
it
as
very
different
,
courteous
and
attentive
,
if
grave
and
sedate
.
<EOS>
One
buxom
farmer
's
wife
noticed
the
change
to
him
.
<EOS>
She
had
a
little
girl
with
her
,
of
about
five
years
old
,
that
she
had
lifted
up
on
the
counter
,
and
who
was
watching
Philip
with
anxious
eyes
,
occasionally
whispering
in
her
mother
's
ear
,
and
then
hiding
her
face
against
her
cloak
.
  
<EOS>
"
She
's
thought
a
deal
o
'
coming
to
see
yo
'
,
and
a
dunnot
think
as
yo
'
mind
her
at
all
.
<EOS>
My
pretty
,
he
's
clean
forgotten
as
how
he
said
last
new
year
's
day
,
he
'd
gi
'
thee
a
barley
-
sugar
stick
,
if
thou'd
hem
him
a
handkercher
by
this
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
child
's
face
was
buried
in
the
comfortable
breadth
of
duffle
at
these
words
,
while
the
little
outstretched
hand
held
a
small
square
of
coarse

.

And

did
thou
say
?
"
asked
Philip
,
doggedly
unwilling
,
even
yet
,
to
give
up
his
purposed
visit
.
  
<EOS>
"
Say
!
<EOS>
why
,
what
could
a
say
,
but
that
we
'd
come
?
<EOS>
There
was
summat
up
,
for
sure
;
and
summat
as
he
thought
we
should
be
glad
on
.
<EOS>
I
could
tell
it
fra
<EOS>
'
t
'
look
on
his
face
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
think
as
I
can
go
,
"
said
Philip
,
feeling
just
then
as
if
the
long
-
hoped
-
for
partnership
was
as
nothing
compared
to
his
plan
.
<EOS>
It
was
always
distasteful
to
him
to
have
to
give
up
a
project
,
or
to
disarrange
an
intended
order
of
things
,
such
was
his
nature
;
but
to
-
day

was
absolute
pain
to
yield
his
own

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
man
alive
?
"
said
Coulson
,
in
amaze
at
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
n't
say
I
might
n't
go
,
"
said
Philip
,
weighing
consequences
,
until
called
off
to
attend
to
customers
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
course
of
the
afternoon
,
however
,
he
felt
himself
more
easy
in
deferring
his
visit
to
Haytersbank
till
the
next
evening
.
<EOS>
Charley
Kinraid
entered
the
shop
,
accompanied
by
Molly
Brunton
and
her
sisters
;
and
though
they
all
went
towards
Hester
's
side
of
the
shop
,
and
Philip
and
Coulson
had
many
people
to
attend
to
,
yet
Hepburn
's
sharpened
ears
caught
much
of
what
the
young
women
were
saying
.
<EOS>
From
that
he
gathered
that
Kinraid
had
promised
them
new
year
's
gifts
,
for
the
purchase
of
which
they
were
come
;
and
after
a
little
more
listening
he
learnt
that
Kinraid
was
returning
to
Shields
the
next
day
,
having
only
come
over
to
spend
a
holiday
with
his
relations
,
and
being
tied
with
ship
's
work
at
the
other
end
.
<EOS>
They
all
talked
together
lightly
and
merrily
,
as
if
his
going
or
staying
was
almost
a
matter
of
indifference
to
himself
and
his
cousins
.
<EOS>
The
principal
thought
of
the
young
women
was
to
secure
the
articles
they
most
fancied
;
Charley
Kinraid
was
(
so
Philip
thought
)
especially
anxious
that
the
youngest
and
prettiest
should
be
pleased
.
<EOS>
Hepburn
watched
him
perpetually
with
a
kind
of
envy
of
his
bright
,
courteous
manner
,
the
natural
gallantry
of
the
sailor
.
<EOS>
If
it
were
but
clear
that
Sylvia
took
as
little
thought
of
him
as
he
did
of
her
,
to
all
appearance
,
Philip
could
even
have
given
him
praise
for
manly
good
looks
,
and
a
certain
kind
of
geniality
of
disposition
which
made
him
ready
to
smile
pleasantly
at
all
strangers
,
from
babies
upwards
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
party
turned
to
leave
the
shop
they
saw
Philip
,
the
guest
of
the
night
before
;
and
they
came
over
to
shake
hands
with
him
across
the
counter
;
Kinraid
's
hand
was
proffered
among
the
number
.
<EOS>
Last
night
Philip
could
not
have
believed
it
possible
that
such
a
demonstration
of
fellowship
should
have
passed
between
them
;
and
perhaps
there
was
a
slight
hesitation
of
manner
on
his
part
,
for
some
idea
or
remembrance
<EOS>
crossed
Kinraid
's
mind
which
brought
a
keen
searching
glance
into
the
eyes
which
for
a
moment
were
fastened
on
Philip
's
face
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
himself
,
and
during
the
very
action
of
hand
-
shaking
,
Philip
felt
a
cloud
come
over
his
face
,
not
altering
or
moving
his
features
,
but
taking
light
and
peace
out
of
his
countenance
.
  
<EOS>
Molly
Brunton
began
to
say
something
,
and
he
gladly
turned
to
look
at
her
.
<EOS>
She
was
asking
him
why
he
went
away
so
early
,
for
they
had
kept
it
up
for
four
hours
after
he
left
,
and
last
of
all
,
she
added
(
turning
to
Kinraid
)
,
her
cousin
Charley
had
danced
a
hornpipe
among
the
platters
on
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
hardly
knew
what
he
said
in
reply
,
the
mention
of
that
pas
seul
lifted
such
a
weight
off
his
heart
.
<EOS>
He
could
smile
now
,
after
his
grave
fashion
,
and
would
have
shaken
hands
again
with
Kinraid
had
it
been
required
;
for
it
seemed
to
him
that
no
one
,
caring
ever
so
little
in
the
way
that
he
did
for
Sylvia
,
could
have
borne
four
mortal
hours
of
a
company
where
she
had
been
,
and
was
not
;
least
of
all
could
have
danced
a
hornpipe
,
either
from
gaiety
of
heart
,
or
even
out
of
complaisance
.
<EOS>
He
felt
as
if
the
yearning
after
the
absent
one
would
have
been
a
weight
to
his
legs
,
as
well
as
to
his
spirit
;
and
he
imagined
that
all
men
were
like
himself
.
    
<EOS>
PARTNERSHIP
  
<EOS>
As
darkness
closed
in
,
and
the
New
Year
's
throng
became
scarce
,
Philip
's
hesitation
about
accompanying
Coulson
faded
away
.
<EOS>
He
was
more
comfortable
respecting
Sylvia
,
and
his
going
to
see
her
might
be
deferred
;
and
,
after
all
,
he
felt
that
the
wishes
of
his
masters
ought
to
be
attended
to
,
and
the
honour
of
an
invitation
to
the
private
house
of
Jeremiah
not
to
be
slighted
for
anything
short
of
a
positive
engagement
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
the
ambitious
man
of
business
existed
strongly
in
Philip
.
<EOS>
It
would
never
do
to
slight
advances
towards
the
second
great
earthly
object
in
his
life
;
one
also
on
which
the
first
depended
.
  
<EOS>
So
when
the
shop
was
closed
,
the
two
set
out
down
Bridge
Street
to
cross
the
river
to
the
house
of
Jeremiah
Foster
.
<EOS>
They
stood
a
moment
on
the
bridge
to
breathe
the
keen
fresh
sea
air
after
their
busy
day
.
<EOS>
The
waters
came
down
,
swollen
full
and
dark
,
with
rapid
rushing
speed
from
the
snow
-
fed
springs
high
up
on
the
moorland
above
.
<EOS>
The
close
-
packed
houses
in
the
old
town
seemed
a
cluster
of
white
roofs
irregularly
piled
against
the
more
unbroken
white
of
the
hill
-
side
.
<EOS>
Lights
twinkled
here
and
there
in
the
town
,
and
were
slung
from
stern
and
bow
of
the
ships
in
the
harbour
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
very
still
,
settling
in
for
a
frost
;
so
still
that
all
distant
sounds
seemed
near
:
the
rumble
of
a
returning
cart
in
the
High
Street
,
the
voices
on
board
ship
,
the
closing
of
shutters
and
barring
of
doors
in
the
new
town
to
which
they
were
bound
.
<EOS>
But
the
sharp
air
was
filled
,
as
it
were
,
with
saline
particles
in
a
freezing
state
;
little
pungent
crystals
of
sea
salt
burning
lips
and
cheeks
with
their
cold
keenness
.
<EOS>
It
would
not
do
to
linger
here
in
the
very
centre
of
the
valley
up
which
passed
the
current
of
atmosphere
coming
straight
with
the
rushing
tide
from
the
icy
northern
seas
.
<EOS>
Besides
,
there
was
the
unusual
honour
of
a
supper
with
Jeremiah
Foster
awaiting
them
.
<EOS>
He
had
asked
each
of
them
separately
to
a
meal
before
now
;
but
they
had
never
gone
together
,
and
they
felt
that
there
was
something
serious
in
the
conjuncture
.
  
<EOS>
They
began
to
climb
the
steep
heights
leading
to
the
freshly
-
built
rows
of
the
new
town
of
Monkshaven
,
feeling
as
if
they
were
rising
into
aristocratic
regions
where
no
shop
profaned
the
streets
.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
Foster
's
house
was
one
of
six
,
undistinguished
in
size
,
or
shape
,
or
colour
;
but
noticed
in
the
daytime
by
all
passers
-
by
for
its
spotless
cleanliness
of
lintel
and
doorstep
,
window
and
window
frame
.
<EOS>
The
very
bricks
seemed
as
though
they
came
in
for
the
daily
scrubbing
which
brightened
handle
,
knocker
,
all
down
to
the
very
scraper
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
young
men
felt
as
shy
of
the
interview
with
their
master
under
such
unusual
relations
of
guest
and
host
,
as
a
girl
does
of
her
first
party
.
<EOS>
Each
rather
drew
back
from
the
decided
step
of
knocking
at
the
door
;
but
with
a
rebuffing
shake
at
his
own
folly
,
Philip
was
the
one
to
give
a
loud
single
rap
.
<EOS>
As
if
they
had
been
waited
for
,
the
door
flew
open
,
and
a
middle
-
aged
servant
stood
behind
,
as
spotless
and
neat
as
the
house
itself
;
and
smiled
a
welcome
to
the
familiar
faces
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
dust
yo
'
a
bit
,
William
,
"
said
she
,
suiting
the
action
to
the
word
.
<EOS>
"
You
've
been
leanin
'
again
some
whitewash
,
a'll
be
bound
.
<EOS>
Ay
,
Philip
,
"
continued
she
,
turning
him
round
with
motherly
freedom
,
"
yo'll
do
if
yo'll
but
gi
<EOS>
'
your
shoon
a
polishin
'
wipe
on
yon
other
mat
.
<EOS>
This'n
for
takin
'
t
'
roughest
mud
off
.
<EOS>
Measter
allays
polishes
on
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
the
square
parlour
the
same
precise
order
was
observed
.
<EOS>
Every
article
of
furniture
was
free
from
speck
of
dirt
or
particle
of
dust
;
and
everything
was
placed
either
in
a
parallel
line
,
or
at
exact
right
-
angles
with
every
other
.
<EOS>
Even
John
and
Jeremiah
sat
in
symmetry
on
opposite
sides
of
the
fire
-
place
;
the
very
smiles
on
their
honest
faces
seemed
drawn
to
a
line
of
exactitude
.
  
<EOS>
Such
formality
,
however
admirable
,
was
not
calculated
to
promote
ease
:
it
was
not
until
after
supper
 
until
a
good
quantity
of
Yorkshire
pie
had
been
swallowed
,
and
washed
down
,
too
,
with
the
best
and
most
generous
wine
in
Jeremiah
's
cellar
 
that
there
was
the
least
geniality
among
them
,
in
spite
of
the
friendly
kindness
of
the
host
and
his
brother
.
<EOS>
The
long
silence
,
during
which
mute
thanks
for
the
meal
were
given
,
having
come
to
an
end
,
Jeremiah
called
for
pipes
,
and
three
of
the
party
began
to
smoke
.
  
<EOS>
Politics
in
those
days
were
tickle
subjects
to
meddle
with
,
even
in
the
most
private
company
.
<EOS>
The
nation
was
in
a
state
of
terror
against
France
,
and
against
any
at
home
who
might
be
supposed
to
sympathise
with
the
enormities
she
had
just
been
committing
.
<EOS>
The
oppressive
act
against
seditious
meetings
had
been
passed
the
year
before
;
and
people
were
doubtful
to
what
extremity
of
severity
it
might
be
construed
.
<EOS>
Even
the
law
authorities
forgot
to
be
impartial
,
but
either
their
alarms
or
their
interests
made
too
many
of
them
vehement
partisans
instead
of
calm
arbiters
,
and
thus
destroyed
the
popular
confidence
in
what
should
have
been
considered
the
supreme
tribunal
of
justice
.
<EOS>
Yet
for
all
this
,
there
were
some
who
dared
to
speak
of
reform
of
Parliament
,
as
a
preliminary
step
to
fair
representation
of
the
people
,
and
to
a
reduction
of
the
heavy
war
-
taxation
that
was
imminent
,
if
not
already
imposed
.
<EOS>
But
these
pioneers
of
1830
were
generally
obnoxious
.
<EOS>
The
great
body
of
the
people
gloried
in
being
Tories
and
haters
of
the
French
,
with
whom
they
were
on
tenter
-
hooks
to
fight
,
almost
unaware
of
the
rising
reputation
of
the
young
Corsican
warrior
,
whose
name
would
be
used
ere
<EOS>
a
dozen
years
had
passed
to
hush
English
babies
with
a
terror
such
as
that
of
Marlborough
once
had
for
the
French
.
  
<EOS>
At
such
a
place
as
Monkshaven
all
these
opinions
were
held
in
excess
.
<EOS>
One
or
two
might
,
for
the
mere
sake
of
argument
,
dispute
on
certain
points
of
history
or
government
;
but
they
took
care
to
be
very
sure
of
their
listeners
before
such
arguments
touched
on
anything
of
the
present
day
;
for
it
had
been
not
unfrequently
found
that
the
public
duty
of
prosecuting
opinions
not
your
own
overrode
the
private
duty
of
respecting
confidence
.
<EOS>
Most
of
the
Monkshaven
politicians
confined
themselves
,
therefore
,
to
such
general
questions
as
these
:
"
Could
an
Englishman
lick
more
than
four
Frenchmen
at
a
time
?
"
<EOS>
"
What
was
the
proper
punishment
for
members
of
the
Corresponding
Society
(
correspondence
with
the
French
directory
)
,
hanging
and
quartering
,
or
burning
?
"
<EOS>
"
Would
the
forthcoming
child
of
the
Princess
of
Wales
be
a
boy
or
a
girl
?
<EOS>
If
a
girl
,
would
it
be
more
loyal
to
call
it
Charlotte
or
Elizabeth
?
"
  
<EOS>
The
Fosters
were
quite
secure
enough
of
their
guests
this
evening
to
have
spoken
freely
on
politics
had
they
been
so
inclined
.
<EOS>
And
they
did
begin
on
the
outrages
which
had
been
lately
offered
to
the
king
in
crossing
St
James
's
Park
to
go
and
open
the
House
of
Lords
;
but
soon
,
so
accustomed
were
their
minds
to
caution
and
restraint
,
the
talk
dropped
down
to
the
high
price
of
provisions
.
<EOS>
Bread
at
1_s
_
.
<EOS>
3_d
<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
the
quartern
loaf
,
according
to
the
London
test
.
<EOS>
Wheat
at
120_s
<EOS>
_
.
<EOS>
per
quarter
,
as
the
home
-
baking
northerners
viewed
the
matter
;
and
then
the
conversation
died
away
to
an
ominous
silence
.
<EOS>
John
looked
at
Jeremiah
,
as
if
asking
him
to
begin
.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
was
the
host
,
and
had
been
a
married
man
.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
returned
the
look
with
the
same
meaning
in
it
.
<EOS>
John
,
though
a
bachelor
,
was
the
elder
brother
.
<EOS>
The
great
church
bell
,
brought
from
the
Monkshaven
monastery
centuries
ago
,
high
up
on
the
opposite
hill
-
side
,
began
to
ring
nine
o'clock
;
it
was
getting
late
.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
began
:
  
"
It
seems
a
bad
time
for
starting
any

on

<EOS>
A
DIFFICULT
QUESTION
  
<EOS>
Philip
went
to
bed
with
that
kind
of
humble
penitent
gratitude
in
his
heart
,
which
we
sometimes
feel
after
a
sudden
revulsion
of
feeling
from

.
<EOS>
The
night
before
it
seemed
as
if
all
events
were
so
arranged
as
to
thwart
him
in
his

;

now

his

,

,

,
<EOS>
so

.
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>

Kinraid

not

another

(
for

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

;
but
he

which
,
when

,

.
<EOS>
And
that

and

,

.

<EOS>
THE
ENGAGEMENT
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
As
the
day
lengthens
so
the
cold
strengthens
.
<EOS>
"
It
was
so
that
year
;
the
hard
frost
which
began
on
new
year
's
eve
lasted
on
and
on
into
late

,
black
and

,
but

to

,

too

of

-

,
and

of

.
<EOS>
But

did
not

as

,

Bell
Robson
,
though
not

worse
,
did

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
was
kept
very

,
notwithstanding
that
she
had

of
a
poor

-

in
the

on

,
or

.
<EOS>
Her

was
quiet
and

,
although
hard
-
working
;
and
while
her
hands
mechanically
found
and
did
their

,

that
rose
in
her

always
centred
on
Charley
Kinraid
,
his
ways
,
his
words
,
his
looks
,
whether
they
all
meant
what
she
would
fain
believe
they
did
,
and
whether
,
meaning
love

time
,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Philip

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

a
door
was
unbolted
,
and
Sylvia
said
,
  
"
I
ca
n't
come
down
again
.
<EOS>
I
'm
noan
comin
'
down

-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Daniel

more

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hearken
how
she
's

her

.
<EOS>
She
'll
noane
come
near

this

.
<EOS>
Eh
!
<EOS>
but
she
's
a
stiff
little
'
un
;
she
's

our

,

.
<EOS>
But

;

that

is
as

as
iver
a
woman

.
"
    
<EOS>
REJECTED
WARNINGS
  
<EOS>
The
post
arrived
at
Monkshaven
three
times
in
the
week
;
sometimes
,
indeed
,
there
were
not
a
dozen
letters
in
the
bag
,
which
was
brought
thither
by
a
man
in
a
light
mail
-
cart
,
who
took
the
better
part
of
a
day
to
drive
from
York
;
dropping
private
bags
here
and
there
on
the
moors
,
at
some
squire
's
lodge
or
roadside
inn
.
<EOS>
Of
the
number
of
letters
that
arrived
in
Monkshaven
,
the
Fosters
,
shopkeepers
and
bankers
,
had
the
largest
share
.
  
<EOS>
The
morning
succeeding
the
day
on
which
Sylvia
had
engaged
herself
to
Kinraid
,
the
Fosters
seemed
unusually
anxious
to
obtain
their
letters
.
<EOS>
Several
times
Jeremiah
came
out
of
the
parlour
in
which
his
brother
John
was
sitting
in
expectant

,
and
,
passing
through
the
shop
,
looked
up
and
down
the
market
-
place
in
search
of
the
old
lame
woman
,
who
was
charitably
employed
to
deliver
letters
,
and
who
must
have
been
lamer
than
ever
this
morning
,
to
judge
from
the
lateness
of
her
coming
.
<EOS>
Although
none
but
the
Fosters
knew
the
cause
of
their
impatience
for
their
letters
,
yet
there
was
such

between

and
those

,
that
Hepburn
,

,
and
Hester

when
the
old

at
length
appeared

letters
.
  
<EOS>
One
of
these
seemed
of
especial
consequence
to
the
good
brothers
.
<EOS>
They
each
separately
looked
at
the
direction
,
and
then
at
one
another
;
and
without
a
word
they
returned
with
it
unread
into
the
parlour
,
shutting
the
door
,
and
drawing
the
green
silk
curtain
close
,
the
better
to
read

in
privacy
.
  
<EOS>
Both
Coulson
and
Philip
felt
that
something
unusual
was
going
on
,
and
were
,
perhaps
,
as
full
of
consideration
as
to
the
possible
contents
of
this
London
letter
,
as
of
attention
to
their
more

business
.
<EOS>
But
fortunately
there
was
little
doing
in

shop
.
<EOS>
Philip
,
indeed
,
was
quite
idle
when
John
Foster
opened
the
parlour
-
door
,
and
,
half

,
called

into
the
room
.
<EOS>
As
the
door
of
communication
shut
the
three
in
,
Coulson
felt
himself
a
little
aggrieved
.
<EOS>
A
minute
ago
Philip
<EOS>
and
he
were
on
a
level
of
ignorance
,
from
which
the
former
was
evidently
going
to
be
raised
.
<EOS>
But
he
soon
returned
to
his
usual
state
of
acquiescence
in
things
as
they
were
,
which
was
partly

,
and

the

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
apparently
by
John
Foster
's
wish
that
Philip
had

.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
,
the
less

and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

,
John
;
better

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

's

.
  
<EOS>
It
seemed
from
his
account
to
Philip
(

what
he
,
in

)

.
<EOS>
The

this

.
<EOS>
They
had

to

his
name
in

,
and
this
morning
's
letter

;
but
the

,

.
<EOS>
Certain

mentioned

,

;
and

.
<EOS>
Probably
,

Dickinson

,

;

,

's

,
and
various

showing

of

's

.
  
<EOS>
After

,
John
had

upon
the

of
sending
Hepburn
to
London
to
make
secret

respecting
the
true

position
of
the
man
whose
creditors
,

,

had
esteemed

an
honour
to
be
.
  
<EOS>
Even

was
ashamed
of
their
want
of
confidence
in

good
;
he
believed
that

had

all

,

;

,

's

himself
that

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
As
all
this
was
being
revealed
to
Philip
,

sat

and

.
<EOS>
In

,
he
was
giving
all

,
leaving
his
own

in

till

should
have
done

.
<EOS>
He
said
little
;
but
what
he
did

was
to
the
point
,
and
satisfied

.
<EOS>
John
perceived
that
his
messenger
would
exercise
penetration
and
act
with
energy
;
while
Jeremiah
was
soothed

Philip
's

in
not

the
probability
of
any
charge
against
Dickinson
,
and
in
giving
full

to
his
previous

.
  
<EOS>
Philip
had
the
satisfaction
of
feeling

employed
on
a
mission
which
would
call
out

powers
,
and
yet

.
<EOS>
In

own

he
forestalled
the

of
his

,
and
was
silently
in

of
John

and

,
while
he
appeared
to

to

that
was
said

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
settled
that
the
next
morning
he
was
to
make

way
northwards
to
Hartlepool
<EOS>
,
whence
he
could
easily
proceed
either

to
Newcastle
,
from

place
smacks
were

to
London
.
<EOS>
As

conduct
and

,

overwhelmed

with

;

a

.
<EOS>
Philip
had
never
had
so
much
in

hands

,
and

,

;

,

,

<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
The

,

.

<EOS>

Philip

<EOS>
He

.

No

<EOS>

,

an

"
    
<EOS>
EDDY
IN
LOVE
'S
CURRENT
  
<EOS>
The
next
morning
shone
bright
and
clear
,
if
ever
a
March
morning
did
.
<EOS>
The
beguiling
month
was
coming
in
like
a
lamb
,
with
whatever
storms
it
might
go
raging
out
.
<EOS>
It
was
long
since
Philip
had
tasted
the
freshness
of
the
early
air
on
the
shore
,
or
in
the
country
,
as
his
employment
at
the
shop
detained
him
in
Monkshaven
till
the
evening
.
<EOS>
And
as
he
turned
down
the
quays
(
or
staithes
)
on
the
north
side
of
the
river
,
towards
the
shore
,
and
met
the
fresh
sea
-
breeze
blowing
right
in
his
face
,
it
was
impossible
not
to
feel
bright
and
elastic
.
<EOS>
With
his
knapsack
slung
over
his
shoulder
,
he
was
prepared
for
a
good
stretch
towards
Hartlepool
,
whence
a
coach
would
take
him
to
Newcastle
before
night
.
<EOS>
For
seven
or
eight
miles
the
level
sands
were
as
short
and
far
more
agreeable
a
road
than
the
up
and
down
land
-
ways
.
<EOS>
Philip
walked
on
pretty
briskly
,
unconsciously
enjoying
the
sunny
landscape
before
him
;
the
crisp
curling
waves
rushing
almost
up
to
his
feet
,
on
his
right
hand
,
and
then
swishing
back
over
the
fine
small
pebbles
into
the
great
swelling
sea
.
<EOS>
To
his
left
were
the
cliffs
rising
one
behind
another
,
having
deep
gullies
here
and
there
between
,
with
long
green
slopes
upward
from
the
land
,
and
then
sudden
falls
of
brown
and
red
soil
or
rock
deepening
to
a
yet
greater
richness
of
colour
at
their
base
towards
the
blue
ocean
before
him
.
<EOS>
The
loud
,
monotonous
murmur
of
the
advancing
and
receding
waters
lulled
him
into
dreaminess
;
the
sunny
look
of
everything
tinged
his
day
-
dreams
with
hope
.
<EOS>
So
he
trudged
merrily
over
the
first
mile
or
so
;
not
an
obstacle
to
his
measured
pace
on
the
hard
,
level
pavement
;
not
a
creature
to
be
seen
since
he
had
left
the
little
gathering
of
bare
-
legged
urchins
dabbling
in
the
sea
-
pools
near
Monkshaven
.
<EOS>
The
cares
of
land
were
shut
out
by
the
glorious
barrier
of
rocks
before
him
.
<EOS>
There
were
some
great
masses
that
had
been
detached
by
the
action
of
the
weather
,
and
lay
half
embedded
in
the
sand
,
draperied
over
by
the
heavy
pendent
olive
-
green
seaweed
.
<EOS>
The
waves
were
nearer
at
this
point
;
the
advancing
sea
came
up
with
a
mighty
distant
length
of
roar
;
here
and
there
the
smooth
swell
was
lashed
by
the
fret
against
unseen
rocks
into
white
breakers
;
but
otherwise
the
waves
came
up
from
the
German
Ocean
upon
that
English
shore
with
a
long
steady
roll
that
might
have
taken
its
first
impetus
far
away
,
in
the
haunt
of
the
sea
-
serpent
on
the
coast
of
"
Norroway
over
the
foam
.
<EOS>
"
The
air
was
soft
as
May
;
right
overhead
the
sky
was
blue
,
but
it
deadened
into
gray
near
the

lines
.
<EOS>
Flocks

hovered
about

edge

the
waves
,
slowly

and
turning
their
white
under

plumage
to
glimmer
in
the
sunlight
as
Philip
approached
.
<EOS>
The
whole
scene
was
so
peaceful
,
so

,
that
it
dispelled
the
cares
and
fears
(
too
well
founded
in
fact
)
which
had
weighed
down
on

during
the

of

past

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
Haytersbank
gully
opening
down
its
green

among
the
warm
brown

of
the
cliffs
.
<EOS>
Below
,
in

sheltered

,
among
the
last
year
's

,
some

might

found
.
<EOS>
He
half

of
gathering
Sylvia
a
posy
of
them
,
and
rushing

.
<EOS>
But

,

was
above
an

,
and
he
must
make
all

on
to
Hartlepool
.
<EOS>
Just

was

this

,

,
and
ran
out
some

;

left

direction
of
Hartlepool
a

Philip
.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
By

his
walk
 
by
everything
 
Philip
knew
it
was
the
specksioneer
,
Kinraid
.
  
<EOS>
Now
the
road
up
Haytersbank
gully
led
to
the
farm
,
and
nowhere
else
.
<EOS>
Still

,

<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
Philip
slackened

,

rock
.
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
Kinraid
,
walking
on
the
sunlight

,
turned
round
and
looked
long
and

Haytersbank

.
<EOS>
Hepburn
paused
when
he
paused
,
but
as

looked
at
some
object
above
,
so

.
<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
Each

now

.
<EOS>
After

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

's

something
of

would

when

should
first

lying

.
  
<EOS>
And

were

near
a

,

.
<EOS>
The

was

(
or

)
that

,
and

.
<EOS>
The

made

in

.
<EOS>
Hepburn
knew

;

,

.
<EOS>
He

;
nay

.
<EOS>
He

;
seven

.
<EOS>
Up

,

right

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
God
's

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
God
's
providence
.
"
  
<EOS>
He

down
where

and

.
<EOS>
He

,
that

of

,

.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
By

.
<EOS>
It

"
Weel

,
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Four

-

-

<EOS>
"

!
"

<EOS>
Their

;

.
<EOS>
The

was

face
.
  
<EOS>
They
knew

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Although

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

:
  
"
Avast
,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

_

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
III

,

<EOS>
"

"

Yet

<EOS>
Hepburn

not

<EOS>
Hepburn

;

rival

?
<EOS>
had

?
<EOS>
lost

his

?
<EOS>
For

Hepburn

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Philip
could
not

;

,

Kinraid
,
and
,

,
were

.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid
lay
as
still

any

:
he
rolled
when
they

;
he
suffered

to

without

,
any

;

strong

while
fighting
was
gone
now
,

was

;

,
as

,

,

.
<EOS>
His

seemed
the

that

was
going

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

,

,
and
in

in

.
  
<EOS>
Without

of

,
he
was
perceiving
and
taking

everything
while
he
lay

.
<EOS>
A

sat
by

side
,
who
had

him
.
<EOS>
The
man
held

in

,

;
but
every
now
<EOS>
and

he
revenged

by

at
the
prostrate

,
till

.
<EOS>
But
Kinraid
never

,

.
  
<EOS>
One

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

;

;
Kinraid
did

.
<EOS>
His

was

against

bars
of
inflexible
circumstance
;
reviewing
in
one

time
what

,

,

.
<EOS>
Yet

thus

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

,
where
Sylvia
must

quickly
,

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Come

,
lad
!
"

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>
Kinraid
an

,
 
Kinraid

;

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

,

to

.
  
<EOS>
Hepburn

,
as

,

.
<EOS>
His

could

four

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

;

,
and
overcome
all

others
,

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
by
no

Hepburn
's
that
the
boat

;
that

now

,

;
now

;

.
<EOS>
No

of

!
<EOS>
and

,

not
an

his

to
be

,

of
Kinraid
's

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Anyhow
,
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
God

!
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,
and
had

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

to
Hartlepool
as

he
could
.
    
<EOS>
AN
IMPORTANT
MISSION
  
<EOS>
Philip
was
too
late
for
the
coach
he
had
hoped
to
go
by
,
but
there
was
another
that
left
at
night
,
and
which
reached
Newcastle
in
the
forenoon
,
so
that
,
by
the
loss
of
a
night
's
sleep
,
he
might
overtake
his
lost
time
.
<EOS>
But
,
restless
and

,
he
could
not
stop
in
Hartlepool
longer
than
to

some

at
the
inn
from
which

coach

.
<EOS>
He
acquainted

with
the
names

,
and

at

would

,
and
left

to
be
on
the
look

out
for

and
pick

.
  
<EOS>
He
was
thoroughly

out
before
this
happened
 
too
much
tired
to
gain
any
sleep
in
the
coach
.
<EOS>
When
he

Newcastle
,
he
went
to

in
the
next
London
-
bound
smack
,
and
then
directed
his
steps
to
Robinson
's
,
in
the
Side
,
to
make
all
the

he
could
think
of
respecting
the
plough
his
uncle
wanted
to
know

.
  
<EOS>
So

was
pretty
late
in
the
afternoon
,

,
before
he
arrived
at

small

-
side
,
where

.
<EOS>
It
was
but
a
rough
kind
of
place
,
frequented
principally
by
sailors
;
he
had
been

to
it
by
Daniel
Robson
,
who
had
known

former
days
.
<EOS>
The

in
it
was
,
however
,
clean
and

,
and
the
people
keeping
it
were
respectable
enough
in
their
way
.
  
<EOS>
Still
Hepburn
was
rather
repelled
by
the
appearance
of
the
sailors
who
sate
drinking
in
the
bar
,
and
he
asked
,
in
a
low

,
if
there
was
not
another
room
.
<EOS>
The
woman
stared
in
surprise
,
and
only
shook
her
head
.
<EOS>
Hepburn
went
to
a
separate
table
,
away
from
the
roaring
fire
,
which
on
this
cold
March
evening
was
the
great
attraction
,
and
called
for
food
and

.
<EOS>
Then
seeing
that
the
other
men
were
eyeing
him
with
the
sociable
idea
of
speaking
to
him
,
he
asked
for

and
ink
and
paper
,
with
the

of
defeating
their
purpose
by
pre
-
occupation
on
his

.
<EOS>
But
when
the
paper
came
,
the
new
pen
,
the
unused
thickened
ink
,
he
hesitated
long

began

write
;
and
at
last

slowly
put
down

words
,
    
"
DEAR
AND
HONOURED
UNCLE
,
"
      
<EOS>
There
was
a
pause
;
his
meal
was
brought
and
hastily
swallowed
.
<EOS>
Even
while
he
was
eating
it
,
he
kept
occasionally
touching
up

of
these
words
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
drunk
a
glass
of
ale
<EOS>
he
began
again
to
write
:
fluently
this

,
for
he
was
giving
an

of
the

.
<EOS>
Then
came
another
long
stop
;
he
was
weighing
in

what

should

about
Kinraid
.
<EOS>
Once

thought
for
a
second
of
writing

Sylvia
herself
,
and
telling
her
   
how
much
?
<EOS>
She
might
treasure

her
lover
's
words
like

,
while
they
were

;

which
such

used

.
<EOS>
It
was
for

;
and

.
<EOS>
But
should

mention
the

Kinraid
's

to
Robson
?
<EOS>
That

the

,
remembering
that
the
last

Philip
had
seen
either
,
they
were
in

's

.
<EOS>
Twenty

of
relating

event
that
had

Kinraid
;
and
as

stopped
,

.
<EOS>
While

thus
sate

,

,
and

on
beyond
the

into

,

<EOS>
They
were
speaking
of
that

Kinraid
,
the
thought
of
whom
filled
his
own

.
<EOS>
In

rough
,

spoke
of
the
specksioneer
,
with

for
his

;
and

jesting

<EOS>
Hepburn
silently

Annie
Coulson

Robson
to

,
and
his

.
<EOS>
Long

done
speaking
about
Kinraid
,

paid

shot
,
and

away
,
he
sate
in

same

,
thinking

.
  
<EOS>
The
people
of
the
house
prepared
for
bed
.
<EOS>
Their
silent
guest
took
no
heed
of
their
mute
signs
.
<EOS>
At
length
the
landlord
spoke
to
him
,
and
he
started
,
gathered
his
wits
together
with
an

,
and
prepared
to

with

rest
.
<EOS>
But

did

,
he
signed

letter
to

,
leaving

still

,
however
,

.
<EOS>
The

his

been
writing
must

early
the

;
as

mails
in

only
left
Newcastle

.
  
<EOS>
All

Hepburn
wearied
himself
with

,

.
<EOS>
Towards

fell
into

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
It
was
broad
full

;
he
had

himself
,
and
the
smack
was
leaving
by

.
<EOS>
He
was
even
now

on
board
.
<EOS>
He
dressed
,
wafered
his
letter
,
and
rushed

to
the

;
and
,

.
<EOS>
Once

board
,
he
experienced
the

it
always
is
to
an

man
,
and
generally
is
at

to

paltering

,

.
<EOS>
In

.
  
<EOS>
And
so
Philip
sailed

.
<EOS>
It

London

,

;

<EOS>
He

<EOS>

Dickinson

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

for

heavy
postage

mere

<EOS>
as

<EOS>
That

,

.
<EOS>
With

<EOS>
When

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
But

;

.
<EOS>
Philip
heard
,

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
He

;

<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>
Naturally

<EOS>
Indeed

<EOS>
Yet

.
<EOS>
For

hear
from
Robson
,
although

.
<EOS>
But
we
often

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Hepburn
's

was
the

;

in

of

.
  
<EOS>
And

,
curt
,
yet

;

Priory

,

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

_

voce

_

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Weary

,

what
he
had
done
and
seen
in
London
,
as
far
as
he
could
without
breaking
confidence
with
his
employers
.
<EOS>
It
was
something
to
see
the
pleasure
he
gave
to
his
auditors
,
although
there
were
several
mixed
feelings
in
their
minds
to
produce
the
expression
of
it
which
gratified

.
<EOS>
Coulson
was
sorry
for
his
former
ungenerous
reception
of
the
news
that
Philip
was
going
to
London
;
Hester
and
her
mother
each
secretly

feel
as
if
this

was
like
more
happy

of
old
,
before
the

came
to
Haytersbank
Farm
;
and
who
knows
what
faint

hopes
this
resemblance
may
not
have
suggested
?
  
<EOS>
While
Philip
,
restless
and
excited
,
feeling
that
he
could
not
sleep
,
was
glad
to
pass
away

that
must

before
to
-

night
,
at
times
,
he
tried
to
make

what
had

in

during
his

,
but
all
had
gone
on
in

,
as
far
as
he

;
if

of
anything
affecting
the
Robsons
,

avoided

;
and
,
indeed
,
how
little
likely
were
they
ever
to
have
heard
their

while
he
was
away
?
    
<EOS>
LOVED
AND
LOST
  
<EOS>
Philip
walked
towards
the
Robsons
'
farm
like
a
man

a
dream
,
who
has
everything

according
to
his

,
and
yet
is
conscious
of
a
secret
mysterious

.
<EOS>
Hepburn
did
not
care
to
think
 
would
not
realize
what
this
drawback
,
which
need
not
have
been
mysterious
in
his
case
,
was
.
  
<EOS>
The
May
evening
was
glorious
in
light
and
shadow
.
<EOS>
The
crimson
sun
warmed
up
the
chilly
northern
air
to
a
semblance
of
pleasant
heat
.
<EOS>
The
spring
sights
and
sounds
were
all
about
;
the
lambs
were
bleating
out
their
gentle
weariness
before
they
sank
to
rest
by
the
side
of
their
mothers
;
the
linnets
were
chirping
in
every
bush
of
golden
gorse
that
grew
out
of
the
stone
walls
;
the
lark
was
singing
her
good
-
night
in
the
cloudless
sky
,
before
she
dropped
down
to
her
nest
in
the
tender
green
wheat
;
all
spoke
of
brooding
peace
 
but
Philip
's
heart
was
not
at
peace
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
he
was
going
to
proclaim
his
good
fortune
.
<EOS>
His
masters
had
that
day
publicly

that
Coulson
and

were
to
be
their
successors
,
and
he
had
now

in

,
when
he
had
resolved
to
openly
speak

his
love
to
Sylvia
,
and
might

to
gain

.
<EOS>
But
,
alas
!
<EOS>
the

had
lagged

.
<EOS>
He
was
placed
as
far

he
could
,
even

,
have

be
as
regarded
business
,

was
as

as
ever
 
nay
,

.
<EOS>
Still

.
<EOS>
Philip

to

.
<EOS>

just

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>
There

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Robson

<EOS>
A
REJECTED

<EOS>
There

.

,

which

Rose

;

,

.

,

.

.
<EOS>
Why
,

,

,

;

.

.

Coulson

;

.
    
<EOS>
DEEPENING
SHADOWS
  
<EOS>
But

happened
 
small

Philip
.
<EOS>
To

as

.
<EOS>
The

up
<EOS>
and

,

he

there
 
<EOS>
these

.
  
<EOS>
From
her
parents
he
always

a

.
<EOS>
Oppressed

daughter
's

,

any

.
<EOS>
The

in

,
owing
to
Bessy
Corney

out

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

;

.
<EOS>
Before

.
<EOS>
And

;

had
he

many
a

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

_

_
<EOS>

<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
He

present
,
and
apt

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

;
but
he

.
<EOS>
With

many

,
however
,
he
had
something

which
made

dearly

,
both

daughter
whom
he

,
and
the
wife
who
was
in
fact

him
,
but
whom
he
imagined
that
he
ruled
with

wise

sway
.
  
<EOS>
Love
to
Sylvia
gave
Philip
tact
.
<EOS>
He
seemed
to
find
out
that
to
please
the
women
of
the
household
he
must
pay
all
possible
attention
to
the
man
;
and
though
he
cared
little
in
comparison
for
Daniel
,
yet
this
autumn
he
was
continually
thinking
of
how
he
could
please
him
.
<EOS>
When
he
had
said
or
done
anything
to
gratify
or

her
father
,
Sylvia
smiled
and
was
kind
.
<EOS>
Whatever
he
did
was
right
with
his
aunt
;
but
even
she
was
unusually
glad
when
her
husband
was
pleased
.
<EOS>
Still
his
progress
was
slow
towards
his
object
;
and
often
he
sighed
himself
to
sleep
with
the
words
,
"
seven
years
,
and
maybe
seven
years
more
"
.
<EOS>
Then
in
his
dreams
he
saw
Kinraid
again
,
sometimes
struggling
,
sometimes
sailing
towards
land
,
<EOS>
the
only
one
on
board
a
swift
advancing
ship
,
alone
on
deck
,
stern
and
avenging
;
till
Philip
awoke
in
remorseful
terror
.
  
<EOS>
Such
and
similar
dreams
returned
with
the
greater
frequency
when
,
in
the
November
of
that
year
,
the
coast
between
Hartlepool
and
Monkshaven
was
overshadowed
by
the
presence
of
guard
-
ships
,
driven
south
from
their
station
at
North
Shields
by
the
resolution
which
the
sailors
of
that
port
had
entered
into
to
resist
the
press
-
gang
,
and
the
energy
with
which
they
had
begun
to
carry
out
their
determination
.
<EOS>
For
on
a
certain
Tuesday
evening
yet
remembered
by
old
inhabitants
of
North
Shields
,
the
sailors
in
the
merchant
service
met
together
and
overpowered
the
press
-
gang
,
dismissing
them
from
the
town
with
the
highest
contempt
,
and
with
their
jackets
reversed
.
<EOS>
A
numerous
mob
went
with
them
to
Chirton
Bar
;
gave
them
three
cheers
at
parting
,
but
vowed
to
tear
them
limb
from
limb
<EOS>
should
they
seek
to
re
-
enter
North
Shields
.
<EOS>
But
a
few
days
afterwards
some
fresh
cause
of
irritation
arose
,
and
five
hundred
sailors
,
armed
with
such
swords
and
pistols
as
they
could
collect
,
paraded
through
the
town
in
the
most
riotous
manner
,
and
at
last
attempted
to
seize
the
tender
Eleanor
,
on
some
pretext
of
the
ill
-
treatment
of
the
impressed
men
aboard
.
<EOS>
This
endeavour
failed
,
however
,
owing
to
the
energetic
conduct
of
the
officers
in
command
.
<EOS>
Next
day
this
body
of
sailors
set
off
for
Newcastle
;
but
learning
,
before
they
reached
the
town
,
that
there
was
a
strong
military
and
civil
force
prepared
to
receive
them
there
,
they
dispersed
for
the
time
;
but
not
before
the
good
citizens
had
received
a
great
fright
,
the
drums
of
the
North
Yorkshire
militia
beating
to
arms
,
and
the
terrified
people
rushing
out
into
the
streets
to
learn
the
reason
of
the
alarm
,
and
some
of
them
seeing
the
militia
,
under
the
command
of
the
Earl
of
Fauconberg
,
marching
from
the
guard
-
house
adjoining
New
Gate
to
the
house
of
rendezvous
for
impressed
seamen
in
the
Broad
Chase
.
  
<EOS>
But
a
few
weeks
after
,
the
impressment
service
took
their
revenge
for
the
insults
they
had
been
subjected
to
in
North
Shields
.
<EOS>
In
the
dead
of
night
a
cordon
was
formed
round
that
town
by
a
regiment
stationed
at
Tynemouth
barracks
;
the
press
-
gangs
belonging
to
armed
vessels
lying
off
Shields
harbour
were
let
loose
;
no
one
within
the
circle
could
escape
,
and
upwards
of
two
hundred
and
fifty
men
,
sailors
,
mechanics
,
labourers
of
every
description
,
were
forced
on
board
the
armed
ships
.
<EOS>
With
that
prize
they
set
sail
,
and
wisely
left
the
place
,
where
deep
passionate
vengeance
was
sworn
against
them
.
<EOS>
Not
all
the
dread
of
an
invasion
by
the
French
could
reconcile
the
people
of
these
coasts
to
the
necessity
of
impressment
.
<EOS>
Fear
and
confusion
prevailed
after
this
to
within
many
miles
of
the
sea
-
shore
.
<EOS>
A
Yorkshire
gentleman
of
rank
said
that
his
labourers
dispersed
like
a
covey
of
birds
,
because
a
press
-
gang
was
reported
to
have
established
itself
so
far
inland
as
Tadcaster
;
and
they
only
returned
to
work
on
the
assurance
from
the
steward
of
his
master
's
protection
,
but
even
then
begged
leave
to
sleep
on
straw
in
the
stables
or
outhouses
belonging
to
their
landlord
,
not
daring
to
sleep
at
their
own
homes
.
<EOS>
No
fish
was
caught
,
for
the
fishermen
dared
not
venture
out
to
sea
;
the
markets
were
deserted
,
as
the
press
-
gangs
might
come
down
on
any
gathering
of
men
;
prices
were
raised
,
and
many
were
impoverished
;
many
others
ruined
.
<EOS>
For
in
the
great
struggle
in
which
England
was
then
involved
,
the
navy
was
esteemed
her
safeguard
;
and
men
must
be
had
at
any
price
of
money
,
or
suffering
,
or
of
injustice
.
<EOS>
Landsmen
were
kidnapped
and
taken
to
London
;
there
,
in
too
many
instances
,
to
be
discharged
without
redress
and
penniless
,
because
they
were
discovered
to
be
useless
for
the
purpose
for
which
they
had
been
taken
.
  
<EOS>
Autumn
brought
back
the
whaling
-
ships
.
<EOS>
But
the
period
of
their
return
was
full
of
gloomy
anxiety
,
instead
of
its
being
the
annual
time
of
rejoicing
and
feasting
;
of
gladdened
households
,
where
brave
steady
husbands
or
sons
returned
;
of
unlimited
and
reckless
expenditure
,
and
boisterous
joviality
among
those
who
thought
that
they
had
earned
unbounded
licence
on
shore
by
their
six
months
of
compelled
abstinence
.
<EOS>
In
other
years
this
had
been
the
time
for
new
and
handsome
winter
clothing
;
for
cheerful
if
humble
hospitality
;
for
the
shopkeepers
to
display
their
gayest
and
best
;
for
the
public
-
houses
to
be
crowded
;
for
the
streets
to
be
full
of
blue
jackets
,
rolling
along
with
merry
words
and
open
hearts
.
<EOS>
In
other
years
the
boiling
-
houses
had
been
full
of
active
workers
,
the
staithes
crowded
with
barrels
,
the
ship
-
carpenters
'
yards
thronged
with
seamen
and
captains
;
now
a
few
men
,
tempted
by
high
wages
,
went
stealthily
by
back
lanes
to
their
work
,
clustering
together
,
with
sinister
looks
,
glancing
round
corners
,
and
fearful
of
every
approaching
footstep
,
as
if
they
were
going
on
some
unlawful
business
,
instead
of
true
honest
work
.
<EOS>
Most
of
them
kept
their
whaling
-
knives
about
them
ready
for
bloody
defence
if
they
were
attacked
.
<EOS>
The
shops
were
almost
deserted
;
there
was
no
unnecessary
expenditure
by
the
men
;
they
dared
not
venture
out
to
buy
lavish
presents
for
the
wife
or
sweetheart
or
little
children
.
<EOS>
The
public
-
houses
kept
scouts
on
the
look
-
out
;
while
fierce
men
drank
and
swore
deep
oaths
of
vengeance
in
the
bar
 
men
who
did
not
maunder
in
their
cups
,
nor
grow
foolishly
merry
,
but
in
whom
liquor
called
forth
all
the
desperate
,
bad
passions
of
human
nature
.
  
<EOS>
Indeed
,
all
along
the
coast
of
Yorkshire
,
it
seemed
as
if
a
blight
hung
over
the
land
and
the
people
.
<EOS>
Men
dodged
about
their
daily
business
with
hatred
and
suspicion
in
their
eyes
,
and
many
a
curse
went
over
the
sea
to
the
three
fatal
ships
lying
motionless
at
anchor
three
miles
off
Monkshaven
.
<EOS>
When
first
Philip
had
heard
in
his
shop
that
these
three
men
-
of
-
war
might
be
seen
lying
fell
and
still
on
the
gray

,
his
heart

,
and
he
scarcely

to
ask

names
.
<EOS>
For
if
one
should
be
the
_
Alcestis
_
;
if
Kinraid
should
send
word
to
Sylvia
;

he
should

he
was
living
,
and

,
and

;

sent

her

through
Philip

:
what

,
not

<EOS>
that
,
of

,
would
be
hopeless
 
but
in
her

?
<EOS>
All

vanished
;
the
fear

detection
awakened
Philip
to
a

;
and
,

,
he

,
that
,

,
he

believing
that
Kinraid
was
in

when
he

,
and

that
they
might
be
borne

.
<EOS>
Some

told
Philip
that
if
the
specksioneer
had
only

with
too
many
,
yet
that

Sylvia
Robson
his

was
true

.
<EOS>
Then
Philip
tried

himself
that
,
from
all
that
was
said
of

character
,
Kinraid

an

;
and

,

_

.
  
<EOS>
Then

<EOS>
She

,

,

<EOS>
;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
she
might

in
battle
before
now
,
and
if
so
      
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
<EOS>
Yet

press

;

talked
about

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

was
a

very
difficult
of

,
for
Daniel
Robson
was
,
as
his
wife
said
,
like
one
possessed
.
<EOS>
He
could
hardly
think
of
anything
else
,
though
he
himself
was
occasionally
weary
of
the
same
constantly
recurring
idea
,
and
would
fain
have
banished
it
from
his
mind
.
<EOS>
He
was
too
old
a
man
to
be
likely
to
be
taken
by
them
;
he
had
no
son
to
become
their
victim
;
but
the
terror
of
them
,
which
he
had
braved
and
defied
in
his
youth
,
seemed
to
come
back
and
take
possession
of
him
in
his
age
;
and
with
the
terror
came
impatient
hatred
.
<EOS>
Since
his
wife
's
illness
the
previous
winter
he
had
been
a
more
sober
man
until
now
.
<EOS>
He
was
never
exactly
drunk
,
for
he
had
a
strong
,
well
-
seasoned
head
;
but
the
craving
to
hear
the
last
news
of
the
actions
of
the
press
-
gang
drew
him
into
Monkshaven
nearly
every
day
at
this
dead
agricultural
season
of
the
year
;
and
a
public
-
house
is
generally
the
focus
from
which
gossip
radiates
;
and
probably
the
amount
of
drink
thus
consumed
weakened
Robson
's
power
over
his
mind
,
and
caused
the
concentration
of
thought
on
one
subject
.
<EOS>
This
may
be
a
physiological
explanation
of
what
afterwards
was
spoken
of
as
a
supernatural
kind
of
possession
,
leading
him
to
his
doom
.
    
<EOS>
RETALIATION
  
<EOS>
The
public
-
house
that
had
been
chosen
by
the
leaders
of
the
press
-
gang
in
Monkshaven
at
this
time
,
for
their
rendezvous
(
or
"
Randyvowse
"
,
as
it
was
generally
pronounced
)
,
was
an
inn
of
poor
repute
,
with
a
yard
at
the
back
which
opened
on
to
the
staithe
or
quay
nearest
to
the
open
sea
.
<EOS>
A
strong
high
stone
wall
bounded
this
grass
-
grown
mouldy
yard
on
two
sides
;
the
house
,
and
some
unused
out
-
buildings
,
formed
the
other
two
.
<EOS>
The
choice
of
the
place
was
good
enough
,
both
as
to
situation
,
which
was
sufficiently
isolated
,
and
yet
near
to
the
widening
river
;
and
as
to
the
character
of
the
landlord
,
John
Hobbs
was
a
failing
man
,
one
who
seemed
as
if
doomed
to
be
unfortunate
in
all
his
undertakings
,
and
<EOS>
the
consequence
of
all
this
was
that
he
was
envious
of
the
more
prosperous
,
and
willing
to
do
anything
that
might
bring
him
in
a
little
present
success
in
life
.
<EOS>
His
household
consisted
of
his
wife
,
her
niece
,
who
acted
as
servant
,
and
an
out
-
of
-
doors
man
,
a
brother
of
Ned
Simpson
,
the
well
-
doing
butcher
,
who
at
one
time
had
had
a
fancy
for
Sylvia
.
<EOS>
But
the
one
brother
was
prosperous
,
the
other
had
gone
on
sinking
in
life
,
like
him
who
was
now
his
master
.
<EOS>
Neither
Hobbs
nor
his
man
Simpson
were
absolutely
bad
men
;
if
things
had
gone
well
with
them
they
might
each
have
been
as
scrupulous
and
conscientious
as
their
neighbours
,
and
even
now
,
supposing
the
gain
in
money
to
be
equal
,
they
would
sooner
have
done
good
than
evil
;
but
a
very
small
sum
was
enough
to
turn
the
balance
.
<EOS>
And
in
a
greater
degree
than
in
most
cases
was
the
famous
maxim
of
Rochefoucault
true
with
them
;
for
in
the
misfortunes
of
their
friends
they
seemed
to
see
some
justification
of
their
own
.
<EOS>
It
was
blind
fate
dealing
out
events
,
not
that
the
events
themselves
were
the
inevitable

of

.
<EOS>
To
such

as

the
large

press
-

the
Mariners

.
<EOS>
The
best

in

of

of

,

,

<EOS>
If

,

.
<EOS>
As

was
,

,

;
no
,

.
  
<EOS>
Every

.
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
But

;

,

,

<EOS>
One
night

<EOS>

fierce
and
now
yelling
crowd
who
rushed
against
them
with
the
force
of
a
battering
-
ram
,
to
recoil
in
baffled
rage
from
the
vain
assault
.
<EOS>
No
sign
,
no
sound
from
within
,
in
that
breathless
pause
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
away
round
here
!
<EOS>
a've
found
a
way
to
t
'
back
o
'
behint
,
where
belike
it
's
not
so
well
fenced
,
"
said
Daniel
,
who
had
made
way
for
younger
and
more
powerful
men
to
conduct
the
assault
,
and
had
employed
his
time
meanwhile
in
examining
the
back
premises
.
<EOS>
The
men
rushed
after
him
,
almost
knocking
him
down
,
as
he
made
his
way
into
the
lane
into
which
the
doors
of
the
outbuildings
belonging
to
the
inn
opened
.
<EOS>
Daniel
had
already
broken
the
fastening
of
that
which
opened
into
a
damp
,
mouldy
-
smelling
shippen
,
in
one
corner
of
which
a
poor
lean
cow
shifted
herself
on
her
legs
,
in
an
uneasy
,
restless
manner
,
as
her
sleeping
-
place
was
invaded
by
as
many
men
as
could
cram
themselves
into
the
dark
hold
.
<EOS>
Daniel
,
at
the
end
farthest
from
the
door
,
was
almost
smothered
before
he
could
break
down
the
rotten
wooden
shutter
,
that
,
when
opened
,
displayed
the
weedy
yard
of
the
old
inn
,
the
full
clear
light
defining
the
outline
of
each
blade
of
grass
by
the
delicate
black
shadow
behind
.
  
<EOS>
This
hole
,
used
to
give
air
and
light
to
what
had
once
been
a
stable
,
in
the
days
when
horse
travellers
were
in
the
habit
of
coming
to
the
Mariners
'
Arms
,
was
large
enough
to
admit
the
passage
of
a
man
;
and
Daniel
,
in
virtue
of
its
discovery
,
was
the
first
to
get
through
.
<EOS>
But
he
was
larger
and
heavier
than
he
had
been
;
his
lameness
made
him
less
agile
,
and
the
impatient
crowd
behind
him
gave
him
a
helping
push
that
sent
him
down
on
the
round
stones
with
which
the
yard
was
paved
,
and
for
the
time
disabled
him
so
much
that
he
could
only
just
crawl
out
of
the
way
of
leaping
feet
and
heavy
nailed
boots
,
which
came
through
the
opening
till
the
yard
was
filled
with
men
,
who
now
set
up
a
fierce
,
derisive
shout
,
which
,
to
their
delight
,
was
answered
from
within
.
<EOS>
No
more
silence
,
no
more
dead
opposition
:
a
living
struggle
,
a
glowing
,
raging
fight
;
and
Daniel
thought
he
should
be
obliged
to
sit
there
still
,
leaning
against
the
wall
,
inactive
,
while
the
strife
and
the
action
were
going
on
in
which
he
had
once
been
foremost
.
  
<EOS>
He
saw
the
stones
torn
up
;
he
saw
them
used
with
good
effect
on
the
unguarded
back
-
door
;
he
cried
out
in
useless
warning
as
he
saw
the
upper
windows
open
,
and
aim
taken
among
the
crowd
;
but
just
then
the
door
gave
way
,
and
there
was
an
involuntary
forward
motion
in
the
throng
,
so
that
no
one
was
so
disabled
by
the
shots
as
to
prevent
his
forcing
his
way
in
with
the
rest
.
<EOS>
And
now

sounds
came
veiled
by

walls
as
of
some
raging
ravening
beast
growling
over
his
prey
;
the
noise
came
and
went
 
once

;
and
Daniel
raised

ascertain

,
when
again

came
clear

,
and

into
the
yard

,
shouting
and

over
the
rescued

of
the
press
-
gang
.
<EOS>
Daniel
hobbled
up
,
and
shouted
,
and
rejoiced
,
and
shook
hands
with
the
rest
,
hardly

that
the
lieutenant
and

had
quitted

house
by

,
and
that

had
poured
out
in

;
the
greater

,
however
,

to
liberate

,
and
then
glut

on
the

and

.
  
<EOS>
From
all
the
windows
,
upper
and
lower
,
furniture
was
now
being

into
the
yard
.
<EOS>
The

of

,
the
heavier

of

,
the

,

,
the

,
all

Daniel
to
the
utmost
;
<EOS>
and
,
forgetting
his
bruises
,
he
pressed
forwards
to
lend
a
helping
hand
.
<EOS>
The
wild
,
rough
success
of
his
scheme
almost
turned

head
.
<EOS>
He
hurraed
at
every
flagrant
piece
of

;
he
shook

with
every

,
and
,
at
last
,
<EOS>
when
the

inside

,
    
"
If
a

a'd

.

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Then

.

.
<EOS>
The

,

"

,

,

.

<EOS>
Daniel

and

.
<EOS>
"

o

'

'
a

"
    
<EOS>
BRIEF
REJOICING
  
<EOS>
Daniel
's
unusually
late
absence
from
home
disturbed
Bell
and
Sylvia
not
a
little
.
<EOS>
He
was
generally
at
home
between
eight
and
nine
on
market
days
.
<EOS>
They
expected
to
see
him
the
worse
for
liquor
at
such
times
;
but
this
did
not
shock
them
;
he
was
no
worse
than
most
of
his
neighbours
,
indeed
better
than
several
,
who
went
off
once
or
twice
a
year
,
or
even
oftener
,
on
drinking
bouts
of
two
or
three
days
'
duration
,
returning
pale
,
sodden
,
and
somewhat
shame
-
faced
,
when
all
their
money
was
gone
;
and
,
after
the
conjugal
reception
was
well
over
,
settling
down
into
hard
-
working
and
decently
sober
men
until
the
temptation
again
got
power
over
them
.
<EOS>
But
,
on
market
days
,
every
man
drank
more
than
usual
;
every
bargain
or
agreement
was
ratified
by
drink
;
they
came
from
greater
or
less
distances
,
either
afoot
or
on
horseback
,
and
the
"
good
accommodation
for
man
and
beast
"
(
as
the
old
inn
-
signs
expressed
it
)
<EOS>
always
included
a
considerable
amount
of
liquor
to
be
drunk
by
the
man
.
  
<EOS>
Daniel
's
way
of
announcing
his
intention
of
drinking
more
than
ordinary
was
always
the
same
.
<EOS>
He
would
say

,
"
Missus
,
I
've
a
mind
to
get
fuddled
to
-
neet
,
"
and

her

little

to

or

.
  
<EOS>
But

had

.
<EOS>
Bell
and

put
the
candle
on
the
low
window

at
the
usual

to

fields
 
<EOS>
it

a
habit

this
 
and

,
<EOS>
so
secure

of

.
<EOS>
Bell

,

thinking

of

whatsoever

<EOS>

and

,
kept
wistfully
looking

the
other
,
desirous
of

on
the

,
which
had

.
<EOS>
She

some

,

's

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Kester

.
<EOS>
Bell

,

.
    
<EOS>
COMING
<EOS>
TROUBLES
  
<EOS>
The
morning
brought
more
peace
if
it
did
not
entirely
dissipate
fear
.
<EOS>
Daniel
seemed
to
have
got
over
his
irritability
,
and
was
unusually
kind
and
tender
to
wife
and
daughter
,
especially
striving
by
silent
little
deeds
to
make
up
for
the
sharp
words
he
had
said
the
night
before
to
the
latter
.
  
<EOS>
As
if
by
common
consent
,
all
allusion
to
the
Saturday
night
's
proceedings
was
avoided
.
<EOS>
They
spoke
of
the
day
's
work
before
them
;
of
the
crops
to
be
sown
;
of
the
cattle
;
of
the
markets
;
but
each
one
was
conscious
of
a
wish
to
know
more
distinctly
what
were
the
chances
of
the
danger
that
,
to
judge
from
Philip
's
words
,
hung
over
them
,
falling
upon
them
and
cutting
them
off
from
all
these
places
for
the
coming
days
.
  
<EOS>
Bell
longed
to
send
Kester
down
into
Monkshaven
as
a
sort
of
spy
to
see
how
the
land
lay
;
but
she
dared
not
manifest
her
anxiety
to
her
husband
,
and
could
not
see
Kester
alone
.
<EOS>
She
wished
that
she
had
told
him
to
go
to
the
town
,
when
she
had
had
him
to
herself
in
the
house
-
place
the
night
before
;
now
it
seemed
as
though
Daniel
were
resolved
not
to
part
from
him
,
and
as
though
both
had
forgotten
that
any
peril
had
been

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
and
her
mother
,
in
like

,

together
,
not
speaking
of
their
fears
,
yet
each
knowing
that
it
was
ever
present
in
the
other
's
mind
.
  
<EOS>
So
things
went
on
till
twelve
o'clock
 
dinner
-
time
.
<EOS>
If
at
any
time
that
morning
they
had
had
the

to
speak
together
on
the
thought
which
was

all
their
minds
,
it
is
possible
that
some
means
might
have
been
found
to
avert
the
calamity
that
was
coming
towards
them
with
swift
feet
.
<EOS>
But
among
the
uneducated
 
the
partially
educated
 
nay
,
even
the
weakly
educated
 
<EOS>
the
feeling
exists
which
prompted
the
futile
experiment
of
the
well
-
known
ostrich
.
<EOS>
They
imagine
that
,
by
closing
their
own

to
apprehended
evil
,
they
avert
it
.
<EOS>
The
expression
of
fear
is
supposed
to
accelerate
the
coming
of
its
cause
.
<EOS>
Yet
,
on
the
other
hand
,
they
shrink
from
acknowledging
the
long
continuance
of
any
blessing
,
in
the
idea
that
when
unusual
happiness
is
spoken
about
,
it
disappears
.
<EOS>
So
,
although
perpetual

of
past

present

and

are
most
common
among
this
class
,

from
embodying
apprehensions
for
the
future
in
words
,
as
if
it
then
took
shape
and
drew
near
.
  
<EOS>
They
all
four
sate

,
but

.
<EOS>
The

,

as
usual
<EOS>
;

<EOS>

!
"

<EOS>
Hester

<EOS>
A

<EOS>

<EOS>

little
journey
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
moved
away
for
this

,

,
    
"
It
's
going
to
see
feyther
:
he

.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor

Robson

<EOS>
At

to

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

's

.
<EOS>

mother

.
<EOS>

patch

an

"
he

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Philip

"

"

<EOS>
GLOOMY
DAYS
  
<EOS>
Philip
had

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
For

Donkin

.
<EOS>
Government

.
<EOS>
It
was

to
assert
authority
which
had

.
<EOS>
An
example

,
to

;

from

severe

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

,

PHILIP

.

<EOS>
Heavily

.
<EOS>
On

,

.
  
<EOS>
But

"
who

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
For

<EOS>
THE
ORDEAL
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
afternoon
of
an
April
day
in
that
same
year
,
and
the
sky
was
blue
above
,
with
little
sailing
white
clouds
catching
the
pleasant
sunlight
.
<EOS>
The
earth
in
that
northern
country
had
scarcely
yet
put
on
her
robe
of
green
.
<EOS>
The
few
trees
grew
near
brooks
running
down
from
the
moors
and
the
higher
ground
.
<EOS>
The
air
was
full
of
pleasant
sounds
prophesying
of
the
coming
summer
.
<EOS>
The
rush
,
and
murmur
,
and
tinkle
of
the
hidden
watercourses
;
the
song
of
the
lark
poised
high
up
in
the
sunny
air
;
the
bleat
of
the
lambs
calling
to
their
mothers
 
everything
inanimate
was
full
of
hope
and
gladness
.
  
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
for
a
mournful
month
the
front
door
of
Haytersbank
Farm
was
open
;
the
warm
spring
air
might
enter
,
and
displace
the
sad
dark
gloom
,
if
it
could
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
newly
-
lighted
fire
in
the
unused
grate
;
and
Kester
was
in
the
kitchen
,
with
his
clogs
off
his
feet
,
so
as
not
to
dirty
the
spotless
floor
,
stirring
here
and
there
,
and
trying
in
his
awkward
way
to
make
things
look
home
-
like
and
cheerful
.
<EOS>
He
had
brought
in
some
wild
daffodils
which
he
had
been
to
seek
in
the
dawn
,
and
he
placed
them
in
a
jug
on
the
dresser
.
<EOS>
Dolly
Reid
,
the
woman
who
had
come
to

Sylvia
during
her
mother
's
illness
a
year
ago
,
was

to
something
in

back

,
making

the

-
cans
,
and

she

;
yet
every
now
<EOS>
and
then
she
checked

,
as
if

sudden

came
upon
her
that
this
was
neither
the
time
nor
the
place
for
songs
.
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
she
took
up
the
funeral
psalm
which
is
sung
by
the
bearers
of
the
body
in
that
country
    
Our
God
,
our
help
in
ages
past
.
  
<EOS>
But
it
was
of
no
use
:
<EOS>
the
pleasant
April
weather
out
of
doors
,
and
perhaps
the
natural
spring
in
the
body
,
disposed
her
nature
to
cheerfulness
,
and
insensibly
she
returned
to
her
old

.
  
<EOS>
Kester
was
turning
over
many
things
in
his
rude
honest
mind
as
he
stood
there
,
giving
his
finishing
touches
every
now
and
then
to
the
aspect
of
the
house
-
place
,
in
preparation
for
the
return
of
the
widow
and
daughter
of
his
old
master
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
month
and
more
since
they
had
left
home
;
more
than
a
fortnight
since
Kester
,
with
three
halfpence
in

pocket
,
had
set
out
after
his
day
's
work
to
go
to
York
 
to
walk
all
night
long
,
and
to
wish
Daniel
Robson
his
last
farewell
.
  
<EOS>
Daniel
had
tried
to
keep
up
and
had
brought
out
one
or
two
familiar
,
thread
-
bare
,
well
-

,
such
as
he
had
made
Kester
chuckle
over
many
a

and
oft
,
when
the
two
had
been
together
afield
or
in
the
shippen
at
the
home
which
he
should
never
more
see
.
<EOS>
But
no
"
Old

in

gunroom
"
could

,

anything

in

,

,
Daniel
being
up

the
last

two
;
for

,
when

,
fairly

heavy

had
never

.
<EOS>
He
had
left

and

in
their

at
York
,
under
Philip
's

;
he
dared

;
he
could

;
he
had
sent
them
his
duty
,
and
bade
Philip
tell
Sylvia
that
the
game
-
hen
had
brought
out
fifteen

.
  
<EOS>
Yet

sent
this

through
Philip

doing

of
Daniel
Robson
,
the

,
his

master
 
<EOS>
he
liked

not

<EOS>
had

.
  
<EOS>
Philip
had
,
perhaps
,

want
of

in

.
<EOS>
Acute

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

long

for

<EOS>

<EOS>
Kester

,

;
for
,

!
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
Poor

,
who

taken
that
office
upon

,

esteem

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
Bell

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Then

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

fifty

<EOS>

<EOS>
WEDDING
RAIMENT
  
<EOS>
Philip
and
Sylvia
were
engaged
.
<EOS>
It
was
not

happy
a
state
of
things
as
Philip

.
<EOS>
He
had
already

,
although

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

why
he
was
dissatisfied
;
if

as

's

.
<EOS>
She

;
but
no

no

no

,

,
than

<EOS>
When

field

heart

fast
,
his

out

.
<EOS>
She
neither

but
seemed

in

of
some
kind
.
<EOS>
But

resisted

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
Right

was
the
stone

for
the
fresh

water
,
that
,

from
a

,
served
for

of

.
<EOS>
By

,

.
<EOS>
Sylvia

,

.
  
<EOS>
They

.

.

"
<EOS>
Well

"

<EOS>
Sometimes

.
<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
And

.

Philip

<EOS>

<EOS>
Bell
only
remembered
her
husband
's
fate
,
which
filled
up
her
poor
wandering
mind
,
and
coloured
everything
;
insomuch
that
Sylvia
not
being
at
hand
to
reply
to
her
mother
's
cry
for
her
<EOS>
,
the
latter
imagined
that
her
child
,
as
well
as
her
husband
,
was
in
danger
of
trial
and
death
,
and
refused
to
be
comforted
by
any
endeavour
of
the
patient
sympathizing
Hester
.
<EOS>
In
a
pause
of
Mrs
Robson
's
sobs
,
Hester
heard
the
welcome
sound
of
the
wheels
of
the
returning
shandry
,
bearing
the
bride
and
bridegroom
home
.
<EOS>
It
stopped
at
the
door
 
<EOS>
an
instant
,
and
Sylvia
,
white
as
a
sheet
at
the
sound
of
her
mother
's
wailings
,
which
she
had
caught
while
yet
at
a
distance
,
with
the
quick
ears
of
love
,
came
running
in
;
her
mother
feebly
rose
and
tottered
towards
her
,
and
fell
into
her
arms
,
saying
,
"
Oh
!
<EOS>
Sylvie
,
Sylvie
,
take
me
home
,
and
away
from
this
cruel
place
!
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
could
not
but
be
touched
with
the
young
girl
's
manner
to
her
mother
 
as
tender
,
as
protecting
as
if
their
relation
to
each
other
had
been
reversed
,
and
she
was
lulling
and
tenderly
soothing
a
wayward
,
frightened
child
.
<EOS>
She
had
neither
eyes
nor
ears
for
any
one
till
her
mother
was
sitting
in
trembling
peace
,
holding
her
daughter
's
hand
tight
in
both
of
hers
,
as
if
afraid
of
losing
sight
of
her
:
then
Sylvia
turned
to
Hester
,
and
,
with
the
sweet
grace
which
is
a
natural
gift
to
some
happy
people
,
thanked
her
;
in
common
words
enough
she
thanked
her
,
but
in
that
nameless
manner
,
and
with
that
strange
,
rare
charm
which
made
Hester
feel
as
if
she
had
never
been
thanked
in
all
her
life
before
;
and
from
that
time
forth
she
understood
,
if
she
did
not
always
yield
to
,
the
unconscious
fascination
which
Sylvia
could
exercise
over
others
at
times
.
  
<EOS>
Did
it
enter
into
Philip
's
heart
to
perceive
that
he
had
wedded
his
long
-
sought
bride
in
mourning
raiment
,
and
that
the
first
sounds
which
greeted
them
as
they
approached
their
home
were
those
of
weeping
and
wailing
?
      
<EOS>
HAPPY
DAYS
  
<EOS>
And
now
Philip
seemed
as
prosperous
as
his
heart
could
desire
.
<EOS>
The
business
flourished
,
and
money
beyond
his
moderate
wants
came
in
.
<EOS>
As
for
himself
he
required
very
little
;
but
he
had
always
looked
forward
to
placing
his
idol
in
a
befitting
shrine
;
and
means
for
this
were
now
furnished
to
him
.
<EOS>
The
dress
,
the
comforts
,
the
position
he
had
desired
for
Sylvia
were
all
hers
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
need
to
do
a
stroke
of
household
work
if
she
preferred
to
"
sit
in
her
parlour
and
sew
up
a
seam
"
.
<EOS>
Indeed
Phoebe
resented
any
interference
in
the
domestic
labour
,
which
she
had
performed
so
long
,
that
she
looked
upon
the
kitchen
as
a
private
empire
of
her
own
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mrs
Hepburn
"
(
as
Sylvia
was
now
termed
)
had
a
good
dark
silk
gown
-
piece
in
her
drawers
,
as
well
as
the
poor
dove
-
coloured
,
against
the
day
when
she
chose
to
leave
off
mourning
;
and
stuff
for
either
gray
or
scarlet
cloaks
was
hers
at
her
bidding
.
  
<EOS>
What
she
cared
for
far
more
were
the
comforts
with
which
it
was
in
her
power
to
surround
her
mother
.
<EOS>
In
this
Philip
vied
with
her
;
for
besides
his
old
love
,
and
new
pity
for
his
aunt
Bell
,
he
never
forgot
how
she
had
welcomed
him
to
Haytersbank
,
and
favoured
his
love
to
Sylvia
,
in
the
yearning
days
when
he
little
hoped
he
should
ever
win
his
cousin
to
be
his
wife
.
<EOS>
But
even
if
he
had
not
had
these
grateful
and
affectionate
feelings
towards
the
poor
woman
,
he
would
have
done
much
for
her
if
only
to
gain
the
sweet
,
rare
smiles
which
his
wife
never
bestowed
upon
him
so
freely
as
when
she
saw
him
attending
to
"
mother
,
"
for
so
both
of
them
now
called
Bell
.
<EOS>
For
her
creature
comforts
,
her
silk
gowns
,
and
her
humble
luxury
,
Sylvia
did
not
care
;
Philip
was
almost
annoyed
at
the
indifference
she
often
manifested
to
all
his
efforts
to
surround
her
with
such
things
.
<EOS>
It
was
even
a
hardship
to
her
to
leave
off
her
country
dress
,
her
uncovered
hair
,
her
linsey
petticoat
,
and
loose
bed
-
gown
,
and
to
don
a
stiff
and
stately
gown
for
her
morning
dress
.
<EOS>
Sitting
in
the
dark
parlour
at
the
back
of
the
shop
,
and
doing
"
white
work
,
"
was
much
more
wearying
to
her
than
running
out
into
the
fields
to
bring
up
the
cows
,
or
spinning
wool
,
or
making
up
butter
.
<EOS>
She
sometimes
thought
to
herself
that
it
was
a
strange
kind
of
life
where
there
were
no
out
-
door
animals
to
look
after
;
the
"
ox
and
the
ass
"
had
hitherto
come
into
all
her
ideas
of
humanity
;
and
her
care
and
gentleness
had
made
the
dumb
creatures
round
her
father
's
home
into
mute
friends
with
loving
eyes
,
looking
at
her
as
if
wistful
to
speak
in
words
the
grateful
regard
that
she
could
read
without
the
poor
expression
of
language
.
  
<EOS>
She
missed
the
free
open
air
,
the
great
dome
of
sky
above
the
fields
;
she
rebelled
against
the
necessity
of
"
dressing
"
(
as
she
called
it
)
to
go
out
,
although
she
acknowledged
that
it
was
a
necessity
where
the
first
step
beyond
the
threshold
must
be
into
a
populous
street
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
possible
that
Philip
was
right
at
one
time
when
he
had
thought
to
win
her
by
material
advantages
;
but
the
old
vanities
had
been
burnt
out
of
her
by
the
hot
iron
of
acute
suffering
.
<EOS>
A
great
deal
of
passionate
feeling
still
existed
,
concealed
and
latent
;
but
at
this
period
it
appeared
as
though
she
were
indifferent
to
most
things
,
and
had
lost
the
power
of
either
hoping
or
fearing
much
.
<EOS>
She
was
stunned
into
a
sort
of
temporary
numbness
on
most
points
;
those
on
which
she
was
sensitive
being
such
as
referred
to
the
injustice
and
oppression
of
her
father
's
death
,
or
anything
that
concerned
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
quiet
even
to
passiveness
in
all
her
dealings
with
Philip
;
he
would
have
given
not
a
little
for
some
of
the
old
bursts
of
impatience
,
the
old
pettishness
,
which
,
naughty
as
they
were
,
had
gone
to
form
his
idea
of
the
former
Sylvia
.
<EOS>
Once
or
twice
he
was
almost
vexed
with
her
for
her
docility
;
he
wanted
her
so
much
to
have
a
will
of
her
own
,
if
only
that
he
might
know
how
to
rouse
her
to
pleasure
by
gratifying
it
.
<EOS>
Indeed
he
seldom
fell
asleep
at
nights
without
his
last
thoughts
being
devoted
to
some
little
plan
for
the
morrow
,
that
he
fancied
she
would
like
;
and
when
he
wakened
in
the
early
dawn
he
looked
to
see
if
she
were
indeed
sleeping
by
his
side
,
or
whether
it
was
not
all
a
dream
that
he
called
Sylvia
"
wife
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
aware
that
her
affection
for
him
was
not
to
be
spoken
of
in
the
same
way
as
his
for
her
,
but
he
found
much
happiness
in
only
being
allowed
to
love
and
cherish
her
;
and
with
the
patient
perseverance
that
was
one
remarkable
feature
in
his
character
,
he
went
on
striving
to
deepen
and
increase
her
love
when
most
other
men
would
have
given
up
the
endeavour
,
made
themselves
content
with
half
a
heart
,
and
turned
to
some
other
object
of
attainment
.
<EOS>
All
this
time
Philip
was
troubled
by
a
dream
that
recurred
whenever
he
was
over
-
fatigued
,
or
otherwise
not
in
perfect
health
.
<EOS>
Over
and
over
again
in
this
first
year
of
married
life
he
dreamt
this
dream
;
perhaps
as
many
as
eight
or
nine
times
,
and
it
never
varied
.
<EOS>
It
was
always
of
Kinraid
's
return
;
Kinraid
was
full
of
life
in
Philip
's
dream
,
though
in
his
waking
hours
he
could
and
did
convince
himself
by
all
the
laws
of
probability
that
his
rival
was
dead
.
<EOS>
He
never
remembered
the
exact
sequence
of
events
in
that
terrible
dream
after
he
had
roused
himself
,
with
a
fight
and
a
struggle
,
from
his
feverish
slumbers
.
<EOS>
He
was
generally
sitting
up
in
bed
when
he
found
himself
conscious
,
his
heart
beating
wildly
,
with
a
conviction
of
Kinraid
's
living
presence
somewhere
near
him
in
the
darkness
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
Sylvia
was
disturbed
by
his
agitation
,
and
would
question
him
about
his
dreams
,
having
,
like
most
of
her
class
at
that
time
,
great
faith
in
their
prophetic
interpretation
;
but
Philip
never
gave
her
any
truth
in
his
reply
.
  
<EOS>
After
all
,
and
though
he
did
not
acknowledge
it
even
to
himself
,
the
long
-
desired
happiness
was
not
so
delicious
and
perfect
as
he
had
anticipated
.
<EOS>
Many
have
felt
the
same
in
their
first
year
of
married
life
;
but
the
faithful
,
patient
nature
that
still
works
on
,
striving
to
gain
love
,
and
capable
itself
of
steady
love
all
the
while
,
is
a
gift
not
given
to
all
.
  
<EOS>
For
many
weeks
after
their
wedding
,
Kester
never
came
near
them
:
a
chance
word
or
two
from
Sylvia
showed
Philip
that
she
had
noticed
this
and
regretted
it
;
and
,
accordingly
,
he
made
it
his
business
at
the
next
leisure
opportunity
to
go
to
Haytersbank
<EOS>
(
never
saying
a
word
to
his
wife
of
his
purpose
)
,
and
seek
out
Kester
.
  
<EOS>
All
the
whole
place
was
altered
!
<EOS>
It
was
new
white
-
washed
,
new
thatched
:
the
patches
of
colour
in
the
surrounding
ground
were
changed
with
altered
tillage
;
the
great
geraniums
were
gone
from
the
window
,
and
instead
,
was
a
smart
knitted
blind
.
<EOS>
Children
played
before
the
house
-
door
;
a
dog
lying
on
the
step
flew
at
Philip
;
all
was
so
strange
,
that
it
was
even
the
strangest
thing
of
all
for
Kester
to
appear
where
everything
else
was
so
altered
!
  
<EOS>
Philip
had
to
put
up
with
a
good
deal
of
crabbed
behaviour
on
the
part
of
the
latter
before
he
could
induce
Kester
to
promise
to
come
down
into
the
town
and
see
Sylvia
in
her
new
home
.
  
<EOS>
Somehow
,
the
visit
when
paid
was
but
a
failure
;
at
least
,
it
seemed
so
at
the
time
,
though
probably
it
broke
the
ice
of
restraint
which
was
forming
over
the
familiar
intercourse
between
Kester
and
Sylvia
.
<EOS>
The
old
servant
was
daunted
by
seeing
Sylvia
in
a
strange
place
,
and
stood
,
sleeking
his
hair
down
,
and
furtively
looking
about
him
,
instead
of
seating
himself
on
the
chair
<EOS>
Sylvia
had
so
eagerly
brought
forward
for
him
.
  
<EOS>
Then
his
sense
of
the
estrangement
caused
by
their
new
positions
infected
her
,
and
she
began
to
cry
pitifully
,
saying
,
    
"
Oh
,
Kester
!
<EOS>
Kester
!
<EOS>
tell
me
about
Haytersbank
!
<EOS>
Is
it
just
as
it
used
to
be
in
feyther
's
days
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
a
can
not
say
as
it
is
,
"
said
Kester
,
thankful
to
have
a
subject
started
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
They'n
pleughed
up
t
'
oud
pasture
-
field
,
and
are
settin
'
it
for
'
taters
.
<EOS>
They
're
not
for
much
cattle
,
is
n't
Higginses
.
<EOS>
They
'll
be
for
corn
in
t
'
next
year
,
a
reckon
,
and
they
'll
just
ha
'
their
pains
for
their
payment
.
<EOS>
But
they
're
allays
<EOS>
so
pig
-
headed
,
is
folk
fra
'
a
distance
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
So
they
went
on
discoursing
on
Haytersbank
and
the
old
days
,
till
Bell
Robson
,
having
finished
her
afternoon
nap
,
came
slowly
down
-
stairs
to
join
them
;
and
after
that
the
conversation
became
so
broken
up
,
from
the
desire
of
the
other
two
to
attend
and
reply
as
best
they
could
to
her
fragmentary
and
disjointed
talk
,
that
Kester
took
his
leave
before
long
;
falling
,
as
he
did
so
,
into
the
formal
and
unnaturally
respectful
manner
which
he
had
adopted
on
first
coming
in
.
  
<EOS>
But
Sylvia
ran
after
him
,
and
brought
him
back
from
the
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
To
think
of
thy
going
away
,
Kester
,
without
either
bit
or
drink
;
nay
,
come
back
wi
'
thee
,
and
taste
wine
and
cake
.
"
  
<EOS>
Kester
stood
at
the
door
,
half
shy
,
half
pleased
,
while
Sylvia
,
in
all
the
glow
and
hurry
of
a
young
housekeeper
's
hospitality
,
sought
for
the
decanter
of
wine
,
and
a
wine
-
glass
in
the
corner
cupboard
,
and
hastily
cut
an
immense
wedge
of
cake
,
which
she
crammed
into
his
hand
in
spite
of
his
remonstrances
;
and
then
she
poured
him
out
an
overflowing
glass
of
wine
,
which
Kester
would
far
rather
have
gone
without
,
as
he
knew
manners
too
well
to
suppose
that
he
might
taste
it
without
having
gone
through
the
preliminary
ceremony
of
wishing
the
donor
health
and
happiness
.
<EOS>
He
stood
red
and
half
smiling
,
with
his
cake
in
one
hand
,
his
wine
in
the
other
,
and
then
began
,
      
"
Long
may
ye
live
,
  
<EOS>
Happy
may
ye
he
,
  
And
blest
with
a
num'rous
  
Pro
-
ge
-
ny
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Theere
,
that
's
po'try
for
yo
'
as

<EOS>

<EOS>

Hester

.
<EOS>

.

.

"
  
<EOS>
Philip

<EOS>
Before

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

's

,

.
<EOS>
Nor

Kinraid
to
human

,
though
,

,
her

;

,

,

"

"
,
and

,
and

;

,

,

only

.
  
<EOS>
She

not

,
which

somewhat
of

of
stolen

;
for
all

other
respectable
matrons
and

whom

content

,

;

the
mother

.
<EOS>
She
used

,

,
her

,

,

the
distant

,

a

of
thought
;
if

on
what

,
she

not

you
.
  
<EOS>
But
,

-
and
-

,

;

,

side
 
her
child
,
Philip
's
child
.
<EOS>
His

,

;
this
was

;
this

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
He
already

to
trace
in
the
little
girl
,
only

days
old
,
the
lovely
curves
that
he
knew
so
well
by
heart
in

mother
's

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
,
too
,
pale
,
still
,
and
weak
,
was
very

;
yes
,
really
happy
for
the
first

marriage
.
<EOS>
For
its

had
weighed
much
upon

with
a
sense
of

;
she

all
Philip
's

,

her
mother
,

<EOS>
She

,

;

like

the
dead
was

,
<EOS>
the
choice
taken
which

.
<EOS>
Now

came

.
  
<EOS>
Even

.
<EOS>

to
Bell

<EOS>

<EOS>
such

the

<EOS>
EVIL
OMENS
  
<EOS>
The
first

's

happened
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
had
made
rapid
progress
in
her
recovery
;
but
now
she
seemed
at
a
stationary
point
of
weakness
;
wakeful
nights
succeeding
to
languid
days
.
<EOS>
Occasionally
she
caught
a
little
sleep
in
the
afternoons
,
but
she
usually
awoke
startled
and
feverish
.
  
<EOS>
One
afternoon
Philip
had
stolen
upstairs
to
look
at
her
and
his
child
;
but
the
efforts
he
made
at
careful
