made
the
door
creak
on
its
hinges
as
he
opened
it
.
<EOS>
The
woman
employed
to
nurse
her
had
taken
the
baby
into
another
room
that
no
sound
might
rouse
her
from
her

;
and
Philip
would
probably
have
been
warned
against
entering
the
chamber
where
his
wife
lay

had
he
been

.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
he
opened
the
door
,
made

,
and
Sylvia
started
up
,
her
face
all
one
flush
,
her

;

looked
about

as

did

was
;
pushed

;
all

Philip
saw
,

.
<EOS>

"

Oh
!
Charley
!
<EOS>
come

!

<EOS>

,
her

<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
Philip
's

;
any

's

,

<EOS>

after
another
man

.
<EOS>

"

?

"

<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>

"

"
It

,

"
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
The

's

,

.

"

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
so

;
<EOS>

<EOS>

praised

because
he
did
well
to
himself
.
<EOS>
He
had
the
perseverance
,
the
capability
for
head
-

and

,
the
steadiness

general

which
might

.
<EOS>
Without

own
,

,

,

's

,

was

;
the
one
to

while

.
<EOS>
The

was

.
<EOS>
He

"
<EOS>
Their

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

RESCUED
FROM
THE
WAVES
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Hester
came

;

,

,
that

<EOS>
She
was

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>
Now

the

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Philip

.
<EOS>
Innocent
Hester
!
<EOS>

he

full

.
<EOS>
Lassie
!
<EOS>
it
's
not
right

thee
,

;

,

tea

.
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If

"

"

.
<EOS>

"

's

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
I

ha

.
<EOS>

,
 
Headlington

,

.

<EOS>

;

,

"

"
  
"
<EOS>
Eh
!
<EOS>
but
it
's
gettin
'
dark
!
<EOS>
See
there
's
t
'
leeghts
in
t
'
houses
in
t
'
New
Town
!
<EOS>
T
'
grass
is
crispin
'
wi
'
t
'
white
frost
under
out
feet
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
a
hard
tug
round
t
'
point
,
and
then
she
'll
be
gettin
'
into
still
waters
.
<EOS>
"
  
One
more
great
push
and
mighty
strain
,
and
the
danger
was
past
;
the
vessel
 
or
what
remained
of
her
 
was
in
the
harbour
,
among
the
lights
and
cheerful
sounds
of
safety
.
<EOS>
The
fishermen
sprang
down
the
cliff
to
the
quay
-
side
,
anxious
to
see
the
men
whose
lives
they
had
saved
;
the
women
,
weary
and
over
-
excited
,
began
to
cry
.
<EOS>
Not
Sylvia
,
however
;
her
fount
of
tears
had
been
exhausted
earlier
in
the
day
:
her
principal
feeling
was
of
gladness
and
high
rejoicing
that
they
were
saved
who
had
been
so
near
to
death
not
half
an
hour
before
.
  
<EOS>
She
would
have
liked
to
have
seen
the
men
,
and
shaken
hands
with
them
all
round
.
<EOS>
But
instead
she
must
go
home
,
and
well
would
it
be
with
her
if
she
was
in
time
for
her
husband
's
supper
,
and
escaped
any
notice
of
her
absence
.
<EOS>
So
she
separated
herself
from
the
groups
of
women
who
sate
on
the
grass
in
the
churchyard
,
awaiting
the
return
of
such
of
their
husbands
as
could
resist
the
fascinations
of
the
Monkshaven
public
houses
.
<EOS>
As
Sylvia
went
down
the
church
steps
,
she
came
upon
one
of
the
fishermen
who
had
helped
to
tow
the
vessel
into
port
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
was
seventeen
men
and
boys
aboard
her
,
and
a
navy
-
lieutenant
as
had
comed
as
passenger
.
<EOS>
It
were
a
good
job
as
we
could
manage
her
.
<EOS>
Good
-
neet
to
thee
,
thou'll
sleep
all
t
'
sounder
for
havin'
lent
a
hand
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
street
air
felt
hot
and
close
after
the
sharp
keen
atmosphere
of
the
heights
above
;
the
decent
shops
and
houses
had
all
their
shutters
put
up
,
and
were
preparing
for
their
early
bed
-
time
.
<EOS>
Already
lights
shone
here
and
there
in
the
upper
chambers
,
and
Sylvia
scarcely
met
any
one
.
  
<EOS>
She
went
round
up
the
passage
from
the
quay
-
side
,
and
in
by
the
private
door
.
<EOS>
All
was
still
;
the
basins
of
bread
and
milk
that
she
and
her
husband
were
in
the
habit
of
having
for
supper
stood
in
the
fender
before
the
fire
,
each
with
a
plate
upon
them
.
<EOS>
Nancy
had
gone
to
bed
,
Phoebe
dozed
in
the
kitchen
;
Philip
was
still
in
the
ware
-
room
,
arranging
goods
and
taking
stock
along
with
Coulson
,
for
Hester
had
gone
home
to
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
was
not
willing
to
go
and
seek
out
Philip
,
after
the
manner
in
which
they
had
parted
.
<EOS>
All
the
despondency
of
her
life
became
present
to
her
again
as
she
sate
down
within
her
home
.
<EOS>
She
had
forgotten
it
in
her
interest
and
excitement
,
but
now
it
came
back
again
.
  
<EOS>
Still
she
was
hungry
,
and
youthful
,
and
tired
.
<EOS>
She
took
her
basin
up
,
and
was
eating
her
supper
when
she
heard
a
cry
of
her
baby
upstairs
,
and
ran
away
to
attend
to
it
.
<EOS>
When
it
had
been
fed
and
hushed
away
to
sleep
,
she
went
in
to
see
her
mother
,
attracted
by
some
unusual
noise
in
her
room
.
  
<EOS>
She
found
Mrs.
Robson
awake
,
and
restless
,
and
ailing
;
dwelling
much
on
what
Philip
had
said
in
his
anger
against
Sylvia
.
<EOS>
It
was
really
necessary
for
her
daughter
to
remain
with
her
;
so
Sylvia
stole
out
,
and
went
quickly
down
-
stairs
to
Philip
 
now
sitting
tired
and
worn
out
,
and
eating
his
supper
with
little
or
no
appetite
 
and
told
him
she
meant
to
pass
the
night
with
her
mother
.
  
<EOS>
His
answer
of
acquiescence
was
so
short
and
careless
,
or
so
it
seemed
to
her
,
that
she
did
not
tell
him
any
more
of
what
she
had
done
or
seen
that
evening
,
or
even
dwell
upon
any
details
of
her
mother
's
indisposition
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
had
left
the
room
,
Philip
set
down
his
half
-
finished
basin
of
bread
and
milk
,
and
sate
long
,
his
face
hidden
in
his
folded
arms
.
<EOS>
The
wick
of
the
candle
grew
long
and
black
,
and
fell
,
and
sputtered
,
and
guttered
;
he
sate
on
,
unheeding
either
it
or
the
pale
gray
fire
that
was
dying
out
 
dead
at
last
.
    
<EOS>
AN
APPARITION
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Robson
was
very
poorly
all
night
long
.
<EOS>
Uneasy
thoughts
seemed
to
haunt
and
perplex
her
brain
,
and
she
neither
slept
nor
woke
,
but
was
restless
and
uneasy
in
her
talk
and
movements
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
lay
down
by
her
,
but
got
so
little
sleep
,
that
at
length
she
preferred
sitting
in
the
easy
-
chair
by
the
bedside
.
<EOS>
Here
she
dropped
off
to
slumber
in
spite
of
herself
;
the
scene
of
the
evening
before
seemed
to
be
repeated
;
the
cries
of
the
many
people
,
the
heavy
roar
and
dash
of
the
threatening
waves
,
were
repeated
in
her
ears
;
and
something
was
said
to
her
through
all
the
conflicting
noises
,
 
what
it
was
she
could
not
catch
,
though
she
strained
to
hear
the
hoarse
murmur
that
,
in
her
dream
,
she
believed
to
convey
a
meaning
of
the
utmost
importance
to
her
.
  
<EOS>
This
dream
,
that
mysterious
,
only
half
-
intelligible
sound
,
recurred
whenever
she
dozed
,
and
her
inability
to
hear
the
words
uttered
distressed
her
so
much
,
that
at
length
she
sate
bolt
upright
,
resolved
to
sleep
no
more
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
was
talking
in
a
half
-
conscious
way
;
Philip
's
speech
of
the
evening
before
was
evidently
running
in
her
mind
.
  
<EOS>
"
Sylvie
,
if
thou're
not
a
good
wife
to
him
,
it
'll
just
break
my
heart
outright
.
<EOS>
A
woman
should
obey
her
husband
,
and
not
go
her
own
gait
.
<EOS>
I
never
leave
the
house
wi'out
<EOS>
telling
father
,
and
getting
his
leave
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And
then
she
began
to
cry
pitifully
,
and
to
say
unconnected
things
,
till
Sylvia
,
to
soothe
her
,
took
her
hand
,
and
promised
never
to
leave
the
house
without
asking
her
husband
's
permission
,
though
in
making
this
promise
,
she
felt
as
if
she
were
sacrificing
her
last
pleasure
to
her
mother
's
wish
;
for
she
knew
well
enough
that
Philip
would
always
raise
objections
to
the
rambles
which
reminded
her
of
her
old
free
open
-
air
life
.
  
<EOS>
But
to
comfort
and
cherish
her
mother
she
would
have
done
anything
;
yet
this
very
morning
that
was
dawning
,
she
must
go
and
ask
his
permission
for
a
simple
errand
,
or
break
her
word
.
  
<EOS>
She
knew
from
experience
that
nothing
quieted
her
mother
so
well
as
balm
-
tea
;
it
might
be
that
the
herb
really
possessed
some
sedative
power
;
it
might
be
only
early
faith
,
and
often
repeated
experience
,
but
it
had
always
had
a
tranquillizing
effect
;
and
more
than
once
,
during
the
restless
hours
of
the
night
,
Mrs.
Robson
had
asked
for
it
;
but
Sylvia
's
stock
of
last
year
's
dead
leaves
was
exhausted
.
<EOS>
Still
she
knew
where
a
plant
of
balm
grew
in
the
sheltered
corner
of
Haytersbank
Farm
garden
;
she
knew
that
the
tenants
who
had
succeeded
them
in
the
occupation
of
the
farm
had
had
to
leave
it
in
consequence
of
a
death
,
and
that
the
place
was
unoccupied
;
and
in
the
darkness
she
had
planned
that
if
she
could
leave
her
mother
after
the
dawn
came
,
and
she
had
attended
to
her
baby
,
she
would
walk
quickly
to
the
old
garden
,
and
gather
the
tender
sprigs
which
she
was
sure
to
find
there
.
  
<EOS>
Now
she
must
go
and
ask
Philip
;
and
till
she
held
her
baby
to
her
breast
,
she
bitterly
wished
that
she
were
free
from
the
duties
and
chains
of
matrimony
.
<EOS>
But
the
touch
of
its
waxen
fingers
,
the
hold
of
its
little
mouth
,
made
her
relax
into
docility
and
gentleness
.
<EOS>
She
gave
it
back
to
Nancy
to
be
dressed
,
and
softly
opened
the
door
of
Philip
's
bed
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Philip
!
"
said
she
,
gently
.
"
<EOS>
Philip
!
"
  
<EOS>
He
started
up
from
dreams
of
her
;
of
her
,
angry
.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
there
,
rather
pale
with
her
night
's
watch
and
anxiety
,
but
looking
meek
,
and
a
little
beseeching
.
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
has
had
such
a
bad
night
!
<EOS>
she
fancied
once
as
some
balm
-
tea
would
do
her
good
 
<EOS>
it
allays
used
to
:
<EOS>
but
my
dried
balm
is
all
gone
,
and
I
thought
there
'd
be
sure
to
be
some
in
t
'
old
garden
at
Haytersbank
.
<EOS>
Feyther
planted
a
bush
just
for
mother
,
wheere
it
allays
came
up
early
,
nigh
t
'
old
elder
-
tree
;
and
if
yo'd
not
mind
,
I
could
run
theere
while
she
sleeps
,
and
be
back
again
in
an
hour
,
and
it
's
not
seven
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thou
's
not
wear
thyself
out
with
running
,
Sylvie
,
"
said
Philip
,
eagerly
;
"
I
'll
get
up
and
go
myself
,
or
,
perhaps
,
"
continued
he
,
catching
the
shadow
that
was
coming
over
her
face
,
"
thou'd
rather
go
thyself
<EOS>
:
it
's
only
that
I
'm
so
afraid
of
thy
tiring
thyself
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
'll
not
tire
me
,
"
said
Sylvia
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Afore
I
was
married
,
I
was
out
often
far
farther
than
that
,
afield
to
fetch
up
t
'
kine
,
before
my
breakfast
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
go
if
thou
will
,
"
said
Philip
.
<EOS>
"
But
get
somewhat
to
eat
first
,
and
do
n't
hurry
;
there
's
no
need
for
that
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
got
her
hat
and
shawl
,
and
was
off
before
he
had
finished
his
last
words
.
  
<EOS>
The
long
High
Street
was
almost
empty
of
people
at
that
early
hour
;
one
side
was
entirely
covered
by
the
cool
morning
shadow
which
lay
on
the
pavement
,
and
crept
up
the
opposite
houses
till
only
the
topmost
story
caught
the
rosy
sunlight
.
<EOS>
Up
the
hill
-
road
,
through
the
gap
in
the
stone
wall
,
across
the
dewy
fields
,
Sylvia
went
by
the
very
shortest
path
she
knew
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
only
once
been
at
Haytersbank
since
her
wedding
-
day
.
<EOS>
On
that
occasion
the
place
had
seemed
strangely
and
dissonantly
changed
by
the
numerous
children
who
were
diverting
themselves
before
the
open
door
,
and
whose
playthings
and
clothes
strewed
the
house
-
place
,
and
made
it
one
busy
scene
of
confusion
and
untidiness
,
more
like
the
Corneys
'
kitchen
in
former
times
,
than
her
mother
's
orderly
and
quiet
abode
.
<EOS>
Those
little
children
were
fatherless
now
;
and
the
house
was
shut
up
,
awaiting
the
entry
of
some
new
tenant
.
<EOS>
There
were
no
shutters
to
shut
;
the
long
low
window
was
blinking
in
the
rays
of
the
morning
sun
;
the
house
and
cow
-
house
doors
were
closed
,
and
no
poultry
wandered
about
the
field
in
search
of
stray
grains
of
corn
,
or
early
worms
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
strange
and
unfamiliar
silence
,
and
struck
solemnly
on
Sylvia
's
mind
.
<EOS>
Only
a
thrush
in
the
old
orchard
down
in
the
hollow
,
out
of
sight
,
whistled
and
gurgled
with
continual
shrill
melody
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
went
slowly
past
the
house
and
down
the
path
leading
to
the
wild
,
deserted
bit
of
garden
.
<EOS>
She
saw
that
the
last
tenants
had
had
a
pump
sunk
for
them
,
and
resented
the
innovation
,
as
though
the
well
she
was
passing
could
feel
the
insult
.
<EOS>
Over
it
grew
two
hawthorn
trees
;
on
the
bent
trunk
of
one
of
them
she
used
to
sit
,
long
ago
:
the
charm
of
the
position
being
enhanced
by
the
possible
danger
of
falling
into
the
well
and
being
drowned
.
<EOS>
The
rusty
unused
chain
was
wound
round
the
windlass
;
the
bucket
was
falling
to
pieces
from
dryness
.
<EOS>
A
lean
cat
came
from
some
outhouse
,
and
mewed
pitifully
with
hunger
;
accompanying
Sylvia
to
the
garden
,
as
if
glad
of
some
human
companionship
,
yet
refusing
to
allow
itself
to
be
touched
.
<EOS>
Primroses
grew
in
the
sheltered
places
,
just
as
they
formerly
did
;
and
made
the
uncultivated
ground
seem
less
deserted
than
the
garden
,
where
the
last
year
's
weeds
were
rotting
away
,
and
cumbering
the
ground
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
forced
her
way
through
the
berry
bushes
to
the
herb
-
plot
,
and
plucked
the
tender
leaves
she
had
come
to
seek
;
sighing
a
little
all
the
time
.
<EOS>
Then
she
retraced
her
steps
;
paused
softly
before
the
house
-
door
,
and
entered
the
porch
and
kissed
the
senseless
wood
.
  
<EOS>
She
tried
to
tempt
the
poor
gaunt
cat
into
her
arms
,
meaning
to
carry
it
home
and
befriend
it
;
but
it
was
scared
by
her
endeavour
and
ran
back
to
its
home
in
the
outhouse
,
making
a
green
path
across
the
white
dew
of

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
Sylvia
!
"
<EOS>

"
<EOS>
Sylvia
!
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

.

;

.

.
  
<EOS>
First

,

.

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
The

Bella

having

slumber
;
Nancy
used
to
tell
long
afterwards
how
he
knelt
down
by
the
side
of
her
cot
,
and
was
so
strange
<EOS>
she
thought
he
must
have
prayed
,
for
all
it
was
nigh
upon
eleven
o'clock
,
and
folk
in
their
senses
only
said
their
prayers
when
they
got
up
,
and
when
they
went
to
bed
.
  
<EOS>
Then
he
rose
,
and
stooped

,

long

.
<EOS>
And
on
tip
-

he
passed
away
into
the
room

his
aunt

;
his
aunt
who
had
been
so
true

!
<EOS>
He
was
thankful
to

that
in
her
present
state
she
was
safe
from
the

what
was
past
,

the

.
  
<EOS>
He

;
he

her
hatred
,
her
scorn
,
but
there
,

's

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Robson
,
too
,
was

,
her

towards

wall
.
<EOS>
Philip
could
not
help

;
he
went
to

.
<EOS>
She

;

.
<EOS>

,
and
a

.
<EOS>
And

only

misery
,
 
misery

.
  
<EOS>
He
sighed

;
but
he

away
,
down

stairs
,
and
away
for

.
<EOS>
Only

parlour
his

,

,
done

the

by
some

.
<EOS>
They

,

but
Philip

<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>
He
went
down
the
entry
on
to

.
<EOS>
The

was
there
,
and
waters
,
they
say
,
have
a

,
and
a
weird

.
<EOS>
But
many

,

;

his

,

entry
 
<EOS>
the
town
is
burrowed

such
 
back
into
the
High

,
<EOS>
which

into

,

rough

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
From

.
<EOS>

,

;

,

?
<EOS>
and

,

<EOS>
Up

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

;
the

poised
"
at

.
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
He

,

fairly
on

;

last

<EOS>
So

evening

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
He

of
Monkshaven

<EOS>

"

!

ta

?
<EOS>
Thou
's
seen
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

,

(

"
dog's
-

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
A

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It
took
effect
on
one
so
habitually
sober
;
and
he
was
soon
in
that
state
when
the
imagination
works

and

.
  
<EOS>
He
saw
the
sergeant

,

,

,

,

,

,

,

;

everywhere
because
of

.
  
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

Monkshaven
,

love
him
once

?
<EOS>
Could
not
he
win
her
heart
?
<EOS>
He
was
brave
by
nature
,
and

of

did

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
thought

,

;

the

twenty

he
,
and
knew

.
  
<EOS>
Philip
was
older
by
some

than

regulation

;
but
,

that

of
great
demand
for
men
,
the

of

was
lightly

.
<EOS>
The
sergeant
was

in

of
the

to

in
his
branch
of

;
how
such

was
sure

;

the

,

.
  
<EOS>
Philip
's

head
thought
the

over
and

,
each

with

.
  
<EOS>
At

,

,
as

,

,

<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

;

,
the

of

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
He

;

.
<EOS>
Anything

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

so

<EOS>
was

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

a
remonstrance
,
or
dreading
a
sudden
bolt
.
  
<EOS>
But
Philip
walked
with
him
the
two
or
three
miles
in
the
most
submissive
silence
,
never
uttering
a
syllable
of
regret
or
repentance
;
and
before
Justice
Cholmley
,
of
Holm
-
Fell
Hall
,
he
was
sworn
into
his
Majesty
's
service
,
under
the
name
of
Stephen
Freeman
.
<EOS>
With
a
new
name
,
he
began
a
new
life
.
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
the
old
life
lives
for
ever
!
    
<EOS>
THINGS
<EOS>
UNUTTERABLE
  
<EOS>
After
Philip
had
passed
out
of
the
room
,
Sylvia
lay
perfectly
still
,
from
very
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
Her
mother
slept
on
,
happily
unconscious
of
all
the
turmoil
that
had
taken
place
;
yes
,
happily
,
though
the
heavy
sleep
was
to
end
in
death
.
<EOS>
But
of
this
her
daughter
knew
nothing
,
imagining
that
it
was
refreshing
slumber
,
instead
of
an
ebbing
of
life
.
<EOS>
Both
mother
and
daughter
lay
motionless
till
Phoebe
entered
the
room
to
tell
Sylvia
that
dinner
was
on
the
table
.
  
<EOS>
Then
Sylvia
sate
up
,
and
put
back
her
hair
,
bewildered
and
uncertain
as
to
what
was
to
be
done
next
;
how
she
should
meet
the
husband
to
whom
she
had
discarded
all
allegiance
,
repudiated
the
solemn
promise
of
love
and
obedience
which
she
had
vowed
.
  
<EOS>
Phoebe
came
into
the
room
,
with
natural
interest
in
the
invalid
,
scarcely
older
than
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
is
t
'
old
lady
?
"
<EOS>
asked
she
,
in
a
low
voice
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
turned
her
head
round
to
look
;
her
mother
had
never
moved
,
but
was
breathing
in
a
loud
uncomfortable
manner
,
that
made
her
stoop
over
her
to
see
the
averted
face
more
nearly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Phoebe
!
"
<EOS>
she
cried
,
"
come
here
!
<EOS>
She
looks
strange
and
odd
;
her
eyes
are
open
,
but
do
n't
see
me
.
<EOS>
Phoebe
!
<EOS>
Phoebe
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Sure
enough
,
she
's
in
a
bad
way
!
"
said
Phoebe
,
climbing
stiffly
on
to
the
bed
to
have
a
nearer
view
.
<EOS>
"
Hold
her
head
a
little
up
t
'
ease
her
breathin
'
while
I
go
for
master
;
he
'll
be
for
sendin
'
for
t
'
doctor
,
I
'll
be
bound
.
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
took
her
mother
's
head
and
laid
it
fondly
on
her
breast
,
speaking
to
her
and
trying
to

;
but
it
was
of
no
avail
:
the
hard
,
stertorous
breathing
grew
worse
and
worse
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
cried
out
for
help
;
Nancy
came
,
the
baby
in
her
arms
.
<EOS>
They
had
been
in
several
times
before
that
morning
;
and
the
child
came
smiling
and
crowing
at
its
mother
,
who
was
supporting
her
own
dying

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Nancy
!
<EOS>
"
said
Sylvia
;
"
what
is
the
matter
with
mother
?
<EOS>
yo
'
can
see
her
face
;
tell

!
"
  
<EOS>
Nancy
set
the
baby
on
the
bed
for
all
reply
,
and
ran
out

the
room
,
crying

,
  
"
Master
!
<EOS>
master
!
<EOS>
Come
quick
!
<EOS>
T
'
old
missus
is
a
-
dying
!
"
  
<EOS>
This
appeared
to
be
no
news
to
Sylvia
,
and
yet
the
words
came
on
her
with
a
great
shock
,
but
for
all
that
she
could
not

;
she
was
surprised
herself
at
her
own
deadness
of
feeling
.
  
<EOS>
Her
baby
crawled
to
her
,
and
she
had
to
hold
and
guard
both
her
mother
and
her
child
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
a
long
,
long
time
before
any

came
,
and
then
she
heard
muffled

,
and
a
heavy
tramp
<EOS>
:
it
was
Phoebe
leading
the
doctor
upstairs
,
and
Nancy
creeping
in
behind
to
hear
his
opinion
.
  
<EOS>
He
did
not
ask
many
questions
,
and
Phoebe
replied
more
frequently
to
his

than
did
Sylvia
,
who
looked
into
his
face
with
a
blank
,
tearless
,
speechless

,
that
gave
him
more
pain
than
the
sight
of
her
dying
mother
.
  
<EOS>
The
long
decay
of
Mrs.
Robson
's

and
health
,
of
which
he
was
well
aware
,
had
in

prepared
him
for
some
such

of
the
life
whose

was
hardly

,
although
he
gave
several

as

;
but
the
white
,

,

great

,

of
the
younger

,

;
and
he
went
on

for
various

,
more

of

,
if

,

that

information
thus

.
  
<EOS>
"
You
had
best
have
pillows
propped
up
behind
her
 
<EOS>
it
will
not
be
for
long
;
she
does
not
know
that
you
are
holding
her
,
and
it
is
only

to
no

!
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
's
terrible
stare
continued
:
he
put
his
advice
into
action
,
and
gently
tried
to
loosen
her
clasp
,
and
tender

.
<EOS>
This
she
resisted
;
laying
her

against
her
poor
mother
's
unconscious

.
  
<EOS>
"
Where
is
Hepburn
?
"
said
he
.
"
<EOS>
He
ought
to
be
here
!
"
  
<EOS>
Phoebe

at

,
Nancy
at

.
<EOS>
It

,
  
"
<EOS>
He
's
neither
i
'
t
'
house
nor
i
'
t
'
shop
.
<EOS>
A
seed
him
go
past
t
'

better
nor
an

;
but
neither
William
Coulson

Hester
Rose

's

.
  
<EOS>
Dr
Morgan
's

were
puckered
up

,
but
he
made

.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
baby
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
,

.
<EOS>
Nancy
had
taken
her
up

had

,

.
<EOS>
The

gave
her
to

.
<EOS>
He

mother
's

,
it

her
child
,
and
he

.
<EOS>
He
gave

soft

,
and
she
cried

;
again

,
the

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
laid
her
mother
down
,
and
stretched

,
hushing

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
So
far

good
!
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
But
where
is

husband
?
<EOS>
He
ought
to
be
here
.
"
<EOS>
He
went
down
-
stairs
to
make
inquiry
for
Philip
;
that
poor
young
creature
,
about
whose
health
he
had
never

since
the
fever
after
her

,
was
in
an

,
and

.
<EOS>
Her
husband
ought
to
be
with
her
,
and
supporting

to

.
  
<EOS>
Dr
Morgan
went
into
the
shop
.
<EOS>
Hester
alone
was
there
.
<EOS>
Coulson
had
gone
to
his
comfortable
dinner
at
his
well
-

house
,
with
his
common

place

.
<EOS>
If

had
felt

about
Philip
's
looks
and

,
he
had
also
managed
to
account

in

.
  
<EOS>
Hester
was
alone
with
the
shop
-
boy
;
few
people
came
in
during
the
universal
Monkshaven
dinner
-
hour
.
<EOS>
She
was
resting
her

on

,
and

about
many
things
 
<EOS>
all

of
the

before
between

;

.
<EOS>
Oh
!
<EOS>
how
easy
Hester
would

!
<EOS>
not

,
but

.
<EOS>
To

,
an
on
-

,

,

should

,

!
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
it
is
often
so
!
<EOS>
and

which

all
such

not

<EOS>
But

,

.
  
<EOS>
Some

.
<EOS>
But

,

;

!
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

,

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

No
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
Further

;

<EOS>

;

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Before
night

was

about

.
<EOS>
Before
night
Bell
Robson
had
gone
to
her

home
.
<EOS>
And
Sylvia
still
lay
quiet

,
apparently
more

than
any
other

by
the
events

,

of

.
  
<EOS>
The
only

seemed

care
for
was
her

;
she

,
and
Dr
Morgan

leave

there
<EOS>
,
its

might
draw

desired

into
her

,

,
and
charm

aching
pain
out

.
  
<EOS>
They
were
afraid
lest
she
should
inquire
for
her
husband
,
whose
non
-
appearance
at
such
a
time
of
sorrow
to
his
wife
<EOS>
must
(
they
thought
)
seem

to

.
<EOS>
And
night
drew
on
while
they
were
all
in
this

.
<EOS>
She
had
gone
back
to
her
own

without

had

do

;
caressing

in

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
They
saw
her

turn
towards

,
and
they
thought
it
was
with

of
one
who
could
not

found
,
though
many
were

for

.
  
<EOS>
When

came
some

had
to

of
her

's
disappearance
;
and
Dr
Morgan
was
the
person

undertook

.
  
<EOS>
He
came
into
her
room
about
nine

;
her

was

in
her

;
she
herself
pale
as

,

,
though

watchful
of

sounds
,
and
probably

of

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
Mrs.
Hepburn
,
"
said

,

,
"

;

I

<EOS>
your

wo

-

.
<EOS>
Some

.
<EOS>
It

,
as
I
'm

he

;
but
we

of

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
watched
her
to
see

of

words
.
  
<EOS>
She

,
that
was
all
.
<EOS>
He
still
remained

.
<EOS>
She

,
  
"
How

yo
'

?
<EOS>

,

yo
'
,
<EOS>
afore

kind
o
'

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can

,
"

<EOS>

,
<EOS>
nay

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>
Though

as

upon
Philip
's

warned
possibly

Kinraid
's
story
against

in
such

as
those
of

general

yet

's

.
  
<EOS>
Marked

's

Cross
 
<EOS>

had

in

,

miserable
I
was
,
and
might
ha
'
cleared
my
misery
away
wi
'
a
word
;
and
he
held
his
peace
,
and
now
it
's
too
late
!
<EOS>
I
'm
sick
o
'
men
and
their
cruel
,
deceitful
ways
.
<EOS>
I
wish
I
were
dead
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
crying
before
she
had
ended
this
speech
,
and
seeing
her
tears
,
the
child
began
to
cry
too
,
stretching
out
its
little
arms
to
go
back
to
its
mother
.
<EOS>
The
hard
stony
look
on
her
face
melted
away
into
the
softest
,
tenderest
love
as
she
clasped
the
little
one
to
her
,
and
tried
to
soothe
its
frightened
sobs
.
  
<EOS>
A
bright
thought
came
into
the
old
man
's
mind
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
taking
a
complete
dislike
to
her
till
her
pretty
way
with
<EOS>
her
baby
showed
him
that
she
had
a
heart
of
flesh
within
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Poor
little
one
!
<EOS>
"
said
he
,
"
thy
mother
had
need
love
thee
,
for
she
's
deprived
thee
of
thy
father
's
love
.
<EOS>
Thou'rt
half
-
way
to
being
an
orphan
;
yet
I
can
not
call
thee
one
of
the
fatherless
to
whom
God
will
be
a
father
.
<EOS>
Thou'rt
a
desolate
babe
,
thou
may'st
well
cry
;
thine
earthly
parents
have
forsaken
thee
,
and
I
know
not
if
the
Lord
will
take
thee
up
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
looked
up
at
him
affrighted
;
holding
her
baby
tighter
to
her
,
she
exclaimed
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
speak
so
,
sir
!
<EOS>
it
's
cursing
,
sir
!
<EOS>
I
have
n't
forsaken
her
!
<EOS>
Oh
,
sir
!
<EOS>
those
are
awful
sayings
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Thee
hast
sworn
never
to
forgive
thy
husband
,
nor
to
live
with
him
again
.
<EOS>
Dost
thee
know
that
by
the
law
of
the
land
,
he
may
claim
his
child
;
and
then
thou
wilt
have
to
forsake
it
,
or
to
be
forsworn
?
<EOS>
Poor
little
maiden
!
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
continued
he
,
once
more
luring
the
baby
to
him
with
the

of
the
watch
and
chain
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
thought
for
a
while
before
speaking
.
<EOS>
Then
she
said
,
  
"
I
can
not
tell
what
ways
to
take
.
<EOS>
Whiles
<EOS>
I
think
my
head
is
crazed
.
<EOS>
It
were
a
cruel
turn
<EOS>
he
did
me
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
.
<EOS>
I
could
n't
have
thought
him
guilty
of
such
baseness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
acquiescence
,
which
was
perfectly
honest
on
Jeremiah
's
part
,
almost
took
Sylvia
by

.
<EOS>
Why
might
she
not
hate
one
who
had
been
both

and
base
in
his

of
her
?
<EOS>
And
yet

by
another
to
Philip
,
by
a

,

to

.
<EOS>
From

,

,
or

least

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

mother
;

;

niver
spared
aught

,
else
I

niver
ha
'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
He

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

"

Charley
were

,
when
he

t
'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
It

;

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
niver

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can

,

;

I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
she

as
one
who

.
  
<EOS>
All

,

,

,
"
Poor
wee
child
!
"
<EOS>
in

,
addressed

.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
I

as
iver
yo

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
I

mun
not

,

Philip
gone

;

:

I

aught
,
only
I
must
keep
her
wi
'
me
.
<EOS>
Whativer

I
do
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Jeremiah
thought
it
over
for
a

or

.
<EOS>
Then
he

,
  
"
I
must

time
to

.
<EOS>
I

John
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
you
've

,

!
"
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

my
word
never

of
what
has

,
but

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

so

as
almost
to

,
and
he

,
as
a

that

.
  
<EOS>
He

;
but

,
<EOS>
so

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

!
<EOS>
The

to

!
"
  
<EOS>
All

,

,

,
    
"
I
'll

,

,
I

.
<EOS>
I
'll
hap
thee
round
wi
'
my
love
,
so
as
thou
shall
niver
need
a
feyther
's
.
"
    
<EOS>
BEREAVEMENT
  
<EOS>
Hester
had
been
prevented
by
her
mother
's
indisposition
from
taking
Philip
's
letter
to
the
Fosters
,
to
hold
a
consultation
with
them
over
its
contents
.
  
<EOS>
Alice
Rose
was
slowly
failing
,
and
the
long
days
which
she
had
to
spend
alone
told
much
upon
her
spirits
,
and
consequently
upon
her
health
.
  
<EOS>
All
this
came
out
in
the
conversation
which
ensued
after
reading
Hepburn
's
letter
in
the
little
parlour
at
the
bank
on
the
day
after
Sylvia
had
had
her
confidential
interview
with
Jeremiah
Foster
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
a
true
man
of
honour
,
and
never
so
much
as
alluded
to
her
visit
to
him
;
but
what
she
had
then
told
him
influenced
him
very
much
in
the
formation
of
the
project
which
he
proposed
to
his
brother
and
Hester
.
  
<EOS>
He
recommended
her
remaining
where
she
was
,
living
still
in
the
house
behind
the
shop
;
for
he
thought
within
himself
that
she
might
have
exaggerated
the
effect
of
her
words
upon
Philip
;
that
,
after
all
,
it
might
have
been
some
cause
totally
disconnected
with
them
,
which
had
blotted
out
her
husband
's
place
among
the
men
of
Monkshaven
;
and
that
it
would
be
so
much
easier
for
both
to
resume
their
natural
relations
,
both
towards
each
other
and
towards
the
world
,
if
Sylvia
remained
where
her
husband
had
left
her
 
in
an
expectant
attitude
,
so
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
Jeremiah
Foster
questioned
Hester
straitly
about
her
letter
:
whether
she
had
made
known
its
contents
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
No
,
not
to
any
one
.
<EOS>
Neither
to
her
mother
nor
to
William
Coulson
?
<EOS>
No
,
to
neither
.
  
<EOS>
She
looked
at
him
as
she
replied
to
his
inquiries
,
and
he
looked
at
her
,
each
wondering
if
the
other
could
be
in
the
least
<EOS>
aware
that
a
conjugal
quarrel
might
be
at
the
root
of
the
dilemma
in
which
they
were
placed
by
Hepburn
's
disappearance
.
  
<EOS>
But
neither
Hester
,
who
had
witnessed
the
misunderstanding
between
the
husband
and
wife
on
the
evening
,
before
the
morning
on
which
Philip
went
away
,
nor
Jeremiah
Foster
,
who
had
learnt
from
Sylvia
the
true
reason
of
her
husband
's
disappearance
,
gave
the
slightest
reason
to
the
other
to
think
that
they
each
supposed
they
had
a
clue
to
the
reason
of
Hepburn
's
sudden
departure
.
  
<EOS>
What
Jeremiah
Foster
,
after
a
night
's
consideration
,
had
to
propose
was
this
;
that
Hester
and
her
mother
should
come
and
occupy
the
house
in
the
market
-
place
,
conjointly
with
Sylvia
and
her
child
.
<EOS>
Hester
's
interest
in
the
shop
was
by
this
time
acknowledged
.
<EOS>
Jeremiah
had
made
over
to
her
so
much
of
his
share
in
the
business
,
that
she
had
a
right
to
be
considered
as
a
kind
of
partner
;
and
she
had
long
been
the
superintendent
of
that
department
of
goods
which
were
exclusively
devoted
to
women
.
<EOS>
So
her
daily
presence
was
requisite
for
more
reasons
than
one
.
  
<EOS>
Yet
her
mother
's
health
and
spirits
were
such
as
to
render
it
unadvisable
that
the
old
woman
should
be
too
much
left
alone
;
and
Sylvia
's
devotion
to
her
own
mother
seemed
to
point
her
out
as
the
very
person
who
could
be
a
gentle
and
tender
companion
to
Alice
Rose
during
those
hours
when
her
own
daughter
would
necessarily
be
engaged
in
the
shop
.
  
<EOS>
Many
desirable
objects
seemed
to
be
gained
by
this
removal
of
Alice
:
an
occupation
was
provided
for
Sylvia
,
which
would
detain
her
in
the
place
where
her
husband
had
left
her
,
and
where
(
Jeremiah
Foster
fairly
expected
in
spite
of
his
letter
)
<EOS>
he
was
likely
to
come
back
to
find
her
;
and
Alice
Rose
,
the
early
love
of
one
of
the
brothers
,
the
old
friend
of
the
other
,
would
be
well
cared
for
,
and
under
her
daughter
's
immediate
supervision
during
the
whole
of
the
time
that
she
was
occupied
in
the
shop
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
's
share
of
the
business
,
augmented
by
the
money
which
he
had
put
in
from
the
legacy
of
his
old
Cumberland
uncle
,
would
bring
in
profits
enough
to
support
Sylvia
and
her
child
in
ease
and
comfort
until
that
time
,
which
they
all
anticipated
,
when
he
should
return
from
his
mysterious
wandering
 
mysterious
,
whether
his
going
forth
had
been
voluntary
or
involuntary
.
  
<EOS>
Thus
far
was
settled
;
and
Jeremiah
Foster
went
to
tell
Sylvia
of
the
plan
.
  
<EOS>
She
was
too
much
a
child
,
too
entirely
unaccustomed
to
any
independence
of
action
,
to
do
anything
but
leave
herself
in
his
hands
.
<EOS>
Her
very
confession
,
made
to
him
the
day
before
,
when
she
sought
his
counsel
,
seemed
to
place
her
at
his
disposal
.
<EOS>
Otherwise
,
she
had
had
notions
of
the
possibility
of
a
free
country
life
once
more
 
<EOS>
how
provided
for
and
arranged
she
hardly
knew
;
but
Haytersbank
was
to
let
,
and
Kester
disengaged
,
and
it
had
just
seemed
possible
that
she
might
have
to
return
to
her
early
home
,
and
to
her
old
life
.
<EOS>
She
knew
that
it
would
take
much
money
to
stock
the
farm
again
,
and
that
her
hands
were
tied
from
much
useful
activity
by
the
love
and
care
she
owed
to
her
baby
.
<EOS>
But
still
,
somehow
,
she
hoped
and
she
fancied
,
till
Jeremiah
Foster
's
measured
words
and
carefully
-
arranged
plan
made
her
silently
relinquish
her
green
,
breezy
vision
.
  
<EOS>
Hester
,
too
,
had
her
own
private
rebellion
 
hushed
into
submission
by
her
gentle
piety
.
<EOS>
If
Sylvia
had
been
able
to
make
Philip
happy
,
Hester
could
have
felt
lovingly
and
almost
gratefully
towards
her
;
but
Sylvia
had
failed
in
this
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
had
been
made
unhappy
,
and
was
driven
forth
a
wanderer
into
the
wide
world
 
never
to
come
back
!
<EOS>
And
his
last
words
to
Hester
,
the
postscript
of
his
letter
,
containing
the
very
pith
of
it
,
was
to
ask
her
to
take
charge
and
care
of
the
wife
whose
want
of
love
towards
him
had
uprooted
him
from
the
place
where
he
was
valued
and
honoured
.
  
<EOS>
It
cost
Hester
many
a
struggle
and
many
a
self
-
reproach
before
she
could
make
herself
feel
what
she
saw
all
along
 
that
in
everything
Philip
treated
her
like
a
sister
.
<EOS>
But
even
a
sister
might
well
be
indignant
if
she
saw
her
brother
's
love
disregarded
and
slighted
,
and
his
life
embittered
by
the
thoughtless
conduct
of
a
wife
!
<EOS>
Still
Hester
fought
against
herself
,
and
for
Philip
's
sake
she
sought
to
see
the
good
in
Sylvia
,
and
she
strove
to
love
her
as
well
as
to
take
care
of
her
.
  
<EOS>
With
the
baby
,
of
course
,
the
case
was
different
.
<EOS>
Without
thought
or
struggle
,
or
reason
,
every
one
loved
the
little
girl
.
<EOS>
Coulson
and
his
buxom
wife
,
who
were
childless
,
were
never
weary
of
making
much
of
her
.
<EOS>
Hester
's

Alice

;

looked
up
to
Hester
as
some
one
very
remarkable
for
her
goodness
.
<EOS>
If
only
she
could
have
liked
her
!
  
<EOS>
Hester
tried
to
do
all
she
could
for
Sylvia
;
Philip
had
told
her
to
take
care
of
his
wife
and
child
;
but
she
had
the
conviction
that
Sylvia
had
so
materially
failed
in
her
duties
as
to
have
made
her
husband
an
exile
from
his
home
 
a
penniless
wanderer
,
wifeless
and
childless
,
in
some
strange
country
,
whose
very
aspect
was
friendless
,
while
the
cause
of
all
lived
on
in
the
comfortable
home
where
he
had
placed
her
,
wanting
for
nothing
 
an
object
of
interest
and
regard
to
many
friends
 
with
a
lovely
little
child
to
give
her
joy
for
the
present
,
and
hope
for
the
future
;
while
he
,
the
poor
outcast
,
might
even
lie
dead
by
the
wayside
.
<EOS>
How
could
Hester
love
Sylvia
?
  
<EOS>
Yet
they
were
frequent
companions
that
ensuing
spring
.
<EOS>
Hester
was
not
well
;
and
the
doctors
said
that
the
constant
occupation
in
the
shop
was
too
much
for
her
,
and
that
she
must
,
for
a
time
at
least
,
take
daily
walks
into
the
country
.
  
<EOS>
Sylvia
used
to
beg
to
accompany
her
;
she
and
the
little
girl
often
went
with
Hester
up
the
valley
of
the
river
to
some
of
the
nestling
farms
that
were
hidden
in
the
more
sheltered
nooks
 
for
Hester
was
bidden
to
drink
milk
warm
from
the
cow
;
and
to
go
into
the
familiar
haunts
about
a
farm
was
one
of
the
few
things
in
which
Sylvia
seemed
to
take
much
pleasure
.
<EOS>
She
would
let
little
Bella
toddle
about
while
Hester
sate
and
rested
:
and
she
herself
would
beg
to
milk
the
cow
destined
to
give
the
invalid
her
draught
.
  
<EOS>
One
May
evening
the
three
had
been
out
on
some
such
expedition
;
the
country
side
still
looked
gray
and
bare
,
though
the
leaves
were
showing
on
the
willow
and
blackthorn
and
sloe
,
and
by
the
tinkling
runnels
,
making
hidden
music
along
the
copse
side
,
the
pale
delicate
primrose
buds
were
showing
amid
their
fresh
,
green
,
crinkled
leaves
.
<EOS>
The
larks
had
been
singing
all
the
afternoon
,
but
were
now
dropping
down
into
their
nests
in
the
pasture
fields
;
the
air
had
just
the
sharpness
in
it
which
goes
along
with
a
cloudless
evening
sky
at
that
time
of
the
year
.
  
<EOS>
But
Hester
walked
homewards
slowly
and
languidly
,
speaking
no
word
.
<EOS>
Sylvia
noticed
this
at
first
without
venturing
to
speak
,
for
Hester
was
one
who
disliked
having
her
ailments
noticed
.
<EOS>
But
after
a
while
Hester
stood
still
in
a
sort
of
weary
dreamy
abstraction
;
and
Sylvia
said
to
her
,
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
afeared
yo're
sadly
tired
.
<EOS>
Maybe
we
've
been
too
far
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hester
almost
started
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
!
"
said
she
,
<EOS>
"
it
's
only
my
headache
which
is
worse
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
It
has
been
bad
all
day
;
but
since
I
came
out
it
has
felt
just
as
if
there
were
great
guns
booming
,
till
I
could
almost
pray
'em
to
be
quiet
.
<EOS>
I
am
so
weary
o
'
th
'
sound
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
stepped
out
quickly
towards
home
after
she
had
said
this
,
as
if
she
wished
for
neither
pity
nor
comment
on
what
she
had
said
.
    
<EOS>
THE
RECOGNITION
  
Far
away
,
over
sea
and
land
,
over
sunny
sea
again
,
great
guns
were
booming
on
that
7th
of
May
,
1799
.
  
<EOS>
The
Mediterranean
came
up
with
a
long
roar
on
a
beach
glittering
white
with
snowy
sand
,
and
the
fragments
of
innumerable
sea
-
shells
,
delicate
and
shining
as
porcelain
.
<EOS>
Looking
at
that
shore
from
the
sea
,
a
long
ridge
of
upland
ground
,
beginning
from
an
inland
depth
,
stretched
far
away
into
the
ocean
on
the
right
,
till
it
ended
in
a
great
mountainous
bluff
,
crowned
with
the
white
buildings
of
a
convent
sloping
rapidly
down
into
the
blue
water
at
its
base
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
clear
eastern
air
,
the
different
characters
of
the
foliage
that
clothed
the
sides
of
that
sea
-
washed
mountain
might
be
discerned
from
a
long
distance
by
the
naked
eye
;
the
silver
gray
of
the
olive
-
trees
near
its
summit
;
the
heavy
green
and
bossy
forms
of
the
sycamores
lower
down
;
broken
here
and
there
by
a
solitary
terebinth
or
ilex
tree
,
of
a
deeper
green
and
a
wider
spread
;
till
the
eye
fell
below
on
the
maritime
plain
,
edged
with
the
white
seaboard
and
the
sandy
hillocks
;
with
here
and
there
feathery
palm
-
trees
,
either
isolated
or
in
groups
 
motionless
and
distinct
against
the
hot
purple
air
.
  
<EOS>
Look
again
;
a
little
to
the
left
on
the
sea
-
shore
there
are
the
white
walls
of
a
fortified
town
,
glittering
in
sunlight
,
or
black
in
shadow
.
  
<EOS>
The
fortifications
themselves
run
out
into
the
sea
,
forming
a
port
and
a
haven
against
the
wild
Levantine
storms
;
and
a
lighthouse
rises
out
of
the
waves
to
guide
mariners
into
safety
.
  
<EOS>
Beyond
this
walled
city
,
and
far
away
to
the
left
still
,
there
is
the
same
wide
plain
shut
in
by
the
distant
rising
ground
,
till
the
upland
circuit
comes
closing
in
to
the
north
,
and
the
great
white
rocks
meet
the
deep
tideless
ocean
with
its
intensity
of
blue
colour
.
  
<EOS>
Above
,
the
sky
is
literally
purple
with
heat
;
and
the
pitiless
light
smites
the
gazer
's
weary
eye
as
it
comes
back
from
the
white
shore
.
<EOS>
Nor
does
the
plain
country
in
that
land
offer
the
refuge
and
rest
of
our
own
soft
green
.
<EOS>
The
limestone
rock
underlies
the
vegetation
,
and
gives
a
glittering
,
ashen
hue
to
all
the
bare
patches
,
and
even
to
the
cultivated
parts
which
are
burnt
up
early
in
the
year
.
<EOS>
In
spring
-
time
alone
does
the
country
look
rich
and
fruitful
;
then
the
corn
-
fields
of
the
plain
show
their
capability
of
bearing
,
"
some
fifty
,
some
an
hundred
fold
"
;
down
by
the
brook
Kishon
,
flowing
not
far
from
the
base
of
the
mountainous
promontory
to
the
south
,
there
grow
the
broad
green
fig
-
trees
,
cool
and
fresh
to
look
upon
;
the
orchards
are
full
of
glossy
-
leaved
cherry
-
trees
;
the
tall
amaryllis
puts
forth
crimson
and
yellow
glories
in
the
fields
,
rivalling
the
pomp
of
King
Solomon
;
the
daisies
and
the
hyacinths
spread
their
myriad
flowers
;
the
anemones
,
scarlet
as
blood
,
run
hither
and
thither
over
the
ground
like
dazzling
flames
of
fire
.
  
<EOS>
A
spicy
odour
lingers
in
the
heated
air
;
it
comes
from
the
multitude
of
aromatic
flowers
that
blossom
in
the
early
spring
.
<EOS>
Later
on
they
will
have
withered
and
faded
,
and
the
corn
will
have
been
gathered
,
and
the
deep
green
of
the
eastern
foliage
will
have
assumed
a
kind
of
gray
-
bleached
tint
.
  
<EOS>
Even
now
in
May
,
the
hot
sparkle
of
the
everlasting
sea
,
the
terribly
clear
outline
of
all
objects
,
whether
near
or
distant
,
the
fierce
sun
right
overhead
,
the
dazzling
air
around
,
were
inexpressibly
wearying
to
the
English
eyes
that
kept
their
skilled
watch
,
day
and
night
,
on
the
strongly
-
fortified
coast
-
town
that
lay
out
a
little
to
the
northward
of
where
the
British
ships
were
anchored
.
  
<EOS>
They
had
kept
up
a
flanking
fire
for
many
days
in
aid
of
those
besieged
in
St
Jean
d'Acre
;
and
at
intervals
had
listened
,
impatient
,
to
the
sound
of
the
heavy
siege
guns
,
or
the
sharper
rattle
of
the
French
musketry
.
  
<EOS>
In
the
morning
,
on
the
7th
of
May
,
a
man
at
the
masthead
of
the
_
Tigre
_
sang
out
that
he
saw
ships
in
the
offing
;
and
in
reply
to
the
signal
that
was
hastily
run
up
,
he
saw
the
distant
vessels
hoist
friendly
flags
.
<EOS>
That
May
morning
was
a
busy
time
.
<EOS>
The
besieged
Turks
took
heart
of
grace
;
<EOS>
the
French
outside
,
under
the
command
of
their
great
general
,
made
hasty
preparations
for
a
more
vigorous
assault
than
all
many
,
both
vigorous
and
bloody
,
that
had
gone
before
(
for
the
siege
was
now
at
its
fifty
-
first
day
)
,
in
hopes
of
carrying
the
town
by
storm
before
the
reinforcement
coming
by
sea
could
arrive
;
and
Sir
Sidney
Smith
,
aware
of
Buonaparte
's
desperate
intention
,
ordered
all
the
men
,
both
sailors
and
marines
,
that
could
be
spared
from
the
necessity
of
keeping
up
a
continual
flanking
fire
from
the
ships
upon
the
French
,
to
land
,
and
assist
the
Turks
and
the
British
forces
already
there
in
the
defence
of
the
old
historic
city
.
  
<EOS>
Lieutenant
Kinraid
,
who
had
shared
his
captain
's
daring
adventure
off
the
coast
of
France
three
years
before
,
who
had
been
a
prisoner
with
him
and
Westley
Wright
,
in
the
Temple
at
Paris
,
and
had
escaped
with
them
,
and
,
through
Sir
Sidney
's
earnest
recommendation
,
been
promoted
from
being
a
warrant
officer
to
the
rank
of
lieutenant
,
received
on
this
day
the
honour
from
his
admiral
of
being
appointed
to
an
especial
post
of
danger
.
<EOS>
His
heart
was
like
a
war
-
horse
,
and
said
,
Ha
,
ha
!
<EOS>
as
the
boat
bounded
over
the
waves
that
were
to
land
him
under
the
ancient
machicolated
walls
where
the
Crusaders
made
their
last
stand
in
the
Holy
Land
.
<EOS>
Not
that
Kinraid
knew
or
cared
one
jot
about
those
gallant
knights
of
old
:
all
he
knew
was
,
that
the
French
,
under
Boney
,
were
trying
to
take
the
town
from
the
Turks
,
and
that
his
admiral
said
they
must
not
,
and
so
they
should
not
.
  
<EOS>
He
and
his
men
landed
on
that
sandy
shore
,
and
entered
the
town
by
the
water
-
port
gate
;
he
was
singing
to
himself
his
own
country
song
,
      
<EOS>
Weel
may
the
keel
row
,
the
keel
row
,
&
c.
  
and
his
men
,
with
sailors
'
aptitude
for
music
,
caught
up
the
air
,
and
joined
in
the
burden
with
inarticulate
sounds
.
  
<EOS>
So
,
with
merry
hearts
,
they
threaded
the
narrow
streets
of
Acre
,
hemmed
in
on
either
side
by
the
white
walls
of
Turkish
houses
,
with
small
grated
openings
high
up
,
above
all
chance
of
peeping
intrusion
.
  
<EOS>
Here
and
there
they
met
an
ample
-
robed
and
turbaned
Turk
going
along
with
as
much
haste
as
his
stately
self
-
possession
would
allow
.
<EOS>
But
the
majority
of
the
male
inhabitants
were
gathered
together
to
defend
the
breach
,
where
the
French
guns
thundered
out
far
above
the
heads
of
the
sailors
.
  
<EOS>
They
went
along
none
the
less
merrily
for
the
sound
to
Djezzar
Pacha
's
garden
,
where
the
old
Turk
sate
on
his
carpet
,
beneath
the
shade
of
a
great
terebinth
tree
,
listening
to
the
interpreter
,
who
made
known
to
him
the
meaning
of
the
eager
speeches
of
Sir
Sidney
Smith
and
the
colonel
of
the
marines
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
the
admiral
saw
the
gallant
sailors
of
H.M.S.
_
Tigre
_
,
he
interrupted
the
council
of
war
without
much
ceremony
,
and
going
to
Kinraid
,
he
despatched
them
,
as
before
arranged
,
to
the
North
Ravelin
,
showing
them
the
way
with
rapid
,
clear
directions
.
  
<EOS>
Out
of
respect
to
him
,
they
had
kept
silent
while
in
the
strange
,
desolate
garden
;
but
once
more
in
the
streets
,
the
old
Newcastle
song
rose
up
again
till
the
men
were
,
perforce
,
silenced
by
the
haste
with
which
they
went
to
the
post
of
danger
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
three
o'clock
in
the
afternoon
.
<EOS>
For
many
a
day
these
very
men
had
been
swearing
at
the
terrific
heat
at
this
hour
 
even
when
at
sea
,
fanned
by
the
soft
breeze
;
but
now
,
in
the
midst
of
hot
smoke
,
with
former
carnage
tainting
the
air
,
and
with
the
rush
and
whizz
of
death
perpetually
whistling
in
their
ears
,
they
were
uncomplaining
and
light
-
hearted
.
<EOS>
Many
an
old
joke
,
and
some
new
ones
,
came
brave
and
hearty
,
on
their
cheerful
voices
,
even
though
the
speaker
was
veiled
from
sight
in
great
clouds
of
smoke
,
cloven
only
by
the
bright
flames
of
death
.
  
<EOS>
A
sudden
message
came
;
as
many
of
the
crew
of
the
_
Tigre
_
as
were
under
Lieutenant
Kinraid
's
command
were
to
go
down
to
the
Mole
,
to
assist
the
new
reinforcements
(
seen
by
the
sailor
from
the
masthead
at
day
-
dawn
)
,
under
command
of
Hassan
Bey
,
to
land
at
the
Mole
,
where
Sir
Sidney
then
was
.
  
<EOS>
Off
they
went
,
almost
as
bright
and
thoughtless
as
before
,
though
two
of
their
number
lay
silent
for
ever
at
the
North
Ravelin
 
silenced
in
that
one
little
half
-
hour
.
<EOS>
And
one
went
along
with
the
rest
,
swearing
lustily
at
his
ill
-
luck
in
having
his
right
arm
broken
,
but
ready
to
do
good
business
with
his
left
.
  
<EOS>
They
helped
the
Turkish
troops
to
land
more
with
good
-
will
than
tenderness
;
and
then
,
led
by
Sir
Sidney
,
they
went
under
the
shelter
of
English
guns
to
the
fatal
breach
,
so
often
assailed
,
so
gallantly
defended
,
but
never
so
fiercely
contested
as
on
this
burning
afternoon
.
<EOS>
The
ruins
of
the
massive
wall
that
here
had
been
broken
down
by
the
French
,
were
used
by
them
as
stepping
stones
to
get
on
a
level
with
the
besieged
,
and
so
to
escape
the
heavy
stones
which
the
latter
hurled
down
;
nay
,
even
the
dead
bodies
of
the
morning
's
comrades
were
made
into
ghastly
stairs
.
  
<EOS>
When
Djezzar
Pacha
heard
that
the
British
sailors
were
defending
the
breach
,
headed
by
Sir
Sidney
Smith
,
he
left
his
station
in
the
palace

,
gathered

his
robes
in

,
and
hurried
to
the
breach
;
where
,
with
his
own
hands
,
and
with
right
hearty
good
-
will
,
he
pulled
the
sailors
down
from
the
post
of
danger
,
saying
that
if
he
lost
his
English
friends
he
lost
all
!
  
<EOS>
But
little
recked
the
crew
of
the
_
Tigre
_
of
the
one
old
man
 
Pacha
or
otherwise
 
who
tried
to
hold

back

the

;
they
were
up
and
at
the
French
assailants
clambering
over
the
breach
in

;
and
so

went

,
as

instead

a

,
until
Kinraid

were

,
as

under

that

in

,

;
for

besiegers
had
made

more

by
their
incessant

,
knocking
down

the
city

.
  
<EOS>
"
Fight
your
best
Kinraid
!
"
said

Sidney
;
"
for
there
's
Boney
on
yonder
hill
looking
at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

,
on

,
called
Richard

's

,
there

,

,

,

,
of

;
at
whose

the
aide
-

galloped

to

more

.
  
<EOS>
The
two
ravelins
which
Kinraid
and
his
men
had
to
occupy
,
for
the
purpose
of
sending
a
flanking
fire
upon
the
enemy
,
were
not

from
that
enemy
's
van
.
  
<EOS>
But
at
length
there
was
a
sudden

of
the
French
to
that
part
of
the
wall
where
they
imagined
they
could
enter
unopposed
.
  
<EOS>
Surprised

this

,
Kinraid
ventured

of
the

of
the
ravelin
to
ascertain

cause
;
he
,
safe
and
untouched
during
that
long
afternoon
of
carnage
,
fell
now
,
under
a
stray
musket
-

,
and
lay
helpless
and

upon
the
ground
undiscerned
by
his
men
,
who
were
recalled
to
help
in
the
hot

which
had
been
planned
for
the
French
;
who
,
descending
the
city
walls
into
the
Pacha
's
garden
,
were
attacked
with
sabre
and
dagger
,
and
lay
headless
corpses
under
the
flowering
rose
-
bushes
,
and
by
the
fountain
side
.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid
lay
beyond
the
ravelins
,
many
yards
outside
the
city
walls
.
  
<EOS>
He
was
utterly
helpless
,
for
the
shot
had
broken
his
leg
.
<EOS>
Dead
bodies
of
Frenchmen
lay
strewn
around
him
;
no
Englishman
had
ventured
out
so
far
.
  
<EOS>
All
the
wounded
men
that
he
could
see
were
French
;
and
many
of
these
,
furious
with
pain
,
gnashed
their
teeth
at
him
,
and
cursed
him
aloud
,
till
he
thought
that
his
best
course
was
to
assume
the
semblance
of
death
;
for
some
among
these
men
were
still
capable
of
dragging
themselves
up
to
him
,
and
by
concentrating
all
their
failing
energies
into
one
blow
,
put
him
to
a
speedy
end
.
  
<EOS>
The
outlying
pickets
of
the
French
army
were
within
easy
rifle
shot
;
and
his
uniform
,
although
less
conspicuous
in
colour
than
that
of
the
marines
,
by
whose
sides
he
had
been
fighting
,
would
make
him
a
sure
mark
if
he
so
much
as
moved

arm
.
<EOS>
Yet
how
he
longed
to
turn
,
if
ever
so
slightly
,
so
that
the
cruel
slanting
sun
might
not
beat
full
into
his
aching
eyes
.
<EOS>
Fever
,
too
,
was
coming
upon
him
;
the
pain
in
his
leg
was
every
moment
growing
more
severe
;
the
terrible
thirst
of
the
wounded
,
added
to
the
heat
and

of
the
day
,
made
his
lips
and
tongue
feel
baked
and
dry
,
and
his
whole

seemed
parched

.
<EOS>
Thoughts
of
other
days
,
of
cool
Greenland

,
where
ice

,
of
grassy

,
began

past
more

present
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
great

he
brought
his
wandering

back
;
he
knew
where
he
was
now
,
and
could
weigh
the

of
his
life
,
which
were
but
small
;
the
unwonted

came
to

as
he
thought
of
the
newly
-
made
wife
in
her
English
home
,
who
might
never
know
how
he
died
thinking

.
  
<EOS>
Suddenly

saw
a
party

under

of

,
to

,

.
<EOS>
They
were
so
near
he
could
see
their

,
could

;
yet
he
durst
not

them
when
he
lay
within
range
of
the
French
picket
's

.
  
<EOS>
For
one

he
could
not
resist
raising

,
to
give

a
chance
for

;
before
the
unclean
creatures
that
infest

camp
came
round

to
strip

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
He

;
he
lay
there

.
  
<EOS>
That
strong
clear
sunbeam
had
wrought

salvation
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
recognized
as
men
are
recognized
when
they
stand

red

fire
;
the
same
despair
of
help
,
of
hopeless

to
life
,
stamped

in

.
  
<EOS>
One
man
left

,

forwards
,
forwards

among

enemy
's
wounded
,
within

;
he
bent

Kinraid
;
he
seemed

understand

;
he

,

;

within

.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid

racked

agony

his
dangling

,
and

seemed

;

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Yet

<EOS>
"
I
niver

ha
'
kept

!
"
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
When

,
and
,

.
  
<EOS>
The

was
away

,
and

;

,

of
any
Philip
Hepburn
.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid
passed

,

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
Partly

,

,

,

to

-

'

.
  
<EOS>
He
,

,

the

,
however

.
  
<EOS>
He
had

upon

so

,
that
he

by

.
<EOS>
However
,
he
had

that
the

,

<EOS>
There

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
Kinraid

,

Hepburn

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
man
was
no

;

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
I

;

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
"

,

<EOS>

,

"

.

<EOS>
But

it
was
;
and
as
you
ca
n't

,
let
me

.
<EOS>
It

him
,

.
<EOS>
It

flesh

,
and
not

,

.
<EOS>
So
get

,

leave
me

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
All
this
time
Stephen
Freeman
lay
friendless
,
sick
,
and
shattered
,
on
board
the
_
Theseus
_
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
been
about
his
duty
close
to
some

that
were
placed
on
her

;
a
gay

was

one
of
these
by

;
and

,
in
which
the
poor

,
cleaning

near
,
was

,
the
very

of
all

by

.
<EOS>
They
said

was
a

that
his

were
spared
;
but
he
could
hardly
feel
anything
to
be

,
as

in

,

,
wounded

,
and
feeling
that
he
was
disabled

if

.
<EOS>
Of

(
and
they
were
many
)
<EOS>
none

so

,

,

,
as
the
Philip
Hepburn
about
whom

inquiries
were
being
made
at
that

.
    
<EOS>
CONFIDENCES
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
little
later
on
in
that
same
summer
that
Mrs.
Brunton
came
to
visit
her
sister
Bessy
.
  
<EOS>
Bessy
was
married
to
a
tolerably
well
-
to
-

farmer
who
lived
at
an
almost
equal
distance
between
Monkshaven
and
Hartswell
;
but
from
old

and

the

was
regarded
as
the
Dawsons
'
market

;
so
Bessy
seldom
or
never
saw
her
old

in
Monkshaven
.
  
<EOS>
But
Mrs.
Brunton
was
far
too
flourishing
a
person
not
to
speak
out
her
wishes
,
and
have

.
<EOS>
She
had
no
notion
,
she

,
of
coming
such

only
to
see
Bessy
and
her
husband
,
and
not
to
have

sight

at

.
<EOS>
She
might
have
added
,
that

would
be
as
good

lost
if

was
not
displayed
among
those
who
,

her
as
Molly
Corney
,
and

less

in

than
she

,
would

upon

with

,
if

.
  
<EOS>
So

's

Brunton
in
all

at

in
the
market

,

Hepburn
and

's

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

met

and
each

<EOS>

<EOS>
AN
UNEXPECTED
MESSENGER
  
<EOS>
After
this
agitation
,
and
these
partial

,
no

the

of
Philip
for

.
<EOS>
They
avoided

;
and
none

.
  
<EOS>
One

little

with

,
and

a

;

,

.

<EOS>
THE
BEDESMAN
OF
ST
SEPULCHRE
  
<EOS>
Philip
lay
long
ill
on
board
the
hospital
ship
.
<EOS>
If
his
heart
had
been
light
,
he
might
have
rallied
sooner
;
but
he
was
so
depressed
he
did
not
care
to
live
.
<EOS>
His
shattered
jaw
-
bone
,
his
burnt
and
blackened
face
,
his
many
injuries
of
body
,
were
torture
to
both
his
physical
frame
,
and
his
sick
,
weary
heart
.
<EOS>
No
more
chance
for
him
,
if
indeed
there
ever
had
been
any
,
of
returning
gay
and
gallant
,
and
thus
regaining
his
wife
's
love
.
<EOS>
This
had
been
his
poor
,
foolish
vision
in
the
first
hour
of
his
enlistment
;
and
the
vain
dream
had
recurred
more
than
once
in
the
feverish
stage
of
excitement
which
the
new
scenes
into
which
he
had
been
hurried
as
a
recruit
had
called
forth
.
<EOS>
But
that
was
all
over
now
.
<EOS>
He
knew
that
it
was
the
most
unlikely
thing
in
the
world
to
have
come
to
pass
;
and
yet
those
were
happy
days
when
he
could
think
of
it
as
barely
possible
.
<EOS>
Now
all
he
could
look
forward
to
was
disfigurement
,
feebleness
,
and
the
bare
pittance
that
keeps
pensioners
from
absolute
want
.
  
<EOS>
Those
around
him
were
kind
enough
to
him
in
their
fashion
,
and
attended
to
his
bodily
requirements
;
but
they
had
no
notion
of
listening
to
any
revelations
of
unhappiness
,
if
Philip
had
been
the
man
to
make
confidences
of
that
kind
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
he
lay
very
still
in
his
berth
,
seldom
asking
for
anything
,
and
always
saying
he
was
better
,
when
the
ship
-
surgeon
came
round
with
his
daily
inquiries
.
<EOS>
But
he
did
not
care
to
rally
,
and
was
rather
sorry
to
find
that
his
case
was
considered
so
interesting
in
a
surgical
point
of
view
,
that
he
was
likely
to
receive
a
good
deal
more
than
the
average
amount
of
attention
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
owing
to
this
that
he
recovered
at
all
.
<EOS>
The
doctors
said
it
was
the
heat
that
made
him
languid
,
for
that
his
wounds
and
burns
were
all
doing
well
at
last
;
and
by
-
and
-
by
<EOS>
they
told
him
they
had
ordered
him
"
home
"
.
<EOS>
His
pulse
sank
under
the
surgeon
's
finger
at
the
mention
of
the
word
;
but
he
did
not
say
a
word
.
<EOS>
He
was
too
indifferent
to
life
and
the
world
to
have
a
will
;
otherwise
they
might
have
kept
their
pet
patient
a
little
longer
where
he
was
.
  
<EOS>
Slowly
passing
from
ship
to
ship
as
occasion
served
;
resting
here
and
there
in
garrison
hospitals
,
Philip
at
length
reached
Portsmouth
on
the
evening
of
a
September
day
in
1799
.
<EOS>
The
transport
-
ship
in
which
he
was
,
was
loaded
with
wounded
and
invalided
soldiers
and
sailors
;
all

could
manage
it
in
any
way
struggled
on
deck
to
catch
the
first
view
of
the
white
coasts
of
England
.
<EOS>
One
man
lifted
his
arm
,
took
off
his
cap
,
and
feebly
waved
it
aloft
,
crying
,
"
Old
England
for
ever
!
"
<EOS>
in
a
faint

voice
,
and
then
burst
into
tears
and
sobbed
aloud
.
<EOS>
Others
tried
to
pipe
up
"
Rule
Britannia
"
,
while
more
sate
,
weak
and
motionless
,
looking
towards
the
shores
that
once
,
not
so
long
ago
,
they
never
thought
to
see
again
.
<EOS>
Philip
was
one
of
these
;
his
place
a
little
apart
from
the
other
men
.
<EOS>
He
was
muffled
up
in
a
great
military
cloak
that
had
been
given
him
by
one
of
his
officers
;
he
felt
the
September

chill
after
his
sojourn
in
a
warmer
climate
,
and
in
his
shattered
state
of
health
.
  
<EOS>
As
the
ship
came
in
sight
of
Portsmouth
harbour
,
the
signal
flags
ran
up
the
ropes
;
the
beloved
Union
Jack
floated
triumphantly
over
all
.
<EOS>
Return
signals
were
made
from
the
harbour
;
on
board
all
became
bustle
and
preparation
for
landing
;
while
on
shore
there
was
the
evident
movement
of
expectation
,
and
men
in
uniform
were
seen
pressing
their
way
to
the
front
,
as
if
to

the
right

.
<EOS>
They
were
the
men
from
the
barrack
hospital
,
that
had
been
signalled
for
,
come
down
with
ambulance

and
other
marks
of
forethought
for
the
sick
and
wounded
,
who
were
returning
to
the
country
for
which
they
had
fought
and
suffered
.
  
<EOS>
With
a
dash
and
a
great
rocking
swing
the
vessel
came
up
to
her
appointed
place
,
and
was
safely

.
<EOS>
Philip
sat
still
,
almost
as
if
he
had
no
part
in
the
cries
of
welcome
,
the

care
,
the
loud

that
cut

,
and
pierced

nerves
through
and
through
.
<EOS>
But
one
in
authority
gave
the
order
;
and
Philip
,
disciplined
to
obedience
,
rose
to
find

.
<EOS>
Passive

he
seemed
to
be
,
he
had
his
likings
for
particular
comrades
;
there
was
one

,
a
man
as

Philip
as
well
could
be
,
to

the
latter
had
always
attached
himself
;
a
merry
fellow
from
Somersetshire
,
who
was
almost
always
cheerful
and
bright
,
though
Philip
had
overheard
the
doctors
<EOS>
say
he
would
never
be
the
man
he
was
<EOS>
before
he
had
that
shot
through
the
side
.
<EOS>
This
marine
would
often
sit
making
his
fellows
laugh
,
and
laughing
himself
at
his
own
good
-
humoured
jokes
,
till
so

of
coughing
came

that

would
die
in

.
<EOS>
After
one

he
had
gasped
out
some
words
,
which
led
Philip
to
question

a
little
;
and
it
turned
out
that
in
the
quiet
little
village
of
Potterne
,
far

,
nestled
beneath
the
high

of
Salisbury

,
he
had
a
wife
and
a
child
,
a
little
girl
,
just
the
same
age
even

week
as
Philip
's

.
<EOS>
It

that
drew
Philip
towards
the
man
;
and
this
that
made
Philip
wait
and
go
ashore
along
with
the
poor
consumptive

.
  
<EOS>
The
litters
had
moved
off
towards
the
hospital
,
the
sergeant
in
charge
had
given
his
words
of
command
to

,
who
tried

,

into

;
but
soon
,
very

,
the

,

;
and
felt
as

the
rough

and

from
the

were

.
<EOS>
Philip
and

were
about

,

,
and

Philip

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Jem
!
"
she

,
"
I
've
walked
all

from
Potterne
.
<EOS>
I
've
never

but

for
Nelly
,
and
now
I
've
got
you
once
again
<EOS>
,
I
've
got
you
once
again
,

!
"
  
<EOS>
She
did

the

that
had

over

husband
since
she
parted
with
him
a
ruddy
young

;
she

once
again
,

,

;
she

,

from

,
while

by

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
Jem
coughed
,
poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
he
coughed

churchyard

;
and
Philip
bitterly
envied
him
 
envied
his
life
,
envied
his
approaching

;
for
was

not
wrapped
round
with
that
woman
's
tender

,
and
is

?
<EOS>
Philip
had
felt
as
if

own

was

,

.
<EOS>
But

of

's

,
he
felt
that

had
yet

.
  
<EOS>
The
road
they
had
to
go
was
full
of
people
,
kept
off
in
some

by
the
guard
of

.
<EOS>
All
sorts
of
kindly

,
and
many
a

,
were

poor

.
<EOS>
Philip
's

,
and

lower

,
were

;
his
cap
was

;
he

,

.
  
<EOS>
They
came
to
a
standstill
from
some

at
the
corner

.
<EOS>
Down

of
this

a

with
a

was

,
with

that
told

.
<EOS>
He
stayed
his

though
,
when
he

of

;

,
"
same
uniform
,
"
"
for

,
"
to

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,

;
he
was
close
to
Philip
,
 
poor
sad
Philip
absorbed
in

own

,
 
so

that
he
noticed

till

at

,
having
the

,

which

,

;
and

,
though

knew

,

,

,
 
<EOS>
the
man
whose

he
had
saved
once
,
and
would

again
,
at

risk

,
but

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Here
,
my

,

,
"
forcing

's

.
<EOS>
"
I
wish

more
;
I
'd

.
"
  
<EOS>
Philip

,

Captain
Kinraid
,

;
nor

,

Philip

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
Indeed

,

,

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
They

,
and
spoke

more

.
<EOS>
It
was
no

to
him
to
give
that
away
which
burned
his

as

he

.
  
<EOS>
Philip
knew
that

he
had

in

_
Theseus
_

.
<EOS>
He

they

.
<EOS>
But
he
had
little

in
his
future
life
;
he
was
without

,
and
in
a
depressed
state
of
health
.
<EOS>
He
remained
for
some
little

,
and
then
went
through
all

forms
of
dismissal
on
account
of
wounds
received
in

,
and
was
turned
out

upon
the

,
uncertain
where
to

,
indifferent

to

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
fine
,
warm
October
weather
as
he
turned
his
back
upon
the
coast
,
and
set
off

.
<EOS>
Green
leaves
were
yet
upon
the

;
the

were
one
flush
of

and
the
wild
rough
-

;
the

were

with
the

-

,

.
<EOS>
The

were
gay

and

and

,
and
the
bright

of

through

.
  
<EOS>
The
war
was
a
popular
one
,
and
,
as
a
natural

,
soldiers
and
sailors
were
heroes
everywhere
.
<EOS>
Philip
's
long
drooping
form
,
his
arm
hung
in

,
his
face
scarred
and
blackened
<EOS>
,
his
jaw
bound
up
with
a
black
silk
handkerchief
;
these
marks
of
active
service
were
reverenced
by
the
rustic

as

had
been
crowns
and

.
<EOS>
Many
a
hard
-
handed
labourer
left
his

by
the
chimney
corner
,
and
came
to
his
door
to
have

at
one
who
had
been
fighting
the
French
,
and
pushed
forward
to
have
a

the

's

as

back
the
empty
cup
into
the
good
wife
's

,
for
the
kind
homely

were
ever

with

to

feverish

's
thirst
when
he
stopped
at

.
  
<EOS>
At

house
he
had
had
a

of

more

,
for
the

full

that

,

a

had
seen
service
.
<EOS>
The
rustic

would

Philip
,
and
smoke

,
and
then
question
and
discuss
till

;
and

extra

.
  
<EOS>
Altogether

turned

out
to
Philip
just

;
and

needed

.
<EOS>
Day

northwards
,
making
<EOS>
but
the
slow
progress
of
a
feeble
man
,
and
yet
this
short

walk
tired
him
so
much
that
he
longed
for
rest
 
for
the
morning
to
come
when
he
needed

to
feel
that

hour

.
  
<EOS>
He
was

this

was

near

,

.
<EOS>
This
place
might
be
yet
two

;
he

looking

.
<EOS>
A

,
observed

,
and
told

for

,

a

on
,
he

the

,
where

,

might

and
rest

on

old

.
<EOS>
Obeying

,
Philip
came
upon
a

which
dated
from
the
time
of
Henry

Fifth
.
<EOS>
Some

who
had
fought

,
and
had

and

,

,
to

,

wherein

were

he

all

(
which

rather

,
pretty

A
FABLE
<EOS>
AT
FAULT
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>
He
had
always

and

.
<EOS>
In

's
he
met

day

,

,

was
over

.
<EOS>
The

employment
his

,

and
chamber
were
,
at
the
beginning
of
his
time
of
occupation
,
as
much
bodily
labour
as
he
could
manage
.
<EOS>
There
was
something
stately
and
utterly
removed
from
all
Philip
's
previous
existence
in
the
forms
observed
at
every
day
's
dinner
,
when
the
twelve
bedesmen
met
in
the
large
quaint
hall
,
and
the
warden
came
in
his
college
-

and

to
say
the
long

which
wound
up
with
something
very
like

for
the

Sir
Simon
Bray
.
<EOS>
It

some

to
get
a
reply

ship
letters
in
those
times
when
no

could

where
the

might

.
  
<EOS>
And

Dr

had
received

of
Stephen
Freeman
,
which
his

's

,
Philip
had

restless
and

in
the
midst
of
all

.
  
<EOS>
Sitting
alone

his
fire
in
the
long

,

of
his
past
life
rose

;

;

;

;

of

poor

;
his

his
child
's

;
and
then
he
came
to
that
last

at

:
and
he
went
over
and
over
again
the
torturing
details
,
the
looks
of
contempt

anger
,
the
words

loathing

,
till

,
out

with
Sylvia
,
to
believe
that
he
was
indeed
the
wretch

.
  
<EOS>
He
forgot
his
own
excuses
for
having
acted
as
he
had
done
;
though
these
excuses
had
at
one
time

.
<EOS>
After
long
thought
and

came
some

.
<EOS>
What
was

doing
now
?
<EOS>
Where
was
she
?
<EOS>
What
was
his
child
like
 
his
child
as
well
as
hers
?
<EOS>
And
then
he
remembered
the
poor
footsore
wife
and
the
little
girl
she

in

arms
,
that

just
the

Bella
;

child
more
,
that

might

.
  
<EOS>
One
night
he
had
gone
round
this
mill

of

till
he
was
weary
to
the
very

.
<EOS>
To

he

the
old

,
hoping

.
<EOS>
There

an
old

_

_
;

;
half

1774
,

_
Seven

_
.
<EOS>
Philip
took

last
,
which
he
had
never
seen
before
.
<EOS>
In

he
read
how
Sir
Guy
,
Earl
of
Warwick
,
went
to
fight
the
Paynim
in
his
own
country
,
and
was
away
for
seven

years
;
and

came
back
his
own
wife
Phillis
,
the
countess
in
her
castle
,
did
not
know
the
poor
travel

,
who
came
daily
to

of

at

along

many

and
much
poor
.
<EOS>
But

last
,
when
he
lay
a
-
dying
in

,

sent

but
to
them
twain
.
<EOS>
And

came
with
great
speed
,
for

who
had
sent
for

;

many

he

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
old

known

most
people
from
their

was
all

.
<EOS>
He
did
not

in
the
truth

,
because

was

.
<EOS>
But
he
could
not

that
this

might

;
and
that
Guy

might

as

,

,

,
as

Sylvia

.
<EOS>
The
old
room
,

quiet

looked
,

everything
that

;

predisposed

to

the
story
he
had
just

reading
as
a
faithful

of
two
lovers
whose

were
long
since

.
<EOS>
He
thought
that
if
he
could
thus
see
Sylvia
,
himself
unknown
,
unseen
 
could
live
at
her
gates
,
so
to

,
and

upon
her
and
his
child
 
some

,
when

-

he
might
send
for

,
and

.
<EOS>
Or
perhaps
 
and
so
he
lost

,
and
from

,
passed

to

.
<EOS>
All

long
Guy

,

and

,
passed

of

;

;
but

not
the
less
strong
for

.
<EOS>
He
felt
as
if
he
were
called
to
Monkshaven
,
wanted
at
Monkshaven
,
and

he

;

,

;
and

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
In

small
oblong
of
looking
-
glass

,
Philip
caught
the

of
his
own
face
,
and
laughed

sight
.
<EOS>
The
thin

lay
upon

temples
in
the
flakes
that
betoken
long
ill

;
his

were

,
and

had

in

;
but

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
As

,

Guy

.
<EOS>
But

,
and
might

.
<EOS>
His

.
  
<EOS>
So

.
<EOS>
Such

in

's

;

.
  
<EOS>
"

's
<EOS>
argues

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

'
  
"
<EOS>
But
?
<EOS>
What

against

,

?
<EOS>
Not
<EOS>
but
what
there

;

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Ten

,

,

;

.
<EOS>
Mind
!
<EOS>
no

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

;
and

,

,

Stephen

,
had

a

,

,

to

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
So

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

was
well
;
and
Philip

upon
St
Sepulchre
's
with

four

'

.
  
<EOS>
He
was
stronger
,
too
,
in
body
,
more

of

that

.
<EOS>
He
had
saved
some

from

,
and
might

.
<EOS>
Yet
the
gentle
,

,

white

always
did
away

first

as

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
February
when
Philip
left
St
Sepulchre
's
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
week
in
April
when
he
began
to
recognize
the
familiar
objects
between
York
and
Monkshaven
.
<EOS>
And
now
he
began
to
hang

,
and
to
question
the
wisdom
of
what
he
had
done
 
just
as
the
warden
had

.
<EOS>
The
last
night
of
his
two
hundred
mile
walk
he

at
the
little
inn
at
which
he
had
been
enlisted
nearly

before
.
<EOS>
It
was
by
no
intention
of
his
that
he
rested
at
that
identical
place
.
<EOS>
Night
was
drawing
on
;
and
,
in
making
,
as
he
thought
,
a
short
cut
,
he
had
missed
his
way
,
and
was
fain
to
seek
shelter
where
he
might
find
it
.
<EOS>
But
it
brought
him
very
straight
face
to
face
with
his
life
at
that
time
,
and
ever
since
.
<EOS>
His
mad
,
wild
hopes
 
half
the
result
of
intoxication
,
as
he
now
knew
 
all
dead
and
gone
;
the
career
then
freshly
opening
shut
up
against

now
;
his

and
health
changed
into

,
and

home

that
should

opened
wide
its
doors
to
console

for
all
,
why
in
two
years
Death
might
have
been
busy
,
and
taken
away
from

his
last
feeble

of
the
faint

of
seeing
his
beloved
without
being
seen
or
known
of
her
.
<EOS>
All
that

and
all
the
next
day
,
the
fear
of
Sylvia
's
possible
death
overclouded
his
heart
.
<EOS>
It
was
strange
that
he
had
hardly
ever
thought
of
this
before
;
so
strange
,
that
now
,
when
the
terror
came
,
it

him
,
and
he
could
almost
have
sworn
that
she
must
be
lying

in
Monkshaven
churchyard
.
<EOS>
Or
was
it
little
Bella
,
that
blooming
,
lovely
babe
,
whom
he
was
never
to
see
again
?
<EOS>
There
was
the
tolling
of

in
the
distant
air
to
his
disturbed
fancy
,
and
the
cry
of
the
happy
birds
,
the
plaintive

of
the
new
-

,
were
all

of
evil
import
to
him
.
  
<EOS>
As
well
as
he
could
,
he
found
his
way
back
to
Monkshaven
,
over
the
wild
heights
and
moors
he
had
crossed
on
that
black

of
misery
;
why
he
should
have
chosen
that
path
<EOS>
he
could
not
tell
 
it
was
as
if
he
were
led
,
and
had
no
free
will
of
his
own
.
  
<EOS>
The
soft
clear
evening
was
drawing
on
,
and
his
heart
beat
thick
,
and
then
stopped
,
only
to
start
again
with
fresh
violence
.
<EOS>
There
he
was
,
at
the
top
of
the
long
,
steep

that
was
in
some
parts
a
literal

leading
down

hill

into
the

,
through
the
very
entry
up
which
he
had
passed
when
he
shrank

from
his
former
and
his
then

life
.
<EOS>
There
he
stood
,
looking
down
once
more
at
the
numerous
irregular
roofs
,
the
many
stacks
of
chimneys
below
him
,
seeking
out
that
which
had
once
been
his
own
dwelling
 
who
dwelt
there
now
?
  
<EOS>
The
yellower
gleams
grew
narrower
;
the
evening
shadows
broader
,
and
Philip
crept
down
the
lane
a
weary
,
woeful
man
.
<EOS>
At
every
gap
in
the
close
-
packed
buildings
he
heard
the
merry
music
of
a
band
,
the
cheerful
sound
of
excited
voices
.
<EOS>
Still
he
descended
slowly
,
scarcely
wondering
what
it
could
be
,
for
it
was
not
associated
in
his
mind
with
the
one
pervading
thought
of
Sylvia
.
  
<EOS>
When
he
came
to
the
angle

junction
between
the
lane
and
the
High
Street
,
he
seemed

all
at
once
into
the
very
centre
of
the
bustle
,
and
he
drew
himself
up
into
a
corner

deep
shadow
,
from
whence
he
could
look
out
upon
the
street
.
  
<EOS>
A
circus
was
making
its
grand
entry
into
Monkshaven
,
with
all
the
pomp
of
colour
and
of
noise
that
it
could
muster
.
<EOS>
Trumpeters
in
parti
-

clothes

first
,
blaring
out
triumphant
discord
.
<EOS>
Next
came
a
gold
-
and
-
scarlet
chariot
drawn
by
six
piebald
horses
,
and
the
windings
of
this
team
through
the
tortuous
narrow
street
were
pretty
enough
to
look
upon
.
<EOS>
In
the

sate

and

,
heroes
and

,
or
what
were
meant
for
such
;
all

little
boys

of
the

envied
them
;
but
they
themselves
were
very
much
tired
,
and
shivering
with
cold
in
their
heroic
pomp
of
classic
clothing
.
<EOS>
All
this
Philip
might
have
seen
;
did

,
in
fact
;
but
heeded
not
one
jot
.
<EOS>
Almost

him
,
not
ten

raised

the
well

,
holding
a
child
,
a
merry

child
,
up

.
<EOS>
She

Sylvia
,
was
laughing
for

,
and
for

pleasure
.
<EOS>
She

better

Coulson
,

.
<EOS>
Philip
saw
it
all
;
her
bonny

,
her
pretty
matronly
form
,
her
evident

mind

.
<EOS>
The
years
that
he
had
spent
in
gloomy

,
amongst
wild

,
on
land
or

,
his
life
in
frequent

a

end
,
had
gone
by
with
her
like
sunny
days
;
all
the
more
sunny
because
he
was
not
there
.
<EOS>
So
bitterly
thought
the
poor
disabled
marine
,
as
,
weary
and

,
he
stood
in
the

upon
the
home

his

,
the
wife
that
should
have
welcomed

,
the
child
that
should
have
been

comfort
.
<EOS>
He
had
banished
himself
from
his
home
;
his
wife
had
forsworn

;
his
child
was
blossoming
into
intelligence
unwitting
of
any
father
.
<EOS>
Wife
,
and
child
,
and
home
,
were
all
doing
well
without
him
;
what
madness
had
tempted
him
thither
?
<EOS>
an

,
like

,
he
had
thought
she
might
be
dead
 
dead

her

the

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
As

,

Sylvia
always

the
warm

the

and

sweet

old

.
<EOS>
He
had
a
sort

of

own
which
kept

going
to
see
her
too
often
,
even

;
but

to
the
times
when
he

this

.
<EOS>

had
,

the

,

the
happiest
in
all
his
long

.
<EOS>
Sylvia
's
father
had
always
treated

the
rough

of

;

's
mother
had
never
stinted

of
the
best

was
going
;

,

ill

,

<EOS>

as

.

<EOS>
FIRST
WORDS
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
spring
of
1800
.
<EOS>
Old
people
yet
can
tell
of
the
hard
famine
of
that
year
.
<EOS>
The
harvest
of
the
autumn
before
had
failed
;
the
war
and
the
corn
laws
had
brought
the
price
of
corn
up
to
a
famine
rate
;
and
much
of
what
came
into
the
market
was
unsound
,
and
consequently
unfit
for
food
,
yet
hungry
creatures
bought
it
eagerly
,
and
tried
to
cheat
disease
by
mixing
the
damp
,
sweet
,
clammy
flour
with
rice
or
potato
meal
.
<EOS>
Rich
families
denied
themselves
pastry
and
all
unnecessary
and
luxurious
uses
of
wheat
in
any
shape
;
the
duty
on
hair
-
powder
was
increased
;
and
all
these
palliatives
were
but
as
drops
in
the
ocean
of
the
great
want
of
the
people
.
  
<EOS>
Philip
,
in
spite
of
himself
,
recovered
and
grew
stronger
;
and
as
he
grew
stronger
hunger
took
the
place
of
loathing
dislike
to
food
.
<EOS>
But
his
money
was
all
spent
;
and
what
was
his
poor
pension
of
sixpence
a
day
in
that
terrible
year
of
famine
?
<EOS>
Many
a
summer
's
night
he
walked
for
hours
and
hours
round
the
house
which
once
was
his
,
which
might
be
his
now
,
with
all
its
homely
,
blessed

,
<EOS>
could
he
but
go
and
assert

it
.
<EOS>
But
to

,
and
in
his
poor

guise
assert
that
right
<EOS>
,

be
other
than
Philip

.
<EOS>

old

hill

summer

once

good

William

his
own

.
<EOS>
Then
Philip
 
there

;

the

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

herself

<EOS>
Oh

Death
.
    
<EOS>
SAVED

<EOS>

Poor

!
